proctext.para: The PRESIDENT (Senator the Hon. Harold Young) took the chair at 10 a.m., and read prayers.

talk.start.para: —Has the attention of the Minister representing the Treasurer been drawn to an extraordinary statement in yesterday's Courier-Mail that the Queensland Minister for Works and Housing, Mr Wharton, said on Tuesday that the Queensland Housing Commission has a policy of lending families more money if the wife says that she has been sterilised? Does the Federal Government make funds available to the Queensland Government for use by the Queensland Housing Commission? If so, will the Federal Government immediately notify the Queensland Government that the unbelievable policy of the Queensland Housing Commission relating to sterilisation must be discontinued before further funds are made available for its use?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — I am not aware of the statement. I do not know whether the Treasurer or the relevant Minister has had the matter drawn to his attention. It does appear to be an extraordinary statement by the Queensland Housing Commission. Of course, under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement funds are made available to the States for housing assistance. If this statement has been made by an official of the Housing Commission, perhaps the Queensland Minister will wish to make some comment on the statement. I will draw this matter to the attention of the relevant Commonwealth Ministers and see what action they feel is necessary to achieve a satisfactory outcome in relation to what appears to be an extraordinary statement.

question.speaker: Teague Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: —I ask the Minister for National Development and Energy whether he is aware that the Premier of South Australia, in his policy speech, said:

question.para: A Liberal government will continue to have as its aim the supply of the best possible quality water at the lowest possible cost.
This will include implementation of the scheme to filter Adelaide's water supply and the filtration of water in the Iron Triangle, Mid-North and Yorke Peninsula and the Barossa Valley.
A Liberal government will continue to place considerable emphasis on the careful management and monitoring of the water quality of the River Murray.
What steps has the Commonwealth Government taken to ensure that additional financial resources are available to the South Australian Government to achieve these goals?

talk.start.para: —Who started the scheme? The Whitlam and Dunstan governments did . I hope he tells us that.

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I am grateful for Senator McLaren's help in answering the question. As usual, the significance of the question has escaped him. The Premier and the Government of South Australia have been very diligent in working towards higher water quality for Adelaide and South Australia. There are two factors involved-salinity and what is called turbidity. A lot of organic matter is churned up, particularly around Murray Bridge-so Senator McLaren tells me; I had a look at that the other day-and that creates an unpleasant appearance for drinking water.
—Does he churn it up?

—Wherever Senator McLaren was, things would be stirred up; there would be a degree of turbidity. The first stage of the filtration process for the Adelaide water supply, very heavily subsidised by the Federal Government, has been completed and the Premier announced recently the commencement of the second stage. That will be very good news for the people of Adelaide. The Commonwealth Government is very keen that this should continue. The best news on the salinity problem is that the River Murray Waters Agreement has been signed by all States. I will be introducing legislation relating to that agreement in this session. That, of course, enforces water quality control. It will be the biggest significant contribution to South Australia. Of course, the Commonwealth plays a major part in that.

answer.para: The Dartmouth Dam, which is functioning now, will enable a flushing, particularly at times of drought. If it were not in existence today we would have trouble with the Hume Weir and all the way down the river. The Maunsell report and its salinity recommendations are being acted upon. The Commonwealth Government is working with the States on a variety of anti-salinity processes. I will be associated with the opening of one within the next week. Taken all in all, in terms of both salinity and turbidity, the Commonwealth is working very earnestly and effectively with the State Government to bring about better water quality, both for drinking and for irrigation purposes.

One other thing is fundamental to the salinity problem, and that is that we must encourage better irrigation processes. We must try to abandon flood irrigation and utilise drip irrigation so that the salt table is not lifted and so that salt, which now amounts to about 1,250,000 tonnes a year, does not pass down the Murray River.

talk.start.para: —How are you going to encourage that?

—The question is asked: How are we encouraging that? A task force was set up to see what kind of incentives can be given, including tax incentives. We will be bringing policies towards that end. Discussions are going on jointly with the various governments at the moment. Fundamentally, all good husbandry and farming should be based on an understanding that flood irrigation is a wasteful use of water and results in a dangerous lifting of the salt table. Orchardists in the area, in particular, have suffered very badly in the past from destruction of their crops by salt.

—My question is directed to the Leader of the Government in the Senate. I refer him to the announcement that the Government will allow vendor shareholders 12 months to pay 75 per cent of company tax owed as a result of evasion schemes. They will also now, according to the announcement, escape the proposed 20 per cent penalty as long as they make a down payment of 25 per cent of the amount owing to the Australian Taxation Office. Will the Minister inform the Senate whether this gesture will also apply to other taxpayers who find themselves owing money to the Taxation Office, or will it apply only to those members of the business community who, while the Government turned a blind eye, were encouraged to avoid paying taxes on a gigantic scale?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —The Government has been conscious that in the recovery of this money-it intends to recover it-there may be very considerable hardship, not just to the vendor shareholders but to those people who are employees in ventures in which the money was invested.
—Why do you not give the Commissioner discretion instead of giving a blanket exemption?
—If the Labor Party is not interested in overcoming hardship for people who are quite innocent-that is, employees in industries that might be affected-this Government is interested.
—Why do you not just tell us they are tax cheats?
—Order! Senator Walsh, I have asked you once this morning not to interject. You have been constantly interjecting since Question Time began. I ask you to cease your continuing interjections.

—I repeat: The Government took into account the fact that vendor shareholders who gained an extra amount by way of what ought to have been paid as company tax, taking it in as capitalisation of their shares, may well have invested that extra amount in businesses which employ people. Therefore, if there were a crash program to recover with immediacy, those whom they employ-Senator Button grins, presumably because he takes some satisfaction in this-may suffer hardship, which they do not deserve. I would have thought that everybody in this Parliament would have agreed with, and supported, such a measure. I repeat that it will not enable the vendor shareholders to escape their responsibility.

answer.para: The fact is that the recoupment of money from vendor shareholders is not a recoupment in relation to a criminal practice. It is under the ordinary taxation laws relating to the recoupment of taxation that was liable to be paid and that the Government now requires to be paid. Therefore, penalties will not be imposed . As to the position of other taxpayers, it is my clear understanding that the Commissioner of Taxation has discretion to make arrangements with taxpayers if aggravated hardship is involved. There will be no difficulty in applying that provision in the future. Apparently Senator Button is opposed to this extension of time and to trying to prevent placing at risk the jobs of employees who have had nothing to do with this matter.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industry. Under section 39A of the Wool Industry Act ministerial approval is required for the processing of the stockpile of wool controlled by the Australian Wool Corporation. I ask: Is this processing restricted to the stockpile in Australia or does it extend to other parts of the world? If it extends outside Australia, what assurances can the Minister give that Australian suppliers and manufacturers who have markets outside Australia will not be deliberately undercut and have their markets jeopardised? Can the Senate be given an assurance that such approval or authority will be withdrawn once the stockpile of carbonised wool has reached a satisfactory level?

—The question raised by Senator Watson is very technical and complicated and certainly is not one that I am able to answer of my own immediate knowledge. However, I would like to comment that the stockpiling of wool by the Australian Wool Corporation does appear to be one of the more successful exercises pursued in assisting the marketing of primary production. Clearly, the objective is to try to ensure a reasonably stable market. There would be no wish, in the administration of that legislation, to damage any part of the industry, whether it be the processors or the producers. Having made that background comment, I will ask the Minister for Primary Industry to advise on the specific point raised. However, I am sure that, in the administration of the wool stockpile and the powers that the Australian Wool Corporation has with respect to it, there would be concern to ensure an orderly market right through the spectrum, from the grower to the consumer.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security whether he will table the text of the opinion of the Attorney-General's Department which, because of the definition of income, is now excluding some thousands of people from sickness benefits. Secondly, I ask whether he believes that it was the intention of the original legislation, passed in 1945, that these people should not be granted sickness benefits? As people have been paid sickness benefits for the past 37 years on the same grounds as those on which his Department is now refusing them, will the Minister as soon as possible bring in amending legislation to restore their eligibility?

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —It is not the normal practice to table opinions but I will examine the honourable senator's request and advise him and the Senate concerning that part of his question. As far as the intention of the original legislation is concerned, without having looked at the original second reading speech, it is my understanding that the intention of sickness benefits is to ensure that when somebody loses income or is unable to get income because of the intervention of sickness he or she is given some income support. The most common situation in which sickness benefit is provided is, of course, one in which somebody is in employment and ceases to be able to work and, hence, is without income. It is true that until the opinion was obtained, I think late last year or early this year, in the administration of that section attention was not directed to that part of section 108 which referred to the requirement that there be loss of income due to sickness. I am paraphrasing because I do not have the section in front of me.

answer.para: I previously advised the Senate, and I think Senator Grimes in correspondence, that I am having that matter very carefully examined to see whether a change of policy ought to be brought about and the legislation amended. In the meantime, as again I think I pointed out to the Senate on an earlier occasion, the instruction which was issued by my Department in June makes the point that when sickness benefit is not payable because the sickness has not resulted in a loss of income there may be an entitlement to special benefit. In other words, it is not a situation in which my Department is not able to assist in cases in which people are without means. So, the position is presently covered. The early advice which I have had from my Department shows that what I would regard as a significant number of cases are affected by the ruling made in June. I have asked my Department for very early advice on the need for a change in the legislation. At this time I have not received that advice, or if advice has come into the office in the last day or so I have not seen it. I will undertake to give the matter very early attention and to advise Senator Grimes and the Senate on whether the Government proposes to introduce changes to the legislation.

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister for Education aware that some uncertainty exists , on the part of those responsible for education in the non-government sector, as to the status of ownership of capital projects funded by government? Will the Minister undertake to examine and clarify the situation?

—I am aware that there is uncertainty. I have had representations on this matter. I imagine that other senators have had representations about it also. The situation is that for some years we have had operating, without the benefit of any standing in law, a policy whereby grants have been made to non-government schools for purposes of acquisition of buildings, et cetera. It has been understood that a Commonwealth interest will remain for some years. We generally have had a write-off period of 20 years. Because of the uncertainty that has been expressed and because of the representations that have been made, the Government has been able to re-examine this matter. It is our intention to codify what has been practice over a number of years, to give legal clarification of the interests of non-government school authorities in grants which they have received. It is the intention of the Government to introduce an amendment to the States Grants (Schools Assistance) Bill, at present before the Parliament, in order to give certainty in this area and to remove the uncertainty which has been the cause of the representations. At the moment, the grants which are made are made through the States. The States act as a conduit for the money. It would be necessary then for the States to acquire extra responsibilities as a result of this codification. I am in the process of consulting State Ministers. The amendment will be in the Bill when it comes to the Senate.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. What action has been taken by the Department of Foreign Affairs in the interests of Father Brian Gore, currently held in detention in the Philippines? Is the Minister aware that seven Filipino Christians have been similarly held in detention in Davao City since being arrested on the night of 16 January 1982, amongst them being Leonor Sevilla, who is well known among Victorian Christians for her work among the poor in the Philippines? Will the Minister take up with the Filipino authorities in Australia the case of Miss Sevilla and the six others in order to seek either their early trial or their discharge from prison?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — With regard to Father Brian Gore, the Australian Embassy in Manila has been advised that warrants of arrest have been served on Father Gore. The local Press reports that he was arrested with six other people on 18 October on charges relating to the possession of explosives and of inciting to rebellion. The Embassy has been in contact with the authorities in Manila and is awaiting a full report from an Embassy official who went to obtain first hand information. The Embassy has kept up with developments from the outset. An officer of the Embassy has travelled twice to see Father Gore and to offer consular assistance. The Department of Foreign Affairs has been reporting directly to Father Gore's parents since the case began. As far as the other persons referred to by Senator Primmer are concerned, I will need to seek further information. I have noted that he has requested that the Minister deal with the Philippine authorities in Australia to see what can be done to assist. If there is any further information on those people, I will ensure that early advice is given.

question.block.title: DISCLOSURE OF PERSONAL INCOME TAX DETAILS

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Why are the details of a person's tax not disclosed to the Treasurer by the Commissioner of Taxation, although the Commissioner can disclose such details to the Minister for Social Security?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — There are secrecy provisions within the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Commissioner has always been very careful with personal details that may be given. It has always been the practice that the Treasurer of the day is not provided with personal details of income tax matters. There are arrangements under other Commonwealth Acts whereby information may be exchanged, usually for the functions of other government departments, such as the Department of Social Security, and for the protection of the revenue. But I am not aware that, in those instances, the Minister for Social Security is necessarily given the information.
—It is given to my Department, not to me.

— It is given to the Department of Social Security and not to the Minister. It is within the prescription of the Act that these matters of confidentiality have always been observed. It is intolerable to imagine that Ministers would decide on eligibility for social security benefits under the administration of the Act. Where information such as personal tax records is exchanged, it is in the interests of proper administration, but not necessarily through the political process.

question.block.title: SECURITY OF BASS STRAIT OIL RIGS

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Defence aware that the security arrangements that protect Bass Strait oil drilling are being impaired owing to the inability of assigned patrol boats to operate in heavy weather conditions? What action does the Government intend to take to rectify this matter?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —If Senator Messner will allow me to do so, I will answer this question, because the general security of the platforms in Bass Strait comes under my supervision. The whole question of strengthening the security of Bass Strait in a wide number of ways is currently under notice by the Government. Legislation will be coming forward to provide for areas of avoidance. The legislation will come before the Senate. It will prevent vessels of over 200 tonnes from coming within an area of avoidance of the rigs. Already, there is a total prohibition area around the rigs. A number of surveillance methods-such as radar and other methods which are necessarily confidential-are being installed. These will strengthen the situation. Aerial and naval patrols continue. I hope that, when the legislation comes before the Senate, I will be able to give a comprehensive answer to Senator Robert Ray rather than just a response to one particular incident. The whole aim is to have the strongest possible prohibition and surveillance in the area.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence, unless the Leader of the Government in the Senate would like to answer it. Will the Minister confirm a report in the Canberra Times yesterday that additional B52 flights over northern Australia will be announced in Port Hedland today? Will the Minister explain the Government's policy of announcing changes in defence policy outside the Parliament in the first instance? Will the Minister detail any differences between the weaponry aboard B52s which are used for training flights and those which are used for operational flights?

—I am not particularly aware of any statement which the Minister might be making anywhere at the moment in regard to B52 flights or otherwise. However, I do have some information which I believe Senator Robertson was seeking on an earlier occasion in connection with B52 flights. I would need to refer the earlier part of his question to the Minister and obtain a reply for him. I undertake to do that before the end of Question Time. With regard to the commencement date that Senator Robertson was seeking for the expanded flights of B52s in the not too distant future, I understand that this has not yet been finally determined but as soon as the information is available I will certainly make it available to Senator Robertson.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. It is rather more by way of giving information. I would ask that the Minister take note of the fact that the statement will be made in Port Hedland today and will be made not by an Australian Minister but by a foreign national; that is, someone from the United States.

—Is the Minister for National Development and Energy aware of a claim by the South Australian Chamber of Commerce that in the last six months the value of new investment projects in South Australia rose by $550m? Does the Minister recognise the link between this encouraging figure and the forward looking Tonkin Liberal Government, particularly in facilitating the construction of the Cooper Basin liquids pipeline and the fractionation plant at Stony Point? Will the Minister ensure Commonwealth support of the Tonkin Government in assisting the Asahi and CRA organisations in their feasibility studies for the construction of a petrochemical plant as a logical extension to the major hydrocarbon industry being established in South Australia?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —I have seen that report which, of course, Senator McLaren has not seen because he could not have made his response yesterday had he done so. I am happy to say, and I am quite sure he is glad to hear, that my advice is that there has been that magnitude of new investment in South Australia in the last six months. One would hope that all South Australians would be happy about that. The fact is, as I have said, that the Tonkin Liberal Government has made enormous strides in attracting industry to South Australia. It is true that the liquids pipeline, which has been completed ahead of time, is a quite significant project. I repeat that it will carry up to 40,000 barrels of liquids a day without pressure and 80,000 barrels a day under pressure. To give the Senate an idea of the magnitude of that project, 80,000 barrels a day would be one-fifth of the Bass Strait production. That will be an enormous contribution to safeguarding Australia's petroleum security. One should be eager to encourage that.

answer.para: It is true that at Stony Point, which I visited, a considerable amount of construction is going on to separate the liquids and the gases and there is in contemplation what is to be done in the longer term with the products. There have been discussions over the years about the construction of petrochemical plants. That has been delayed somewhat because of the world recession and because a lot of stripping instead of flaring of gases is now going on in the Middle East, so there is some competition. But as the world moves out of the recession there is every reason to believe that it would be competent to have petrochemical industries within South Australia. That is particularly the case because the one thing in South Australia that we normally decry-salt-is a very valuable asset, along with ethane, in a petrochemical works. I know that the Premier, Mr Tonkin, has been very active in that regard. The Premier yesterday made signals to Queensland suggesting that the pipeline from the Jackson field, which is under development, might link with the Moomba field to go to South Australia. It would be a cheaper construction and would increase the quantity of fluids carried. It is exciting that the Jackson field should be showing commercial tendencies. It is interesting to see the discussions in the various States as to the route that these fluids will take.

I stress that on top of that is the story of Roxby Downs, of Honeymoon and of the new discoveries of coal which look commercial. Week by week there are more announcements that, under the drive and energy of the Tonkin Government, new industries are coming to South Australia which will, given the support of the Tonkin Government, mature in the immediate years ahead, giving more employment and more incentive to the people of South Australia.

talk.start.para: —I direct my question to the Minister for National Development and Energy. The Minister, in a joint Press release with the Minister for Foreign Affairs on 22 September last, announced that a series of South Pacific marine geoscientific investigations had been successfully completed. The Minister said the program had been designed to obtain geophysical, geological and geochemical data and ocean bottom samples. I ask: In any of the studies to be carried out by scientists over the next 18 months is it intended to test for radioactive material which it is claimed pollutes the South Pacific in the region of the Muroroa Atoll? If there are no such plans, will the Minister consider asking the scientists to test the marine and other material for nuclear pollutants so that the claims can be proved or disproved?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —Of course I am well aware of the Press statement. The geoscientific studies are of considerable interest. In conjunction with the countries of the area Australia has an interest to ensure a full understanding and full environmental protection. I share with all honourable senators, including Senator McIntosh, the desire that there should be no pollution, one way or another, including any radioactive pollution. The Senate will know that this Government has protested about testing at Muroroa Atoll. As to atmospheric pollution, the evidence given from time to time has shown no significant increase in atmospheric pollution. But I am not fully aware whether the geoscientific expedition has tested for radioactivity or whether it has done any basic testing in that region. I would be interested, as Senator McIntosh is , to get that information. I will seek to secure it and let him know.

—Mr President, I wish to ask a supplementary question. My question did ask, if there are no such plans, whether the Minister will consider asking the scientists to test the marine and other material for nuclear pollutants. Samples have been taken and those samples should indicate whether they have been contaminated.

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —My intention was to indicate that I would find out what has been happening, whether there has been any testing and whether it is feasible--
—According to your statement, you have samples.
—Yes, we have samples. I will see whether it is possible to test those samples for radioactivity and I will give an answer to Senator McIntosh in due course.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. A veteran's pension, when granted, is backdated to cover the 10 to 12 weeks processing time but the health card is not backdated, so individuals have to maintain health insurance while awaiting notification of the granting of their pension. Can consideration be given to the granting of a rebate equal to the cost of basic medical insurance to cover the additional costs incurred during the processing period?

—Senator Watson has raised a very interesting problem that does occur from time to time in relation to the difficulties that he outlined in his question. The Government does give consideration to this matter from time to time. It would naturally have to be considered in the light of new policy discussions and, therefore, would be a Budget matter. I am unable to comment upon that at this stage. I can say to Senator Watson that it is a matter which in a general way receives very considerable concern and attention from the Department and the Repatriation Commission. It is one that we will bear in mind.

—I ask a question of the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer to a report published in the Canberra Times today, 21 October. Does the Government accept the implications of decisions taken in this year's Budget for the 1983-84 Budget? In particular, does the Government accept that the effects of decisions taken last July mean that a $5 billion deficit is likely by 30 June 1984 of which at least $3 billion will be a domestic deficit? How does the Government intend to fund deficits of this size? Would inflation indexed securities be one option which the Government would consider? Does the Minister agree that there is a considerable difference between a planned deficit, which is designed to stimulate demand and production, and an accidental deficit which will come about because Australia is plunging into a depression?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: — My attention was drawn to the report published in the Canberra Times which suggested that some advice had been given with regard to the outcome of the 1983-84 Budget and that there would be a deficit figure of about $5 billion. My Department advises me that it is not aware of the source of that report, nor has that figure been mentioned to me at any time with regard to next year's Budget. With the discussion that we are having on this year's Budget I believe it would be assumed by everyone that to project figures with accuracy at the 1983-84 Budget level at this time would be fraught with many assumptions that may or may not be accurate when the time comes. When reports of that kind which come from an anonymous source are printed they make many assumptions and predict something for which there is no basis.

answer.para: As far as the other part of Senator Siddons's question is concerned, accidental deficits, deficits that have been deliberate and so on, all need funding. We will take into consideration whether inflation indexed securities or any other form of financing is the best way in which to fund a deficit at the time the 1983-84 Budget is cast. I will refer the question of Senator Siddons to the Treasurer to see whether he has any other comment to make. As far as I am aware, the figure that was produced in the report today has no basis, certainly from my Department.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport. I refer to the extremely successful sea passenger service provided by the Empress of Australia across Bass Strait carrying some 112,000 passengers a year. I also refer to the report of a committee of this Senate which indicated that replacement capacity should allow for 140,000 passengers a year in the 1980s and 1990s. I ask: Will the Government accept as a principal criterion for its decision on the replacement of the Empress of Australia the report of the Senate Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania and the desire of both the State Government and the Opposition that the viability of Tasmania's four-port system be sustained by the continued use of Devonport as the port of embarkation and disembarkation for sea passenger services across Bass Strait, should one replacement vessel be chosen? In the event that two replacement vessels are chosen, will the Government ensure that Devonport and Burnie, as the principal north-west ports of Tasmania, obtain those replacement services?

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday Senator Archer asked a very significant question in relation to the future of the Bass Strait service and the replacement of the Empress of Australia. At that time I pointed out that the Government was at a fairly early stage in assessing the propositions coming from five persons or companies which had interests in this proposal. Those matters are receiving attention at this stage but further discussions will need to be arranged and undertaken between the Victorian and Tasmanian governments in relation to the overall future arrangement.

answer.para: In relation to the particular matters which Senator Tate drew to our attention- the four-port system and matters of that kind-they seem to me to be elements which may be inherent in any propositions which are currently under discussion by the Government. Consequently, I believe the best line of action to take at this time would be to refer to the Minister Senator Tate's concerns in this area so that they might be used to reinforce any decisions that might be taken or discarded according to what is deemed by the Government to be the best course to follow at the moment. I understand the matter is still in a state of flux. It is possible that other operators will seek to take part in this new service if and when it becomes available. Senator Tate's valuable suggestions will be drawn to the attention of the Minister.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister for Veterans' Affairs. I thank him for the answer he gave me yesterday to the question I asked him on Tuesday about surveying. My question today follows on from that. What survey work is done by the Department of Transport and Construction and the Department of Aviation? How is that work assigned? Do the departments do their own assignments? In the light of the decision of the Committee of Review of Commonwealth Functions, are those departments supposed to allocate 40 per cent of their tasks to the private sector? Finally, is there any truth in the allegation that those two departments have outflanked the RCF decision by expanding their in-house survey capacity to do all their own work?

—The matter to which Senator MacGibbon addresses us is one of some detailed administration within the Department of Transport and Contruction and the Department of Aviation. I will need to refer it to the Minister to obtain a detailed reply for him, and I undertake to do that.

—I ask the Minister for Social Security: Has his Department implemented any new funding initiatives for voluntary welfare groups which have been overwhelmed in directly assisting very needy individuals and families, particularly over the last 12 months? Is the Minister aware that preliminary findings of a joint national research project undertaken by the Australian Council of Social Service and the Social Welfare Research Centre confirm that Government support to voluntary welfare groups has generally declined? How can the Government justify acceptance of this situation when demand on these most effective groups has not declined but has increased as dramatically as it did in the depression of the 1930s?

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —The responsibility of the Commonwealth for the broad income maintenance programs which are administered largely through my Department but also significantly through the Department of Veterans' Affairs is, I think, well understood. Providing what is commonly termed 'emergency relief' for those who require short term assistance is a matter on which there has been considerable debate. It is undoubtedly true that over the last year or two there has been a significant increase in demand for emergency assistance. The Commonwealth has been putting a constant amount of money in for emergency assistance, a relatively small contribution to meet the overall demand. This is in the context of emergency relief traditionally having been in the hands of State governments and voluntary agencies. Indeed, the question asked by Senator Elstob relates primarily to the burdens borne by voluntary agencies.

answer.para: Pursuant to the Commonwealth's responsibility, a series of adjustments to income maintenance programs has been made. There are to be further changes in the new year which ought to do something to reduce the burden which is carried by the voluntary agencies; changes such as the increase in supplementary assistance, the variations to the limits on income which can be earned in part time work without affecting the benefit, the extension of a new form of pharmaceutical benefit to those pensioners and beneficiaries who do not have the pensioner health card, the basic indexation of pensions and benefits and the making of indexation level adjustments to non-indexed benefits. These are all steps which contribute to a solution to the problems raised by the honourable senator. But I would accept that, notwithstanding those changes, there will be, and is, a continuing demand for emergency relief. It would be my hope that the sorts of adjustments to which I have referred would help to keep those demands within manageable limits.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Resources. What is the current position in closer economic relations negotiations with New Zealand, particularly including objections raised by Tasmanian horticultural growers as recently expressed by the Australian Agricultural Council? Specifically, has any progress been made in removing the current New Zealand import licensing and export incentive schemes which so strongly advantage the New Zealand producers supplying Australia but hamper Australian producers supplying New Zealand?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —Following release of the draft exposure paper on closer economic relations-the so-called CER-between Australia and New Zealand on 4 June of this year, consultations have been held with interested industry organisations, State governments and other appropriate organisations such as the Australian Agricultural Council. I have been advised that all the issues raised by the Tasmanian horticultural industry and the Australian Agricultural Council have been considered by the Government as part of its broad review of the proposal following the consultation period. In the light of that review, further negotiations are now taking place with New Zealand. Senator Archer can be assured that the interests of Tasmania and the people of Australia will be closely guarded and protected.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Prime Minister. Did the Prime Minister in 1979 wind up the family trust which he had previously set up to avoid taxation? Did he then allot 40,360 shares in Fraser Properties Pty Ltd to each of his four children as a return lodged with the Victorian Corporate Affairs Office on 26 December 1979 shows? Was the share issue contrived to avoid tax through income fragmentation; that is, did he by the issue of those shares achieve the same result as had previously been achieved by the tax avoiding family trust? If that was not the reason, why were the shares issued? Was the effect of issuing the shares the continued avoidance of tax through the fragmentation of income?

answer.speaker: Carrick Sen The Hon Sir J.L.

talk.start.para: —Senator Walsh would know that by the very nature of his question he is seeking information to which I could not personally respond. He would know that that question by its very nature is one that should be put on notice and I invite him to do so.

—I direct a question to the Minister representing the Minister for Defence. Many statements emanating from the United States of America indicate that the future of the FA18 fighter aircraft appears to be somewhat controversial with one report indicating that there has been a substantial cut in the price of the aircraft and that there have been recommendations that, for various reasons, the FA18 project should be scrapped. Having in mind that Australia has recently negotiated a large contract for these multi-purpose fighter aircraft, I ask: Have these recent reports any implications for the price and supply of the FA18s to Australia?

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —It is true to say that the United States Navy Secretary Lehman has been reported as saying that he would curtail the FA18 production program unless the manufacturer, McDonnell Douglas, reduced the price of the aircraft. The report was made in the context of the pressures generated by the formulation of the next United States defence budget which is by no means at all firm. There is some way to go before Congress and the Government get to a final stage of negotiation on that. This Government will be maintaining a very close contact with the United States Government in this situation.

answer.para: Australia would benefit from any price reduction achieved. We would support Secretary Lehman's efforts to obtain that. There would be some consequences for Australia's FA18 acquisition and the Australian industry program if the United States program were curtailed. Similar consequences would arise for other nations that are purchasing the FA18. They include Canada and Spain. I think the point to be made is that, except for that relationship, the implications would be expected to be favourable as any price reduction would certainly favour this Government.

talk.start.para: —Is the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services aware that Australian Federal Police officers at Sydney Airport are holding travellers passing through the airport with the demand that they pay outstanding State parking fines or face arrest, as reported in the Sydney Sun of 13 October? Is it normal practice for the Federal Police to carry out such relatively minor activities at international airports, particularly when one has regard to the obvious shortage of officers which was referred to by the Assistant Commissioner recently in respect of Medibank frauds and other frauds? Do police have access to computer records concerning travellers on a regular basis? What is the relationship between the Federal and State police forces in cases such as this?
—I am sure Senator Gietzelt would agree that the nature of the question which he has put forward makes it one that should appropriately go on notice, and I ask him to place it on notice.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Social Security. I realise that the Minister has had the report on homeless youth tabled by the Senate Standing Committee on Social Welfare for only two months. However, at this early stage, can the Minister tell the Senate of the progress of the report within his Department?

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —The report on homeless youth was brought down in a very timely fashion in the sense that it coincided with a report on the evaluation of the youth services scheme. As a result, the Government has two very useful bits of material on which to examine the appropriate policies that should be developed for homeless youth. I indicated earlier that the Committee was good enough to give me in an informal way some of its preliminary views during last year. I hope that members of the Committee will see at least some of their thinking reflected in the decisions which were announced in the Budget and in the funding decisions under the Homeless Persons Assistance Act which were announced within the last fortnight. As far as the funding decisions are concerned, there has been, for example, the funding of a number of smaller scale, longer term accommodation arrangements which are, I think, very much along the lines of the support services which are favoured by the Committee.

answer.para: A detailed work program for the assessment of the Senate Committee's report has been laid down, including a detailed timetable. I am anxious to meet the six- month commitment and also the deadline for the production of next year's Budget. The decisions made this year with respect to homeless youth were made by the Government on the basis that it was undertaking detailed consideration of policy in this area. I want the assessment of the Committee's report and the evaluation of the youth services scheme to be completed in the early part of the next calendar year. That might seem a lengthy time but the assessment involves consultation with States and agencies involved in the field. I certainly think that the Senate Committee's report and the response to it will represent a useful step in trying to cope with a social problem which disturbs many honourable senators and certainly many Australians.

talk.start.para: —I address my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to a question that I asked over a week ago and in which I asked the Minister on what date the Torres Strait treaty would be ratified. As yet I have not had an answer. I now ask the Minister whether she can inform me what negotiations have taken place in relation to this treaty. Who was at the negotiations and when did they take place? What timetable has been set down, if no date is available at this stage?

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —The earlier question was referred to the Minister and I am not aware of any information having come forward from him. I will have the matter checked and will put the further question before him for attention.

—I draw the attention of the Minister for Social Security to an article, appearing in the first edition of a publication entitled Australian Society, which relates to the Federal Government's new directions in child care. In particular, I draw attention to the claim made by the community child care movement that the recent Budget allocation of $200,000 for a pilot project which gives low income families a subsidy to use a commercial child care centre is 'a first step towards directing government money from the public to the private sector'. Is the Minister aware that in North America, where many public centres have been forced to close as a result of subsidies being shifted from public to private care, commercial child care chains, which have been dubbed 'Kentucky Fried child care', have flourished? In light of this overseas experience and the strong opposition to commercial child care from a broad range of groups throughout Australia, I ask the Minister: Will he assure the Senate that the pilot project does not signify a fundamental shift in directing government moneys from public to private care and that the Government will do all possible to increase its funding of public centres so as to provide good quality care for everyone who needs it?

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —I am familiar with the article referred to in the question. The magazine mentioned is a new one and I believe it was the first edition. I was not surprised to find in it an article on the subject of child care. I can assure the Senate that the $200,000 pilot project announcement which was contained in the Budget does not represent a fundamental shift in the approach which the Government has adopted in this area. I was pleased to be able to announce the Government's decision to proceed with that initiative in the context of a very considerable increase in funding for non-commercial centres. The increase in child care funding this year will enable an expansion of activity in that new projects will be able to be approved but, just as importantly, there can be an upgrading of subsidies, in particular those available to people on low incomes who might otherwise be excluded from Commonwealth-funded centres. So the $200,000 proposal was produced in a context of significant additional assistance being given to the non-commercial sector.

answer.para: I have heard some reports about commercial child care chains in the United States. I comment that there are significant differences between the United States and Australia in terms of the societies of the two countries. There are certainly significant differences in the approach to enterprise and various other things. In any event, I think there is a well-established public child care chain in Australia. The State governments are involved in the supervision of standards. There is a very active lobby which watches the interests of consumers in this area. I really think that there is no prospect of the sorts of difficulties raised by Senator Missen occurring in Australia.

By running this pilot project, the Government is seeking to establish whether it can effect a significant lift in the standard of care available to some children who at the moment might not have access to any form of supervised care- certainly not to a Commonwealth-funded centre-but who might have geographic proximity to a commercial centre and not be able to afford to go there. We are anxious to have a pilot which will be conducted in conjunction with State authorities and which will be watched by the voluntary sector both formally and informally. I believe that through this pilot we can contribute to our knowledge of how we can best ensure the provision of reasonable standards of care for all Australian children. It remains true that a very tiny minority of Australian children are cared for in formal child care facilities. We are anxious to ensure that in that other minority of cases-in which children are cared for in unsupervised conditions away from their families-the best available option should be open to them, whatever their economic circumstances.

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations. Is it a fact that a memo was issued to all Commonwealth Employment Service managers instructing them not to insert employer-paid job advertisements in the Press for any vacancies which are normally handled by the private employment agencies? Does the Minister not agree that this action will deprive the CES of many vacancies it would otherwise have got and, therefore, reduce its effectiveness as a job placement agency?

—I am trying to see whether I have any advice on the particular point raised by the honourable senator. I do not have any personal knowledge of the matter which he has raised. I do, however, have a note from the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations which refers to some Press reports which may be relevant. It says that there has been an incorrect attribution of the loss of certain Commonwealth Employment Service functions to the private agency lobby. Following the implementation of the recommendations of the Review of Commonwealth Functions professional employment offices were absorbed into the CES network, employer-paid advertising was restricted and Templine was abolished . These decisions were made independently of the private agency lobby and were made in line with the Government's general aim at the time to devolve functions to private enterprise where appropriate. The CES continues to deliver a service to all job seekers and employers who wish to use the CES services. I will examine the written record of the question asked by Senator Foreman to see whether it needs a more detailed and specific reply. If it does, I will let him have that as soon as possible.

—My question is directed to the very popular Minister for Veterans ' Affairs, who represents the Minister for Defence Support. I refer to reports that the new Royal Australian Navy fleet replenishment ship to be named-Mr Frank Cranston describes it as 'most inappropriately' named-HMAS Success is currently two years behind its delivery date and that both her delivery date and final cost are now totally unpredictable. I ask: Are the reports true that, if an order were now placed in a French or South Korean shipyard for a second ship of this class, the second ship could be obtained well before the completion of HMAS Success? Can the Minister offer the Senate any explanation for the appalling delays in the construction and delivery of this vessel?

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —I do have some information on this matter. The question of the date of completion of HMAS Success is very important. It is true that the program is well behind schedule. It is the subject of continuing negotiations between the Royal Australian Navy and the Department of Defence Support and the builder. I cannot at this stage give any indication of the outcome of those negotiations. They are well in progress at present. It is true that the problems which have occurred at the builder's yard-the builder is Vickers Cockatoo Dockyard Pty Ltd-relate to the attracting and retaining of suitable skilled workers after a long gap in shipbuilding at that dockyard. Also, one very significant contribution to the delay has been industrial disputation because that builder has been a target for the unions' shorter working hours campaign. Consequently, that has led to a very significant addition to the time taken to build this vessel. The difference between the production documentation received from the French and the documentation available at the time of tendering, as well as some deficiencies in the production documentation which have since been rectified or are being rectified with the ready co-operation of the French source, are matters that have contributed to the delay also.

answer.para: In relation to that part of Senator Lewis's question as to whether the French and/or the South Koreans could build a ship in less time than it will take to build HMAS Success, it has to be acknowledged that Australia's policy in relation to this kind of development is for work to be undertaken in Australia. Consequently, the question of vessels being built in other countries does not arise. That, of course, is distinct from the matter relating to which design might be utilised. Of course, that brings us back to the delays which have been attendant upon the determination of the exact specifications on the French design. For those reasons there is very considerable concern on this matter. The Government is proceeding with it in all haste in order to bring about a speedy resolution of the problems which the builder is currently experiencing.

talk.start.para: —I ask that the document quoted from by the Minister be tabled.

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —Yesterday I had a question without notice from Senator Evans, the shadow Attorney-General, relating to the production of documents before the Public Accounts Committee. Yesterday Senator Evans also gave notice of his intention to move a motion on the same subject. Senator Evans has seen the document I have which represents a response to his question asked yesterday, together with some comment on his notice of motion. With his agreement, I propose to respond to the question by seeking leave of the Senate to have incorporated in Hansard a statement which relates also to the motion of which he gave notice. I think there is now a fair amount of common ground between us on the issue of the Joint Committee of Public Accounts. There is an express statutory provision in the Public Accounts Committee Act which gives witnesses the same privileges as they have before a court. Section 19 of the Act is referred to in the statement which I seek to have incorporated in Hansard. That is one matter.

answer.para: It will also be common ground between us that different issues or different rules may apply in general committee situations and they may be the subject of more extensive debate at some other time in this place. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard a statement in response to the question asked yesterday by Senator Evans.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
MOTION CONCERNING THE CLAIM BY THE CROWN SOLICITOR FOR LEGAL PROFESSIONAL PRIVILEGE BEFORE THE PUBLIC ACCOUNTS COMMITTEE
Statement by the Minister representingtheActing Attorney-General,Senator F. M. Chaney
21 October 1982

This motion and the question asked by Senator Evans yesterday is concerned with what is essentially a question of law. It is not a simple question of law but, as I see it, a question of law of some complexity. Some may wonder, and I am amongst them, whether the Senate is really the place in which to seek to debate a complex issue of law of this character. But since, the motion is before us and the motion is for debate, we really have no alternative but to debate it.
At the outset let us be quite clear what the motion is about and what it is not about.

The motion is not about whether legal professional privilege has been waived in this case or whether it should have been waived by the Government in this case or whether it should now be waived. Indeed, the Government has now waived privilege in this case and the Public Accounts Committee has been so advised. What the debate is about is whether there was any foundation for the claim of legal professional privilege that was made by the Crown Solicitor before the Public Accounts Committee on 19 October.

First, let us look at what are the relevant facts. By summons dated 6 October 1982 addressed to Mr B. J. O'Donovan Commonwealth Crown Solicitor, the Chairman of the Public Accounts Committee acting under section 13 of the Public Accounts Committee Act 1951 summoned the Commonwealth Crown Solicitor to appear before the Joint Committee of Public Accounts on 19 October 1982 at 10.30 a.m. Honourable Senators will observe that Mr O'Donovan was summoned, not in his personal capacity, but in his official capacity as Commonwealth Crown Solicitor .

That summons was received in the Crown Solicitor's Office on 11 October 1982. During the week commencing 11 October 1982, the Crown Solicitor was in touch with staff of the Public Accounts Committee and acknowledged receipt of the summons. In course of discussion with officers of the Public Accounts Committee it emerged that Mr O'Donovan's attendance was required at 9.00 a.m. on 19 October and not at 10.30 a.m. as the summons indicated. Mr O'Donovan attended on the Committee at 9.00 a.m. on 19 October.

The summons addressed to the Crown Solicitor required not only his attendance but also that he should produce to the Committee documents held by him concerning the doctors and organisations listed at attachment ''A'' to the summons. Attachment ''A'' set out the names of some 41 doctors and organisations all of them in the State of Victoria.

There can be no doubt but that the Crown Solicitor attended before the Public Accounts Committee on 19 October as a witness before that Committee. He was there under compulsion of law. Sections 13 and 14 of the Public Accounts Commitee Act make that clear beyond doubt.
Section 19 of the Public Accounts Committee Act provides as follows:
''(1) a person summoned to appear or appearing before the Committee as a witness shall have the same protection and privilege as a witness in proceedings in the High Court.

(2) A person shall not use, cause, inflict or procure any violence, punishment , damage, loss or disadvantage on or to a person for or on account of his having appeared as a witness before the Committee, or for or on account of any evidence lawfully given by him before the Committee.''

The effect of section 19 of the Public Accounts Committee Act is to confer upon a witness appearing before the Committee the same protection and privileges as a witness would have in proceedings in the High Court. The privileges of a witness before the High Court are not in any respect now relevant different from the privileges of a witness before any other court in Australia.

One of the privileges enjoyed in proceedings in the High Court and other courts in Australia is legal professional privilege. The rule with respect to legal professional privilege is stated succinctly in the second Australian edition of ''Cross on Evidence'' at paragraph 11.25 as follows:

''Communications passing between a client and his legal adviser together, in some cases, with communications passing between those persons and third parties may not be given in evidence without the consent of the client if they were made either-
(1) with reference to litigation that was actually taking place or was in contemplation of the client; or
(2) if they were made to enable the client to obtain or the adviser to give, legal advice.''

Unlike most other Honourable Senators, I have had the opportunity of looking at the files that were the subject of the claim for legal professional privilege. These files contain communications from the Victorian Regional Office of the Department of Health to the Victorian Regional Office of the Crown Solicitor. The communications from the Department of Health request advice. A typical communication has in it a paragraph to this effect-''We would be grateful if you would furnish the Department with your legal opinion as to whether there is sufficient evidence to be able to pursue the matter''. Accompanying that letter, there was, of course, a brief of evidence. In most cases, the brief of evidence is not in the possession of the Crown Solicitor or his regional office. It seems to me to be clear beyond doubt that that letter constitutes a communication made to enable the client to obtain, or the adviser to give, legal advice within the rule that I have quoted above. It is within that rule if the communication is a communication passing between a client and his legal adviser.

There is one minor exception. One of the files contains some material involving communications with a third party. It is my view, and the Crown Solicitor agrees, that legal professional privilege would not attach to those particular documents, that is, part of one file.

The Crown Solicitor claims, and I agree with him, that the client in those cases is the Commonwealth, the body politic. Is then the Crown Solicitor a legal adviser to the Commonwealth for the purposes of the rule with respect to legal professional privilege? In my view he clearly is.
Section 55E of the Judiciary Act, in so far as it is here relevant, provides as follows-
''The Crown Solicitor may, in his official capacity, act as Solicitor for-
(a) the Crown in right of the Commonwealth;
(b) the Commonwealth;
(d) a Minister;
(f) an officer of, or a person employed by-
(i) the Commonwealth; or
(ii) a body established by an Act or a law of a Territory;
(g) a person holding office under an Act or a law of a Territory;

and is for the purpose of so acting, entitled to practise as a solicitor in any Court and entitled to all the rights and privileges of a solicitor in each State or Territory whether or not he is, apart from this section, entitled to practise as a solicitor in any State or Territory.''

Communications passing between the Commonwealth represented by any of its Departments and the Crown Solicitor of the Commonwealth with reference to litigation, whether civil or criminal that is actually taking place or was in the contemplation of the client, or such communications, if they were made to enable the Commonwealth to obtain or the Crown Solicitor to give legal advice, attract legal professional privilege and may not be given in evidence without the consent of the client.

As recently as June of this year, Mr Justice Ellicott in the case of the Commonwealth of Australia against Sidney Frost and Others upheld a claim of legal professional privilege made in a matter before a Board of Accident Inquiry established under the Air Navigation Regulations. The documents to which the privilege was held to apply were documents containing proofs of evidence taken by an officer of the Crown Solicitor's office from a witness employed in the Department of Transport, being proofs of evidence taken for the purpose of the Inquiry. That case would seem to be clear authority for the view that the fact that the legal adviser is the Crown Solicitor and the client is the Commonwealth is not a basis upon which it can be said that legal professional privilege cannot be claimed. In this respect, the present case as it seems to me, is stronger than the case decided by Mr Justice Ellicott in that for the purpose of ascertaining the privilege of witnesses the Public Accounts Committee Act itself equates the Public Accounts Committee to a Court.

For these reasons, it seems clear that there was a foundation and a proper foundation for the claim of legal professional privilege made by the Crown Solicitor before the Public Accounts Committee. The privilege is a privilege of the client, that is to say, the Commonwealth. The privilege may, of course, be waived by the Commonwealth and as previously stated, it has been waived in this case. But, as I have said whether it is waived or whether it is not waived is irrelevant to the question whether there was a proper foundation for the claim being made.

There is one further matter on which I would wish to speak briefly. I understand that a view expressed by the Crown Solicitor to the Public Accounts Committee to the effect that documents on files in the Department of Health that had come into the possession of officers of the Department of Health in the performance of his duties or functions under the Health Insurance Act 1973 cannot be compelled to be produced before the Public Accounts Committee. I would myself agree with the view expressed by the Crown Solicitor.
Sub-section (2) of section 130 of the Health Insurance Act is as follows:
''(2) A person who is, or has been, an officer shall not, except for the purposes of this Act, be required-
(a) to produce in court any document that has come into his possession or under his control in the performance of his duties or functions under this Act; or
(b) to divulge or communicate to a court any matter or thing that has come under his notice in the performance of any such duties or functions.''

Bearing in mind that witnesses before the Public Accounts Committee have the same privileges as witnesses before the High Court, it seems clear that sub- section (2) of section 130 protects an officer of the Commonwealth from being compelled to produce documents that have come into his possession or under his control in the performance of his duties or functions under the Health Insurance Act to the Public Accounts Committee.

Language similar to that used in sub-section 130 (2) of the Health Insurance Act is also used in sub-section (3) of section 16 of the Income Tax Assessment Act. That provision was the subject of consideration by Dixon CJ in Canadian Pacific Tobacco Co. Ltd. v. Stapleton 86 CLR 1 at page 7. There His Honour said this-

''Sub-section (3) provides that an officer shall not be required to produce in Court (certain documents) or to divulge or communicate to any court any matter or thing coming under his notice in the performance of his duty as an officer except when it is necessary to do so for the purpose of carrying into effect the provisions of this Act or of any previous law.''

''In spite of the word 'exclusion' in the passage that was read from O' Flaherty v. McBride, I think that this provision gives only a protection to the officer against compulsion and does not make inadmissible evidence which the officer is prepared to give under instructions from his superiors or the Commissioners.''
The judgment of Dixon CJ in that case was affirmed by a Full Court of 3 judges .

Whilst it is clear that the secrecy provisions in section 130 of the Health Insurance Act do not prohibit the production to the Public Accounts Committee of papers coming into the possession of an officer in the performance of his duties or functions under the Health Insurance Act, it seems to me to be reasonably clear that the Public Accounts Committee cannot compel the production of those papers any more than a Court could compel their production.

talk.start.para: —I thank the Senate.
—Were you not going to say something about privilege?

—I am grateful to Senator Evans for reminding me that in the instant case the matter is academic because the Crown has in fact waived its privilege in this particular case. That is also dealt with in the statement. The Attorney-General has written to the Public Accounts Committee advising that , in all the circumstances of the case, the Crown does not intend to claim in this case the professional privilege to which it is entitled. That is another reason for dealing with it in the way that I am suggesting this morning.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen G.J.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I am glad to hear from the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) that the particular controversy relating to the production of documents to the Joint Committee of Public Accounts appears to have been resolved satisfactorily. Of course, if that is so, it will make it unnecessary for me to pursue the motion of which I gave notice yesterday. As to the statement which has been incorporated in Hansard by the Minister, which I have so far only had a fleeting opportunity to peruse, I do not want to be taken as acceding to all the matters there asserted. In particular, I do not concede that legal professional privilege was ever properly claimed in relation to the particular documents in dispute in this matter.

speech.para: What I do concede is that, on the technical question of whether legal professional privilege can ever properly be claimed in proceedings before the Public Accounts Committee, the language of section 19 of the Public Accounts Committee Act does seem to put that beyond doubt. However, as Senator Chaney indicated, it remains the case that, for all other Senate committee inquiries and parliamentary committee inquiries generally-that is, where there is no explicit statutory provision of this kind governing the protection of witnesses- in my view legal professional privilege claims are clearly inapplicable. That seems to have been the view of the former Attorney-General, the late Senator Greenwood, and of the then Mr Ellicott, as Solicitor-General, in their paper tabled in the Parliament in 1972. It certainly remains my reading of the present law, although I acknowledge it is an area in which there can be argument. Whether it should be the law that witnesses be able to claim legal professional privilege in parliamentary committee inquiries generally clearly remains a matter for serious debate on another occasion.

interject.speaker: Senator MESSNER

talk.start.para: —Earlier today, Senator Robertson asked me a question which drew our attention to an article that appeared in this morning's Canberra Times claiming certain statements by an American Air Force brigadier. I have since had an opportunity to look at that article. I have determined that it is certainly an article of a speculative kind. It might be said that it really has a particular connotation put upon certain anticipated statements by that officer. But, while drawing attention to certain statements made last weekend by the Minister for Defence in relation to the training of B52 teams over Australia, it does not in any way change the original thrust of that statement. That statement , which the Minister for Defence put down at the Federal Council of the National Party last weekend, is a clear statement of the Government's intention in this regard. For the benefit of the Senate, I seek leave to have the Press statement which followed that announcement incorporated in Hansard.

interject.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
The Minister for Defence, Mr Ian Sinclair, today announced new arrangements ralating to United States B52 navigation training flights over Australia.
Mr Sinclair was speaking at the Federal Conference of the National Country Party in Canberra.

Mr Sinclair said that the Government had agreed to a US request for the frequency of some of these flights to be increased and for permission to be given for B52s to conduct low-level navigation training flights over certain areas of the Northern Territory and Western Australia. At present the aircraft were only operated over northern Queensland.
The purpose of the new arrangements was to give the US greater flexibility in scheduling navigation training flights and to increase the training benefits that the B52 crews get from those flights.

Mr Sinclair said there were two separate arrangements governing the conduct of existing B52 operations in Australia. The first of these, announced by the Minister for Defence on February 3, 1980, provided for pairs of B52 aircraft to travel each fortnight from Guam. In November, 1980, the Minister agreed that the frequency of these operations could be increased to once a week.

The second arrangement was announced by the Prime Minister in Parliament on March 11, 1981. That arrangement provided for periodic deployments to be made through Darwin of B52s and associated KC135 tanker aircraft on sea surveillance missions over the Indian Ocean after conducting navigation training in northern Queensland.

The new arrangements, Mr Sinclair said, would make it possible for some B52 aircraft to carry out navigation training flights over northern Queensland, then land at Darwin and subsequently conduct more low-level training over selected low jet routes in the Northern Territory and Western Australia before returning to Guam.

The actual frequency with which the various B52 operations would be conducted would vary according to such factors as the USAF's operational commitments for the relevant aircraft, on aircraft maintenance requirements and on weather conditions. Altogether a monthly maximum of about 16 B52 flights might be made through Australia for navigation training and sea surveillance purposes although in practice the actual number was likely to be substantially fewer than this. Of these, up to three B52s a month may land at Darwin.
Mr Sinclair noted that, as is the case with all the existing B52 flights conducted through Australian territory, the aircraft will be unarmed and will carry no bombs.
The low jet routes to be used by the B52s in Western Australia and the Northern Territory are as follows:
(a) commences south of Junction Bay, heading south passing to the east and south of Katherine, turns west to pass south of Kununurra, then north-east to terminate south of Daly river Mission;
(b) crosses the coast north of Wyndham, heads south to Mt Bedford and then proceeds west to the coast at King Sound;
(c) commences south of Roper Valley, heads westerly, passing south of Katherine , and crosses the coast at Cape Scott;
(d) crosses the coast at Cape Leveque, heads easterly to Mt Bedford, then turns north, crossing the coast again north of Wyndham.

speech.speaker: Button Sen J.N.

talk.start.para: —by leave-Yesterday, Wednesday , 20 October, an article appeared on the front page of the Adelaide News headed: 'ALP tactics may delay new benefits deal. Threat to pensions and dole rises.' In part, the article stated:

speech.para: Delaying tactics by the A.L.P. are likely to mean a range of new benefits will not be available from November 1 as promised by the Government.
These include an indexation of all pensions, an indexation of the married unemployment benefit, an increase in the dole payments and the 50 per cent rise in family allowances.
Promised tax cuts . . . . will not be affected.
That is the charitable part of the article, which I refer to in the interests of balance.

I raise this matter because I am primarily responsible for stating the Opposition's attitude to legislation which comes into this chamber. Five days after the Budget was presented, I called a Press conference. At the same time, I distributed widely a Press release in which I said that the Opposition would not obstruct or delay the Budget. In the course of a Press conference, I said that the Budget was the Fraser Government's responsibility and that the Opposition will not oppose it. I said:
It is his Budget-
That is, Mr Fraser's-
and he will have to live with the political and economic consequences of it.
Since that time there has been no statement by any Opposition spokesman which casts any doubt on that statement. On a number of occasions, the statement has been reiterated.

With regard to the question of any possible delay of the Budget, I simply point out to the Senate that, on 11 October this year, the Government circulated to honourable senators, and to me and other Opposition spokesmen in particular, a proposed draft legislative program. In that proposed draft legislative program, it was indicated that there were 11 Bills which the Government wanted passed by the end of October. In a letter to Senator Sir John Carrick on 12 October, I indicated that the Opposition would ensure that those Bills were passed by the end of October as requested. Subsequently, of course, there has been another Bill added to that list.

I should point out that in the draft business list circulated by the Government it was not the Government's intention to introduce Appropriation Bills before at least 9 November. The particular objection I take to the article to which I have referred is that not only is it incorrect and in a sense totally misrepresents the position of the Opposition, but also is it chronically bad and incompetent journalism. For example, it is suggested that the social security payments will be delayed. If the journalist who wrote the article in question had bothered to familiarise himself with what happens in the Senate instead of getting his information from the Prime Minister's office, he would have known that the day before he wrote the article the social security legislation was passed by this chamber without opposition. It was passed in two hours-between 3.15 p.m. and 5. 15 p.m.-on Tuesday of this week. The article in question appeared the following day. The article does not allege anything other than that the Opposition was delaying legislation which had already been passed by the Senate. Alternatively, the article is open to the construction that the Government is somehow running out of money. I do not think the Government could be running out of money on the basis of its suggested program for this sitting of the Senate.

talk.start.para: —I would not bet on it.
—We do not know; I am relying on the Government's program.
—You cannot rely on the Government for anything.

—Senator Haines would not rely on the Government for anything. I am afraid I have to, otherwise it would be quite impossible to say anything here . I rely on the Government for some things; for example, on its estimates of its financial situation. Of course, the article does not go into that at all. It suggests very strongly that legislation which relates to pensions and so on is being opposed in the Senate-legislation which had already been passed at the time the article was written.
—Refer it to the Press Council.

—If the proprietor of the newspaper were a member of the Press Council one would certainly do something about it, but that is not the situation . I raise this matter by way of personal explanation because I am primarily responsible for the position stated by the Opposition in this chamber.

proctext.para: Annual Report 1981

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT
