talk.start.para: —For the information of honourable senators, I present the fourth annual report of the Department of the Parliamentary Library for the calendar year 1981. I also have a statement in connection with the report which, with the concurrence of the Senate, I will incorporate in Hansard.

interject.para: The statement read as follows-
For the information of honourable senators, I present the fourth annual report of the Department of the Parliamentary Library for the calendar year 1981.

The report covers a year of record levels of activity for the client services, total measurable demand being up by some 17 1/4% over the previous year. Similarly, in the supporting services, some 9% more books and periodicals were processed than the previous year while demand on the Alert services was up by nearly 50%.

A Client Assessment Survey carried out during the year sought the reactions of users to specific responses received for information and research requests. The overall result indicated a high degree of satisfaction with the work done but indicated that some attention is needed in ensuring the relevance of documents provided in response to questions.

Planning for automation is well underway with the expectation that electronic means of information retrieval and delivery will be routine in the New Parliament House. In the year under review the Statistics Group of the Legislative Research Service in particular greatly enhanced its computer capability and commenced the development of a number of major packages. These include a time-series and econometric analysis package, an election results data base and another consisting of the demographic profiles of Federal electorates.

The Parliament's Bicentenary Publications Project, an initiative of considerable national significance, was begun during the year and is administered and funded through the Department of the Parliamentary Library. It arose out of a lengthy consideration by the Library Committee concerning the appropriate way in which the Parliament might mark the Australian Bicentenary and the opening of the new Parliament House in 1988. The general framework of the project has been determined as follows:
an analytical history of the Australian Parliament since Federation
a narrative history of the people and events connected with the Parliament
a popular book explaining how Parliament works and
a series of smaller and more specialised monographs prepared in conjunction with the major works.

An immense amount of preparatory work undertaken in connection with this Project in 1981 enables me to allude to developments in 1982 and to tell honourable Senators that the author commissioned to write the analytical history is Professor Gordon Reid, Deputy Vice Chancellor of the University of Western Australia. Professor Reid was an officer of the House of Representatives from 1946 to 1958 where he was Serjeant at Arms from 1955 to 1958. The author commissioned for the writing of the narrative history is Mr Gavin Souter, a senior journalist with the Sydney Morning Herald and the author of a number of successful historical works including Company of Heralds, a history of John Fairfax Ltd.

Expressions of interest are currently being sought from authors interested in writing the popular account of how Parliament works. Proposals for the writing of the monographs will be assessed by the Advisory Board which Mr Speaker and I have set up to advise us on all aspects of the Project, and by the Publisher to the Project when he is appointed.

The year 1981 was a busy one for the Parliamentary Library and I am sure that all honourable Senators would wish me to thank the Library Committee for its services and to congratulate staff of the Parliamentary Library on their work and achievements.

debate.title: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

debate.sub1.title: Report on Retail Trading Hours in the Australian Capital Territory

speech.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —On behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory I present a report into retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory, together with extracts from the minutes of proceedings of the Committee and the transcript of evidence.

speech.para: Ordered that the report be printed.

speech.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

The report I have just tabled deals with the subject of retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory. This matter was referred to the Committee for consideration after a proposal to repeal the present Trading Hours Ordinance contained in section 90 of the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act 1981 , was debated in the Senate. During this debate it was agreed that the Government would not proclaim the relevant section of this Act until the Australian Capital Territory Committee had considered comprehensively the question of its implementation and the possible effects of deregulation of trading hours. It was further stated in the debate that the Committee should provide every opportunity for all views to be heard.

The Committee formally accepted its terms of reference on 10 September 1981, commenced its series of public hearings on 2 November 1981 and concluded its deliberations on the inquiry in less then twelve months after its referral. Initial response to the inquiry was overwhelming-in the four weeks immediately after advertising the terms of reference, about 4,000 pro-forma slips from individual shoppers, 200 form letters from small retailers, 60 form letters from individuals, 40 letters from small traders, 67 letters from residents in the Australian Capital Territory, as well as 50 major submissions from retailers, trade unions and interested organisations and individuals were received.

In order to provide an opportunity for interested parties to present their arguments, the Committee held a series of public hearings in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne. It was also decided in the concluding stages of the inquiry to conduct a series of inspections and informal discussions in the Northern Territory where trading hours, apart from liquor trading, are not subject to regulation. In all 68 witnesses, representing 38 organisations and seven persons appearing in a private capacity, gave evidence to the Committee.

The current Trading Hours Ordinance in the Australian Capital Territory provides that the sale of goods in shops is prohibited on a Sunday, a gazetted public holiday, a weekday before 6.00 a.m. and after 6.00 p.m. other than a late shopping day when trading hours are extended to 9.00 p.m. and on a Saturday, that is not a public holiday, before 6.00 a.m. and after 12.00 noon. The schedule to the Ordinance specifies goods and classes of goods which are exempt from the provisions of the Ordinance.

The Trading Hours Ordinance has been subject to a number of public inquiries and reviews and the difficulties associated with the enforcement of the Ordinance have been repeatedly highlighted at public inquiries. Due to problems associated with the lack of enforcement of the present legislation, the situation in relation to trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory is at present not satisfactory and some direct action is required to correct the anomalies in the present system.

In accordance with its terms of reference, the Committee has examined 'the manner in which deregulaton of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory . . . might be implemented having regard to the effect on retailers, employees and consumers', after having examined how trading hours operate in other States, and after having taken into account the special conditions applying in the Australian Capital Territory.

In looking at the effect of regulation on retailers, it is recognised that certain constraints apply which make it difficult for total deregulation to operate. Retailers have entered the market on the basis that the hours of trading as set out in the 1962 Ordinance will continue to apply. Small traders are more vulnerable to sudden changes in legislation affecting their hours of operation than are larger retailers. Therefore, small traders would be greatly disadvantaged in an environment which changes overnight from one of regulated trading hours to one of deregulation. The Committee has taken this into account in its recommendations. Another point is that the nature of leases in large shopping complexes prohibits individual retailers from opening or closing at times which they are free to determine. The question of whether any increased costs associated with opening longer hours would be reflected in increased prices to consumers was not able to be determined by the Committee.

As far as the effect of deregulation on employees is concerned, a lot of controversy has been generated by claims that deregulation will contribute to a further decline in the number of full time, permanent positions in the retail industry. The Committee considers that deregulation would most probably accelerate or at least continue the trend towards the structural re-adjustment of employment in the industry-away from full time to part time and casual employment. However, it is considered that this is an inevitable trend and major retailers have stated in evidence that only voluntary staff would be used on weekends. This would reduce the impact on the family and social life of employees on Saturdays and Sundays.

Reference was made during the inquiry to results of surveys to determine public support or opposition to deregulation or extended hours of trading. The most recent survey results indicate increasing support for an extension of trading hours to include Saturday afternoons. The Committee acknowledges the shortcomings of such results but at the same time has included the latest findings as an appendix to its report.

The Committee, while favouring the general principle of deregulation, considers that the nature of the market place in the Australian Capital Territory, combined with the oversupply of retail space in areas of Canberra and a shortage in others, makes it difficult to recommend the immediate repeal of existing legislative provisions governing trading hours. It is impossible to accurately forecast the effect of deregulation because of the number of variables involved. It is also not possible to draw on the experience of comparable areas in Australia because of the special nature of the market place in the Australian Capital Territory and the fact that there is a general lack of experience of deregulation in other States.

Therefore, in reaching its final conclusions, the Committee wanted to arrive at a formula which would enable a move to greater flexibility in trading hours while not implementing full deregulation. It was considered that too many exclusionary categories of shops or goods would create problems of definition and legal interpretation and that therefore a single provision was preferable to a number of constraints. For this reason, it was decided to base the determination on the number of staff employed by any one retailer. The only restriction applies to major traders which are those employing more than 100 staff, whether in one or more shops throughout Australia.

The Committee supports unlimited trading Monday to Saturday. This means that in addition to the hours presently allowed under the Ordinance, all shops will be free to determine their own hours of operation between midnight Sunday to midnight Saturday. Major traders will be excluded from opening on Sundays enabling small shopowners to be free to trade in an environment not dominated by the major stores.
Finally, the Committee considers that any future reviews of trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory be referred to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly.

talk.start.para: —In accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969 I present the final report relating to the following proposed work:

speech.para: New air traffic services centre and control tower, Perth Airport, Western Australia.
I seek leave to have a statement in relation to that report incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The document read as follows-
Mr President, the report just presented is the final report relating to a new air traffic services centre and control tower at Perth Airport, Western Australia.

The initial report which recommended the construction of all works contained in the reference, except the control tower, was presented on 27 October 1981. The Committee recommended deferment of the control tower because at that stage a Master plan for Perth Airport had not been completed, and the Committee felt that both the siting and size of the control tower could pre-empt certain options for the ultimate development of Perth Airport.

This report and the public hearings in relation to the control tower have been completed with the Committee and public fully aware of the four development strategies, and of the announced preference of the Department of Aviation for what is termed Strategy 1-In short, retention of the current runway system with all terminal development centred around the current terminal locations. The Committee thought it necessary to fully canvas the development options and to make a recommendation on a preferred development strategy for Perth Airport, before examining the narrower question of the control tower. Most witnesses giving evidence to the Committee chose to comment on the development strategies, and additionally, the Committee received from the Department of Aviation copies of all submissions it received from organisations and individuals commenting on the four development strategies proposed by the Department of Aviation.

In making its recommendation on a preferred strategy, the Committee acknowledges two constraints-firstly, that the final environmental impact statement will not be completed until November 1982, and secondly that the House of Representatives Committee on Environment and Conservation had just commenced its inquiry on aircraft noise at airports in and adjacent to major cities. The Committee, based on its study of the initial EIS, does not anticipate that significant environmental problems will arise.

However, in relation to the inquiry on airport noise, the Committee has taken pains to ensure that any recommendations that that Committee may make in relation to Perth Airport are not pre-empted. The Committee acknowledges that an aircraft noise nuisance problem exists in relation to Perth Airport, and has given this aspect considerable weight in recommending a strategy. A number of aspects of the aircraft noise nuisance have arisen at my Committee's inquiry into Perth Airport. These include:
(1) The night flight weighting formula used for preparation of noise exposure forecast recommended for change by the recent National Acoustic Laboratory report.
(2) Claims that NEF patterns are inaccurate because planes are not following the defined flight paths in and out of Perth Airport.

(3) Conflict in information given by DOA in relation to areas likely to be affected by aircraft noise should a wide-spaced parallel runway be provided. It is necessary that definite information be gathered on this point, particularly as it affects suburbs such as Forrestfield and Gosnells. It would be a futile exercise if the noise problem is merely transferred from one residential area to another.

(4) Some housing development still appears to be taking place in areas likely to be exposed to some aircraft noise nuisance. In its initial report, the Committee recommended the re-formation of the Western Australian Airports Committee, and sees the co-operation of all levels of government as necessary to reduce the likelihood of such problems arising.

These matters have been passed on to the House of Representatives Committee on Environment and Conservation for their detailed examination. The strategy recommended by the Committee is basically strategy 4, with deferred provision of a wide-spaced parallel runway. The Committee recommends the provision of the wide-spaced parallel runway when traffic demands it or earlier if recommended by the House of Representatives Committee on Environment and Conservation. Very simply, strategy 4 provides for development of a wide-spaced parallel runway, and terminal developments to take place east of the current runways.
The Committee has therefore recommended a 60-65 metre high control tower consistent with its recommended development strategy.

debate.title: AUSTRALIAN DELEGATION TO THE MIDDLE EAST

proctext.para: Report

speech.speaker: Sibraa Sen K.W.

talk.start.para: —I present the official report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and the Sultanate of Oman. I seek leave to move a motion and to incorporate my tabling statement in Hansard.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The document read as follows-

I present the official report of the Australian parliamentary delegation to the Kingdom of Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and the Sultanate of Oman. The delegation was led by the honourable member for Warringah, Mr M. MacKellar and included the member for Swan, Mr K. Beazley, the member for Melbourne Ports, Mr C. Holding, the member for Paterson, Mr F. O'Keefe, the member for Eden-Monaro, Mr M. Sainsbury, and Senator Kilgariff and myself. The visit to the Middle East took place from 10 to 21 January of this year. This was the first Australian parliamentary delegation to visit the area, and I sincerely hope not the last, for it is an area where increased contact can but benefit the three countries visited and Australia. It is an area of great wealth and progress where Australian industry can play a part.

One of the purposes of the delegation was to confirm and expand the goodwill of the Australian Parliament and people towards Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and Oman. In this regard I would like to acknowledge the work done by the Deputy Prime Minister on his visits to the region. His high standing in the Middle East certainly assisted the delegation in its task.

The delegation's prime purpose was to gather information on the three countries visited, with a view to making recommendations to aid the formulation of Australia's policies on developments in those countries and the region generally . The delegation came away from the Middle East realising the vast potential for additional Australian trade in the area. The amount of development going on in the region at present gives us the perfect opportunity. The delegation saw cities and ports being created from scratch, with most building materials, expertise and labour being imported. It is to be hoped that Australian industry through our Trade Commissioners will grasp this opprtunity to expand trade with the Middle East. As the Middle East learns more about Australia, and vice versa, I am sure Australia's relations with these countries will go from strength to strength.

Every country we visited expressed interest in sending students to Australia for higher education; I believe some students are already here, and hopefully the knowledge they obtain about Australia will greatly assist our future relations with the Middle East. In the report the delegation has recommended a number of areas where Australia's knowledge in agriculture can be utilised. The delegation has also recommended that cultural exchanges between Oman and Australia, particularly youth exchanges, take place. The Omanis are particularly interested in having an Australian youth soccer team visit their country. By visiting this area of the world we were able to dispel many myths, and that is why I see it as a high priority that members of this Parliament and Australian businessmen continue to visit the area in order to learn the history and the customs, so that our relations and trade with the Middle East can increase.
I would like to thank the Australian Ambassador in Jeddah, the Senior Trade Commissioner in Adu Dhabi, and their staffs, for the great assistance given to the delegation during our visit.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

proctext.para: Annual Report 1981-82

speech.speaker: Ray Sen R.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the paper.

Initially I would like to refer-this is not reported in the Australian Electoral Office report-to the amount of assistance given by divisional returning officers in Victoria in the State elections. We have a rather strange system in Victoria where the 33 divisional returning officers become State returning officers. Added to that are about another 40 or 50 amateur returning officers whose quality varies from excellent to hopeless. I have to say that the 33 returning officers conducted the last State campaign with commendable efficiency and were able to get results in early and efficiently.

The most significant part of this report is on page 5 under 'Legislation'. There we find the citizens amendment to the Commonwealth Electoral Act, consisting of some five lines, and then the rest of the page is blank, as has been the Government's record in reforming the Electoral Act. Two years ago the Government amended the Electoral Act to take out any constriction on expenditure by individuals or parties in election campaigns. It promised at the time to set up an inquiry and come back with recommendations to amend the Electoral Act. The Harders Committee of Inquiry into Disclosure of Electoral Expenses has, I think, reported. For over a year the Government has had that report in its hands. It is still considering the matter. If we have an early election it will still be considering the matter so we will go into a second federal election without any restriction on expenditure by candidates seeking to be elected to either this chamber or the House of Representatives. I think it is disgraceful that that report has not been acted upon. I do not know what is in it, whether its recommendations are so complex and require such drafting skills that the Government cannot bring in any legislation. As well as that, two committees have reviewed the Electoral Act. The first committee recommended substantial changes but because the changes were so comprehensive and caused so much distaste to this Government, it had to set up a second inquiry. The second inquiry has progressed. According to information received during the Estimates committees hearings it reported long ago to the Government. Again the Government has the matter under consideration and review and we hear nothing about it.

There is no doubt that the Electoral Act needs urgent review. It has not been reviewed for almost 17 years, since 1965. Reviews were conducted in 1973, 1974 and 1975. The amendments were all rejected in this place by this Government. If anyone is wondering why the Government does not review the Electoral Act, it is simply because as it is currently constituted it is favourable to the Government . To use a football expression: 'If you are kicking with the breeze, why should you switch to the other end?' Nearly every aspect of the existing Act favours the Government. I do not place any blame for this on the Australian Electoral Office. It is not its job to criticise governments or to say they are working under an archaic electoral Act. But it is disappointing that every time we get one of these annual reports we find virtually nothing under the heading of ' Legislation'.

One thing I would like to congratulate the Electoral Office on is its initiatives taken, particularly in the Lowe by-election, in trying to get the turnout of voters to the highest possible level. Instead of just sitting back and conducting the election in Lowe it sent two different lots of mail out to every elector in Lowe telling them there was a by-election and how important it was to vote. The turnout was higher than for a general election. There were other factors, notably the importance of the by-election, which contributed to that. I have known other returning officers actually sending out to each subdivision a note saying when the election is and where the nearest polling booth is so not everyone goes to the same booth in that subdivision. This results in an even spread, which is more efficient. I think that is a very commendable initiative by the Electoral Office.

The only other thing I would like to say is in regard to the electoral officers conduct of industrial elections in unions. I believe the Electoral Office has been given an impossible task to run efficiently fair elections when union elections are referred to them. There are no uniform rules governing how those elections should be conducted. There are certain guidelines in industrial relations legislation. But the problem that has cropped up in the last few years is that because there are no uniform rules-no rules to say, for instance, in certain unions that when the votes are returned the name of the person who is voting must be on the back of it-all sorts of allegations of bodgie elections conducted by the Electoral Office are made. It is not its fault; it has to run those elections in accordance with the rules of the union, whatever those rules may be. I think it is time that the Department of Employment and Industrial Relations drew up a uniform code of electoral procedures in union elections and so avoid those things. Of course, if the Government cannot revise the Commonwealth Electoral Act I do not really give it very much chance of revising the Conciliation and Arbitration Act to effect fair elections within unions when they are conducted by the Electoral Office.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: —I believe that the annual report of the Australian Electoral Office is a disappointing document from a range of viewpoints. Most importantly, I suppose, it is disappointing for what it does not say rather than what it does say. The Office goes back a fair way in Federal history. However, I do not believe that in past years it has really done its job in a promotional sense. I point to one aspect and refer honourable senators to an answer given in the other place in August this year by the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman), who has ministerial responsibility for the Australian Electoral Office. I wish to relate that answer to page 3 of the annual report of the Commonwealth Electoral Office, in which there is some discussion about automatic data processing. The report says that the Office is looking at this matter. It states:

speech.para: The design is expected to include an on-line network connecting all Divisional Offices, Head Office and Central Office with computer systems to support roll maintenance, polling result collation and distribution, election arrangements, employment of polling officials and provision of management information.

While there is some updating into the 1980s in respect of the Office keeping its records in order, what is the position in relation to updating our voting procedures? The very essence and basis of why the Australian Electoral Office exists and the very basis of the democratic system is the means by which we are able to record our votes and have the system operate efficiently and effectively .

The Minister made some extraordinary statements in his reply. I suppose we in this place listen to some rather odd answers. But when written down those answers become an almost alarming admission of ignorance. I quote from the House of Representatives Hansard of 9 September. Talking about why we should not go anywhere near computers in relation to elections the Minister said:
It also needs to be taken into account that existing computerised voting systems are essentially giant adding machines.
Of course, that would immediately lead one to the conclusion that the person who gave such an answer knows absolutely nothing about computers. He went on to say:
This is satisfactory with first-past-the-post voting, but quite a different story when it comes to a preferential system, notwithstanding the advances of recent years.

I am not quite sure in what year the Minister is living but he is certainly not living in 1982. One can get, for under $5, off the desk of a major department store a hand-held computer which will perform calculations of a most extraordinarily advanced kind. In other words, the technology had advanced way beyond the suggestion that computers are essentially giant adding machines. The information on which the Minister based his answer presumably came out of a handbook that was given to children in primary schools about 15 years ago.

One, of course, only has to look at the American situation to find the range of mechanical devices which are used in the States. These devices have been used for a long time and are appropriate only in respect of the first-past-the-post system. A punchcard operation, which is able to take care of equally well both a first-past-the-post and a preferential system, is also used. There is no great difficulty with either of these systems. A number of States, such as Arkansas, California, Indiana, Michigan and Minnesota, are using optical scanners which can take care of any ballot operation one would care to name. The Minister's objection to our looking at and investigating other systems is absurd. Probably an objection which of much more substance is that of cost. Of course, cost has to be looked at in terms of cost outlay for ensuing elections and cost recovery during the elections that a system would be able to service.

As Senator Robert Ray has already pointed out, the Australian Electoral Office conducts not only Federal polls but also polls in respect of the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly, as well as miscellaneous polls such as those on industrial matters. A system adopted by the Australian Electoral Office could, simply by agreement with the States, be used for local government and State elections. In other words, the system could be employed constantly. It need not be like the one-off method that we use at the moment.

Of course, we acknowledge that our elections are costly. I think that this fact is accepted by everybody within a democracy. But let us look at the type of cost savings we might be able to achieve as well as the cost efficiency we would be able to gain by making use of computerised systems. The Minister outlined the reason why the Australian Electoral Office is not engaging in any of these activities. He also informed us that the Australian Electoral Office does not even have a listing of recent articles on this substantial matter. This is a most extraordinary admission to make about the major body in this country which looks after Federal elections. The Minister in his answer said:
The polling booths are not necessarily on Commonwealth property, fixed from one election to another . . .

This is certainly the case. However, with a little bit of lateral thinking one could easily move them to property which is either Commonwealth or State owned. I make two suggestions. We have throughout this country, although we are rapidly closing them down, a very large number of post offices. We have also primary, secondary, tertiary and further education, university and colleges of advanced education facilities throughout the country. A combination of just those two groups of organisations would allow us immediately to put computers on line. This could even be done by telephone linkages. Almost all of the post offices and schools that I have mentioned would be linked to a telephone.

Of course, the absurdity of the objections comes clearly into focus when we look at the Totalisator Agency Board system which operates every Saturday, the day on which we normally have elections. The system required for elections would be no more complex than that one. The TAB system is able to supply results of a race that night. It is interesting to note, in terms of our national priorities, that we can run a gambling organisation of a most massive and comprehensive kind , yet we cannot do the same thing in respect of elections. Every possible type of pseudo objection has been put up.

talk.start.para: —You are talking about the Government?
—Yes.
—As a gambling organisation?

—No; I am saying that the TAB is a gambling organisation which has a facility which the Government does not have. I come to the last point, a point which I think is constantly missed in this debate: The reason for computerisation is not the speed at which results can be produced. I think if somebody in this House actually paid some attention to the way in which we count the Senate ballot he would immediately be impressed by the possibilities of a computerised system. The counting of the ballot for the Senate is probably one of the most archaic methods still existing in any democratic country, yet the system itself is one of the most advanced. In other words, we have in operation for the Senate an incredibly advanced voting system which can very accurately predict the percentage support within the country at large. Yet the counting method is extremely primitive. It is done by taking large guesstimates on tables and phoning in from around the country to try to see which pile of ballot papers shall be taken off next. I suggest that the Australian Electoral Office needs to look carefully at and get on its files before next year all information relevant to this topic so that in its report next year we may actually have some suggestions from it which have more substance than the reply that the Minister gave in the other place.

speech.speaker: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

talk.start.para: —Once again, the annual report of the Australian Electoral Office is instructive, principally because of the deficiencies it reveals in the electoral policies of the Fraser Government. In that respect, I do not put any blame on the Electoral Office itself because it is a very highly efficient and professional organisation which operates very successfully within the confines of what this Government allows, both financially and politically. Two points need to be brought out in respect of the Electoral Office and the way in which this Government has shackled its work.

speech.para: After the 1977 elections, the Government, through the then Minister for Administrative Services, Mr McLeay, called for a report to be prepared on the electoral legislation. After a considerable delay-it took 18 months to prepare it-a report running to 181 pages and looking at all the aspects and deficiencies of the Commonwealth Electoral Act and the effects that flow from them was prepared. It was and still is a very thorough and useful contribution to what needs to be done in respect of voting in Federal elections. It was made available to the Minister and the Government but not to the Parliament. I probed and asked questions on numerous occasions of Ministers in this place, one of whom actually held in the Senate the portfolio of Administrative Services, but the report was not made public for reasons best known to the Government. It has not been presented to the Parliament nor did the Government take any action to implement any of the recommendations in the report. As honourable senators know the Senate has been stymied in looking at the report because of the intransigent and obstructive position taken by the Government in refusing to allow a Senate select committee to look at the report or the Electoral Act itself.

The new Minister for Administrative Services (Mr Newman)-we have had three ministerial changes in this area-obviously decided that the report was too hot to handle and set about getting around the problem by commissioning a further review of the Electoral Act. Despite a great deal of prodding on my behalf, the whereabouts of that review is still not known. In a letter to me, Mr Newman said the review was nearing completion. That was in April 1981, 18 months ago. He said that the second report was nearing completion. Of course, a third report on the Commonwealth Electoral Act was prepared by Mr Harders which dealt with another aspect of elections. It too has been pigeonholed. Three reports have dealt with aspects of the Electoral Act which have been kept from the Parliament and the Australian people. As a result, the valuable reviews that have been carried out by the Department and by the special committee under Mr Harders are still not public documents and have still not been considered by this Government . The Government stands indicted for that when we know, on the basis of those reports, that there are considerable deficiencies in the way in which the Electoral Act is operating.

The second point that I wish to make regarding aspects that were raised in one of the reports which came into my hands is the Department's considerable concern about the enormous informal vote still rife in our Federal electoral system. This is a particularly severe problem for the Senate because in excess of 10 per cent of voters have their votes ruled invalid as a result of the complexities of the voting system and the deficiencies in the way in which the Electoral Act is being administered. Ten per cent of those people who vote in Australia are being disenfranchised by the nature of the voting system which causes their votes to be set aside because they have not gone to the extraordinary length of filling in to the last detail 50 or 60 numbers against the names of the candidates standing for an election. That only shows how correct it was that the Australian Labor Party, under the Daly legislation, sought to rectify it. That gave rise to another of the obstructions placed in the way of the Labor Party's endeavours in 1972-75 to bring about a more fair and equitable system which removed the sorts of difficulties to which I am referring.

The stringent requirement of our voting system in this regard makes Australia a laughing stock. Nowhere else in the world does this situation exist. Nowhere else does an absurd rule operate. Nowhere else could an informal voting rate of 10 per cent or more be allowed by any government, any Minister or any chamber worth its salt. The efforts that I have made in this chamber to look at this problem have been nullified by the obstructionist position taken by every Government member on the other side of the House. Yet the solution is quite simple. It has already been introduced in State politics in New South Wales, Tasmania and South Australia. Even in the Australian Capital Territory itself, a system operates which reduces the requirement of having to mark every square on the ballot paper and provides for a lesser more meaningful number. Such a reform in the Federal system would immediately cut the informal vote by at least two- thirds. Instead of 10 per cent of people losing the value of their vote, the figure would be reduced to no more than two or three per cent. That would be in accordance with normal voting patterns.

The Electoral Office has for some time been carrying out another survey in respect of the informal voting. It has that report in its possession as an internal working document. The Minister has it. He has sat on it and has not been prepared to take any steps. Perhaps it is not the Minister's fault. Perhaps this Government has refused to act on it as it has refused to take any steps to rectify the current redistribution problem that faces Australia. More than 32 seats in Australia are now beyond the tolerance level of voters. We have an absurd situation in that some mainland electorates in Australia have over 93,000 voters and others have over 60,000 voters. In Tasmania, because of the constitutional requirements, the numbers are about 50,000. If there is no election until the end of next year, mainland seats could conceivably have twice the number of voters of those in Tasmania.

These matters have been brought to the attention of the Government and it has refused to take any steps at all. It is recreant. It is a failure on the part of the Minister that he has done nothing about these matters or, if he has done something, it is a failure on the part of the Government. It is another example of the failure of the Government to move when it knows what needs to be done. Of course, a further example of where it has failed to act is the wholesale tax evasion which was in the Government's knowledge when it came to office in 1975. Cabinet members were not able to be persuaded to act because of their conservative bias and the protection of their friends in the tax area. In the same way, the Government has not been prepared to take the necessary steps to reform the Electoral Act and to act on the grave deficiencies that exist in it. One can conclude only that it is purely a party political decision on the part of the Minister, the Government or the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) that these sorts of things should still exist despite the fact that they have had in their possession since 1977 reports the adoption of whose recommendations would overcome and obviate the deficiencies to which I have referred.

Why does the Government do this? It gives the Government a decided advantage if ethnic people and people with low educational standards cannot comprehend the system. Migrants come to Australia from countries whose voting systems are entirely different. They may have proportional voting, first past the post or optional voting systems. The States have optional systems. In the States voting has to finish by 6 o'clock. Commonwealth elections are still being conducted from 8 a.m. to 8 p.m., but in a number of states they are conducted from 8 a.m. to 6 p.m. The different voting systems and legislation of many of the States create difficulties for the electorate at large. That is understandable. Yet this Government sits on the reports and fails to take any action at all. However , it is prepared to allow to operate in the Australian Capital Territory such optional preferential systems which make allowance for a person's inability to complete a ballot paper. As long as the clear intention of the voter is indicated the vote is regarded as valid.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

proctext.para: Annual Report 1981-82

speech.speaker: Button Sen J.N.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The Senate has before it the annual report of Telecom Australia for the year ended June 1982, and I wish to draw attention to one or two of the key matters referred to therein. The first is mentioned on the first page of the Chairman's statement. He reports vastly improved results in the operations of Telecom since 1975, when that organisation was established, and makes the following point:

Telecom is sometimes criticised on the grounds that its profits are too high. Those who suggest that Telecom should operate at a lower level of return, fail to appreciate that the consequent reduced cash flow would mean a reduction in funds available for expenditure on the expansion and maintenance of the network and would make Telecom's task of improving the standard of customer service more difficult than it now is.

I have read that passage because it draws attention to a very important aspect which is frequently misrepresented by the Press in commenting on Telecom's profits. On 14 and 15 October a number of articles in the Press drew attention to Telecom's high profit of some $275m. Profits of that order made by private corporations are sometimes hailed as providing an example of success, whereas they are not in relation to Telecom because it is a public corporation providing public services. For the record, I make the point that the profit of $275m, given Telecom's capital investment, represents a profit of 9.2 per cent before interest charges are allowed for and 3.2 per cent after interest charges are allowed for. It is very important to realise the size of the investment in respect of which that profit is earned. I repeat, the position is frequently misrepresented. It is suggested that Telecom should not make such profits because it is providing a public service.

What should be realised, as the Chairman points out, is that Telecom must finance urgently needed new services from profits. Thus, in 1981-82 internal funds, or profits, provided 74 per cent of the total capital investment needed by Telecom in order to extend its telephone network. That network has been massively extended since 1975 when Telecom was established. I repeat, 74 per cent of the funds needed for capital investment were internally generated from profits. Those funds are spent on expanding the network and carrying out other necessary works to improve Australia's telecommunications service.

Telecom is required to generate internally 50 per cent of its working capital, and the figure of 74 per cent is much higher than is achieved by any other telecommunications authority in the world and certainly much higher than that of any normal business enterprise. I draw attention to some comparative figures. For instance, Bell Canada finances 53 per cent of its expansion from internal revenue. For the National Telecommunicatons Company of Japan the figure is 68 per cent; for the Bell Company of the United States it is 67 per cent; and for Deutsches Bundespost the figure is 44 per cent. For Telecom this year, according to the business outlays document of Telecom, the figure is close to 85 per cent.

If one examines the comparative proportions of internal financing in private business, or other large statutory undertakings, one notes the following examples: Australian Consolidated Industries Ltd finances 56 per cent of its capital works internally. For the State Electricity Commission of Victoria the figure is 21 per cent; and for a company such as CSR Ltd the figure is 67 per cent. Thus, an enormous corporation such as Telecom is required to finance a much higher proportion of its capital works than is expected of other instrumentalities in other countries and of other businesses in Australia.

The point of all of this is simply to comment on Telecom's integrity and efficiency in financing its business operations. The Chairman, in the report, makes the point that between 1975 and 1982 the rate of annual business growth ranged from 8 per cent to 13 per cent. Last year it was 12 per cent. More than 80 per cent of homes in Australia now have telephones, compared with 62 per cent in 1975. The lesson in all of this is that Telecom is a highly productive organisation with increases in its productivity, increased business growth and increases in the proportion of capital that is generated internally to expand the telephone network; that at this time it can be seen, by Australian standards , to be a most successful enterprise. That does not mean that it does not have faults in regard to the delivery of services. There is always room for improvement in efficiency.

At present this Parliament is awaiting the report of the Public Inquiry into Telecommunications Services in Australia-the Davidson, Committee-which was set up by the Government at the time of the disastrous razor gang exercise of April 1981. Its purpose is to ascertain which sections of Telecom might be made available to private enterprise. The consequences of any such action would be to damage severely the business structure that I have just described. It would be damaging in terms of competition, which would result in poorer services, particularly for people in Australia's rural communities. Telecom has not been allowed by this Government to function as well as it might. It has not been allowed to borrow additional finance for capital works, as recommended by the McKinsey and Co. Inc. inquiry which was set up by the Government. The report of that inquiry suggested that Telecom's borrowing capacity should be expanded. That has not been permitted. Telecom is not being permitted to develop new services such as videotex, which would have provided a service throughout Australia in rural communities especially. Permission to proceed was denied on ideological grounds. As a result, because no other organisation can provide it as efficiently, cheaply and well, this new technology will not proceed in Australia for a number of years. These sorts of hobbles which have been placed on Telecom as a result of ministerial stupidity have not debilitated the organisation to the extent that it cannot produce a very favourable report, such as the annual report for 1981-82, which I commend to the Senate.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

proctext.para: Annual Report 1981-82

speech.speaker: Button Sen J.N.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report of the Australian Broadcasting Commission is more or less on time this year. The ABC has been the subject of criticism in the past for not presenting its annual report to the Parliament at the right time. This is a significant report. It is the fiftieth report of the ABC. Honourable senators will recall that earlier this year the ABC celebrated its 50th anniversary with a very high standard of programs. It is the fiftieth report of the ABC; it is also the last. I think it is important to note that too. If the legislation which has been through the House of Representatives and has come to the Senate- it will be supported by the Opposition except for some disastrous provisions-is passed the ABC, as it has been traditionally known, will no longer exist. It will be replaced by a new national broadcasting service which, of course, will represent a continuance of the role which the ABC has played.

I wanted to highlight one or two important aspects of this report. The ABC, in referring to the new legislation before the Parliament and in referring to the Australian Broadcasting Commission Committee of Review-the Dix Committee-which inquired into the organisation, notes that its role has now been clarified. That is to say, the ABC is now enjoined to 'provide a balance between programs of wide appeal and specialised programs'. In practice this will mean both. I hope that this will mean an end to the silly sort of arguments which debilitated the ABC for years about what its proper function was-whether it was a majority broadcaster or a complementary special broadcaster looking after the interests only of minority groups. I would argue and I have argued for some time-I think the Government has acceded to this argument-that it has to be both. It will have a very good effect on commercial and other broadcasters if it can do so-called mass entertainment programming as well as other programming and give those broadcasters good and quality competition. I think that is very important.

It was in this spirit of achieving a vigorous approach to the ABC that the Opposition made its widely publicised response to the Dix Committee report. One of the points which was argued very much in that response was that this question of a charter for the ABC should be resolved. One of the things we also hoped for in that comment on the Dix report was that the ABC would have adequate funding for Australian productions from now on. Traditionally, the ABC has been a pace setter in terms of quality programming in this country, particularly in quality drama and current affairs programs. It would be nice to see the ABC in this new period resuming the role which it carried out over such a long period.

Unfortunately, of course, the Government is still doing curious things in relation to the ABC. The Commission itself draws attention to its being left off the board of Aussat Pty Ltd, the satellite company, when every other major user of the satellite is represented on the board of that company. Only the ABC, of the major or potential users is left off. It is nice to see that even the commissioners, with that touch of humour which sometimes flashes into ABC programming, noted, surely with tongue in cheek, that although the ABC has been left off the board of Aussat Pty Ltd, the satellite company, a man called Denis Horgan, who happens to be a director of the satellite company, has been appointed recently as a commissioner of the ABC. One can only assume that the comment was made by the Australian Broadcasting Commission with, as I said, tongue in cheek.

The report displays the continued mean-spirited approach of this Government towards important issues confronting the ABC. One example, as I have said, is that it has been left off the board of the satellite company. The Opposition hopes that the Government will change its attitude to some of these questions in light of the new legislation relating to the ABC. The Government will have the opportunity when it considers the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal report on radiated subscription television to consider the case for an ABC RSTV network throughout Australia. At page 7 of the report the Commissioner states that the ABC is willing, in principle, to operate such a service. As we all know the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, for reasons not fully justified, said that the ownership and operation of subscription television should be exclusively the province of the private sector. The ABC and the Special Broadcasting Service are , in the view of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal, to be excluded. That report of the Tribunal has some horrendous philosophical defects in it and some appallingly bad economics. It is unfortunate but I guess that most of its decisions will not be taken too seriously in the light of those facts.

Ministers in this Government, of course, talk consistently of the need to get more funds into national or non-commercial broadcasting. Here they have a golden opportunity to raise such money by subscription television. Surely the ABC needs it more than the commercial sector. If the ABC had a subscription television service that would be a substantial contributor, in our estimate, to the funds of the Australian Broadcasting Commission and to the improvement of national broadcasting in this country. It would mean also, of course, that giving it to the ABC would be fairer as between commercial operators. I draw attention to the fact that at page 57 of the report it is recorded that ABC television achieved a 55 per cent or more Australian content in its programming last year. This is a very important achievement and we must not lose sight of it.

I note again that the recommendations of the Australian Broadcasting Tribunal on subscription television and cable television in relation to Australian content are tantamount to culling it right down in order to make such services viable in Australia. The message from that is that existing commercial broadcasters and the ABC presumably will be required to maintain Australian content but that providers of cable television will not be. Most of the programs presumably will come from the United States, or overseas. In this country we have spent years building up what Mr Gyngell, as chairman of the Broadcasting Tribunal, called the 'Australian look'. If it is all to be prejudiced by the introduction of new technologies in haste that would be disastrous in the Opposition's view for this country.

The report refers to other notable achievements of the ABC, including a valuable contribution to Aboriginal broadcasting. We look ahead to a great development for the national broadcasting service. The necessity for a second regional radio network is a matter of prime concern. We hope that the Government will think again on such issues as the appointment of commissioners of the ABC and some of the other undesirable features of the proposed legislation.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debate.title: UNITED NATIONS GENERAL ASSEMBLY THIRTY-SIXTH SESSION 1981

proctext.para: Report of the Australian Delegation

speech.speaker: Martin Sen K.J.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the paper.
I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

proctext.para: Report on Impact of Robots

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the report.

This report by the Australian Science and Technology Council is prepared by the Technological Change Committee of that body. It is the first report on the impact of robots in Australia and as such is significant. It goes through the benefits that industry generally can expect to receive from the introduction of robots. Generally it encourages their introduction without any problems or discouragement. The report lists amongst the advantages of robots increased productivity, reduced labour costs, increased product quality and improved safety and working conditions. It also states that there is a great need for good communication among the trade union movement, the Government and industry so that everybody is quite clear what impact robotics will have on Australian industry and the Australian economy. While I could not agree more with that aspect of the report, it is vital that consultation take place.

The report makes a number of recommendations which appear to me to be quite reasonable. Nevertheless, there is one aspect of the report with which I must take great issue. It tries to make an estimate of the number of jobs that robots will replace. It states that in the next decade it expects the introduction of 1 ,200 to 1,600 robots into Australian industry. It goes on to state that each robot will replace 1.5 jobs and on that basis in the next decade it expects only about 3,000 to 4,000 jobs to be significantly affected by the introduction of robots. That is an estimate with which I cannot agree. I believe that the Committee of ASTEC has very seriously underestimated the number of robots that will be introduced into this country and the effect that their introduction will have on the job market. In Japan and in the United States factories are being set up right now composed entirely of robots. Some years ago I attended an international convention which was attended by leading businessmen and manufacturers from around the world. The only thing they wanted to talk about was robots. It was the thing exciting their imaginations. They were saying that we could get robots to work 24 hours a day without any overtime and that they did not go on strike.

talk.start.para: —They do not buy goods either, do they, Senator?

—I am coming to that. The point I am trying to make is that we have our heads in the sand in this country if we do not honestly recognise the impact that robots will be likely to have on the job market. We are in the middle of an industrial revolution and we have to face up to that. This report does not face up to that. It is seriously in error in this vital aspect.

speech.para: Senator Primmer raised a very important point. Robots are a basic new development and they will dramatically affect the job market. What are we going to do about them? I do not believe there is any way that we can inhibit their introduction. There is no way that we can stop the flow of technology, particularly in this area where, as the Committee has pointed out, there are so many advantages. Robots offer the opportunity to replace uninteresting jobs in often very difficult, noisy and unattractive environments. We cannot stop their introduction but we can face up to their impact and plan accordingly. There is no doubt that in the next decade there will be a vital need for retraining. Clearly, we have to get some basic objectives ahead of the nation and particularly ahead of our manufacturing industries so that we can direct our efforts and our resources in line with objectives that are generally agreed to by all sectors of the community and which could reasonably be expected to be pursued with vigor by employees, employers and the Government alike. This is possible. It is not easy, but it is possible.

I suggest a long term indicative plan is absolutely essential if we are to avoid a catastrophic labour situation in Australia. I believe the report is significant. It is the first report that has faced up to the technological revolution. However, a lot more work needs to be done on the impact on the job market and on our labour relations generally. I conclude by stressing that the only way this impact can be minimised and serious social disruption avoided is by consultation, which the report makes clear, with sectors of the community so that the estimates of the future effect of technology are accurately forecast. At this point I believe they have not been accurately forecast.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

proctext.para: Statement by Minister for Transport and Construction

speech.speaker: Tate Sen M.C.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the paper.

It is with pleasure that I speak on this statement. I am particularly pleased that Senator Townley is in the chair because Senator Townley, Senator Rae, Senator Grimes and I were the four senators designated by this chamber to consider, among other things, a replacement service for the Empress of Australia which fulfils an extremely important role in plying across Bass Strait between Webb Dock in Melbourne and Devonport, carrying some 112,000 passengers a year. The Senate Select Committee on Passenger Fares and Services to and from Tasmania concluded that the figure was quite considerably below the demand which could be generated by an efficiently run, well promoted service. The Committee came to the conclusion that some 140,000 passengers could be carried across Bass Strait in a passenger-cargo ferry service, either by means of one vessel or two. The purport of the statement is to aquaint the Parliament with the fact that some five organisations have indicated an interest in providing that replacement service. They are the Australian National Line, Brambles Industries Ltd, Celsiunator Industries Pty Ltd, Tasmanian Shipping Services and TNT Bulkships Ltd.

I think it is extremely important that some points made in that statement be commented on, always in the light of the Senate Committee's report. For example, it should always be kept in mind by the Government that the Senate Committee set out very clearly those principles which it thought, after taking much evidence, ought to be the guiding principles for a replacement service. They were: That passengers and freight should be combined in the service; that the main service should operate between Melbourne and Devonport; that the service should operate overnight; that the service should contain a mixed configuration of berths and sleeper lounge chairs; that the service should provide accommodation for at least 650 passengers in one or more ships; and that the ANL should negotiate with the maritime unions with a view to reducing manning levels.

I should like to elaborate on at least two of those matters. Firstly, in relation to the statement by the Minister for Transport and Construction (Mr Hunt) that some of the proposals, but not all, envisaged an overnight service, it must be said that the Senate Committee concluded very firmly that a daylight crossing of Bass Strait was not in the best interests of those passengers who would have to stay awake during the transit of what can be a somewhat turbulent stretch of water. The second matter relates to costs involved in the embarkation or disembarkation of passengers, cargo and vehicles at penalty rates outside normal daylight working hours. Of course, it is a fact that most tourists would prefer to travel across Bass Strait at night time so they could enjoy daylight hours for travelling on land.

In relation to the statement by the Minister that all the proposals were for a combined passenger-cargo vessel and included services capable of operating on a commercially viable basis without direct government subsidy, it must be said that this also was the view of the Committee. It was known that, in any case, the ANL would have to replace its freight vessels operating into north-west Tasmania in the mid-1980s and that therefore it was sensible to attempt to combine those two functions of carrying cargo and passengers across Bass Strait in a vessel or vessels which were so constructed and which provided extra capacity for both cargo and passengers in a way which would not require Commonwealth Government subsidy. I think that that was an important point of agreement between the Senate Committee and most of the proposals put forward. But what is of concern is the fact that the Minister says that terminal ports in the proposals vary between Melbourne-Devonport, Melbourne-Burnie, Melbourne-Bell Bay, Westernport-Bell Bay, or some combination of these terminal ports. He further says:

. . . that the Commonwealth Government's prime concern is that as far as possible the Empress of Australia be replaced with a service or services based on a sound commercial decision rather than government selection.

I put it to the Senate that the Government cannot escape making a decision which is essential to the viability of the four-port system in Tasmania, particularly to the viability of the port of Devonport; namely, that the Senate Committee's recommendations on the routes and ports that ought to be employed in a replacement service ought to be adopted by the Government as the criteria within which the proposals should be assessed.
The Senate Committee, in Chapter 14 of its report, said:

Devonport has been the main Tasmanian sea passenger terminal since the introduction of the Princess of Tasmania in 1959. The city has therefore been geared for a long time to the needs of people using the sea service. The Marine Board of Devonport warned that:

'If the revenue from the sea passenger service is removed from the Port of Devonport, its financial structure, which has been developed for the last 20 years around this type of interstate passenger and cargo service, will become unviable.
The loss of revenue of some $500,000 would mean a deficit operation for the port unless some other unexpected trade arose.'
The Committee concluded that the present arrangements, being satisfactory, ought to be continued.

In relation to the possibility that a second vessel might be brought on to the run, the Committee thought that Burnie had many desirable features, once again being a north-west coast port and therefore within two hours shorter steaming time from Melbourne than Bell Bay on the Tamar. Also, of course, it would allow passengers to disembark in the centre of a small north-west community rather than 50 kilometres from the main city, as would be the case with the Bell Bay- Launceston link.

I think it is very important, therefore, that the Government makes a clear and unequivocal commitment to the retention of Devonport as the sole or primary port for the replacement vessel or vessels, as the case may be, with Burnie being designated the second port for the service should a two-vessel replacement strategy be adopted. That commitment should be made known to the five prospective operators and their submissions and tenders for the service should be tailored accordingly. That is the way that the Committee of the Senate saw the matter. That is the way that the north-west and west coast communities see the matter. I strongly urge the Government to see the matter in the same light.

Finally, may I say that while it is gratifying to see that the Minister considers that discussions and consultations ought to take place with the two State governments concerned-that is, Victoria and Tasmania-and with the proponents of the replacement service, he neglects to mention the most important matter in the view of the Committee; namely, that the unions be consulted at the earliest possible opportunity so that disputes over manning levels do not impede the provision of a service which is perhaps more efficient in relation to manning levels but which also respects the legitimate employment aspirations of those involved in the maritime unions. Members of the Committee I am sure will recall hearings that we held in Melbourne, at which Mr Roger Wilson, the Acting Secretary of the Victorian Branch of the Seamen's Union of Australia and Mr Kenneth MacLeod, the Secretary of the Victorian Branch of the Federated Marine Stewards and Pantrymans Association of Australia, both indicated on behalf of their members their concern that these negotiations and consultations should embrace the unions at the earliest possible opportunity. That is the way to an industrially harmonious and effective agreement which will enable the replacement service to provide that fillip to Tasmania's tourist trade and, indeed, to the normal social intercourse of Tasmanians with the mainland which is so desired.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

speech.speaker: Sibraa Sen K.W.
