proctext.para: Report on Exotic Diseases Control

speech.speaker: Martin Sen K.J.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the paper.

This report is, according to a letter addressed to the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) by the Director of the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory, Mr R. W. Gee, a report describing the management of emergent exotic diseases in Australia and the role of the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory in dealing with them. The report is, in effect, a special plea by ANAHL for the opportunity to introduce into Australia a virus associated with certain exotic diseases. Of course the proposal which is exciting an amount of public attention at the moment is a proposal to introduce into Australia, for the ANAHL the foot and mouth disease virus. A great deal of concern has been expressed by a large number of primary producers in Australia about the possibility of this virus being introduced. Of course everyone is aware that, if there were ever an outbreak of foot and mouth disease in Australia, it would wipe out our beef export industry. That would have disasterous consequences for much of Australia but particularly for the northern half of Australia where the major part of our beef export industry is located. Without a doubt we would lose access overnight to nearly all of our overseas market. Therefore, it is understandable that the beef producers have indicated great concern at the possibility of the virus of foot and mouth disease being present in Australia.

This debate is one that will be pursued by scientists and by producers as well as by others. It should be noted that not all scientists are of the view of those who wrote this report. The report gives enthusiastic support to the importation of the virus by ANAHL and there is close argument through the report on why it is necessary to introduce the virus and why there is no risk, according to ANAHL in the introduction of the virus. However, as I have said, it is a special pleading. A number of scientists are of different opinions on the importance of the importation of the virus and the risks of importation. So the view expressed in this report is by no means the unanimous view of experts on the subject. It is clear from the letter to which I have referred, to the Minister from Mr Gee, that there was a request for this report to be written. It has been very valuable to have ANAHL write a report to the Minister and publically state its view on the issue. However, I would not like the report to be seen as having the status of the final expert document on the subject and the only recommendation that could be made to the Government on it. We have to treat it as only one point of view and we have to realise that it is written by those who have sought from the Government the opportunity to import the virus for experimentation, research and training.

I would not seek to denigrate the scientists who hold the point of view expressed in this report. I just have to say, as someone who is certainly not a scientist, that I am a little wary of scientists being advisers as well as being arbiters on a matter of such public moment as this. There has been considerable controversy in the last few days about radioactive mineral sands tailings in northern New South Wales and Queensland. I am aware that a couple of years ago it was thought to be a very good idea for keen gardeners to buy mineral sands tailings to topdress their lawns. I was told with full confidence by someone who was advising me on the top dressing of my lawn that this was the product to have . As it happened, thank goodness, I did not follow that advice because whilst I was assured at the time-I certainly did not ask whether it was radioactive; it did not cross my mind-that there was no problem in using this product, it was just good for lawn, the views that were held by scientists a few years ago on the safety of this product are now very close to being discredited.

I do not think the scientists should be discredited, but I think we should conclude from that experience that science is not always an exact science and that, when scientists give advice on whether something is safe, they give it in the light of the best knowledge that they have available to them. That knowledge may grow and expand as a result of either further research or the consequences of decisions that are taken and which can be shown to have been the result of wrong advice. We have to accept that scientists can make mistakes, that they are not infallible, and we should not flagellate them verbally or otherwise because they have made a mistake in the past in regard to advice they have given. However, scientists should also admit the fallibility of the science that they are pursuing. If they wish to seek the right to be kindly viewed as fallible when a mistake is discovered, they must also admit fallibility when they are giving advice.

I do not pick up in this report a suggestion that this is the best advice available on the evidence available; it is possible that there are risks. I have had put to me a view that there are risks involved in the importation of the live foot and mouth disease virus. I am aware that that view is held by eminent and respectable scientists, just as eminent and respectable scientists hold the contrary point of view. My hope is that this matter is some distance from resolution and that great caution will be exercised in proceeding with the debate before making a decision.

talk.start.para: —Do you know that a Senate committee has a determined reference?

—I am aware of that, Senator Tate, and I am very pleased that it has the reference. Without in any way denigrating Senate committees, I would say that it will bring a particular point of view to bear and that there will be still other points of view, as well. Nevertheless, I am sure that the submissions to the Senate committee in question will be in themselves valuable documents in the general debate.

speech.speaker: Townley Sen M.

talk.start.para: —The importation of foot and mouth virus worried me when I first heard about it. As a scientist-one of the few scientists in this Parliament-I think I should briefly say a few things about it. Following the worry that I originally had about this matter, I sought quite specialised advice from people who unfortunately have to remain nameless at this stage. They told me they would give me information provided I did not mention their names. I asssure the Senate that they hold quite eminent positions in this country. They pointed out to me that foot and mouth disease concerns not just one virus; in fact, upwards of 60 different viruses are classified as foot and mouth disease, and many other diseases in cattle may be just as dangerous. Of course the report of the Australian National Animal Health Laboratory does point to some of those.

speech.para: The information that I was given was that Australia has been extremely fortunate in not having had foot and mouth disease imported already. I believe there was one outbreak, many years ago. The person I talked to, who was very knowledgeable in this matter, said it was quite remarkable that, for one reason or another, one of the viruses had not come into this country and we have not had to adopt a process of slaughtering animals or isolating them, or of undertaking a vaccination program.

talk.start.para: —It is a tribute to the quarantine service.

—I do not think that it is necessarily a tribute to the quarantine service. I think it has been lucky. The country has been lucky. Whereas I was originally opposed to the importation of these viruses, I now am not. I have yet to visit the laboratory in Geelong but I have asked to accompany the Senate Standing Committee on National Resources when it goes there. I have been informed that it is of world class, if not the best in the world. It has a means of making sure that the viruses do not escape. Although there can always be human error, I think the risk of human error at a place like the laboratory in Geelong would be much less than the risk Australia presently faces from importation by accident, in spite of the groups that try to keep these viruses out of the country. The risk is higher from that point of view than it is from loss or leakage of the virus from the laboratory. Of course, one can always say in a situation such as this that the risk is increased by having the virus in the country. If that risk is very small, I think it is something with which we can live. Whilst we will have some argument among the different scientists, I believe that argument has to be taken with due regard to the reason people do not want the virus to come in. I believe that for some reasons some people have a vested interest in not having the virus here. I hope that when the Senate committee deals with this matter it will keep that kind of thing in mind. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

speech.para: Leave granted; debate adjourned.

proctext.para: Report on Australian Citizenship Act 1948

speech.speaker: Tate Sen M.C.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the paper.

The report of the Human Rights Commission on the Australian Citizenship Act unfortunately has been in the hands of honourable senators for less than an hour . I have not been able to review it as comprehensively as I would like. Nevertheless, the report represents an important fulfilment of one of the functions of the Human Rights Commission as set out in its enabling Act; namely, that it examine enactments for the purpose of ascertaining whether the enactments are inconsistent with or contrary to any human rights and to report to the Minister concerned the results of any such examination. I still have not had given to me any accompanying statement by the Minister concerned in relation to this report. However, the report is an indication of the type of work which will be undertaken by the Human Rights Commission, given the fact that it was not invested with many of the important powers which many honourable senators in this chamber thought it ought to be invested with to give it real teeth.

In the review of the Citizenship Act-taking as the basis for the review the understanding that citizenship is one of the fundamental elements in the life of a nation and the Citizenship Act itself has an important bearing on everyone's civil and political rights-the Commission examined five or six aspects of that Act. In the short time that is available to me I wish to look at the section which deals with the oath of allegiance. What is required as part of the ceremony when a person takes out Australian citizenship is the renunciation of all other allegiance. To my mind the Human Rights Commission does not see the point that that part of the ceremony has a very severe impact on persons who are of dual nationality within our country. What the Commission said in relation to that renunciation is quite correct; namely, that it is totally ineffectual and only symbolic to renounce one's allegiance to the former homeland, the home of one's first nationality. It is ineffectual because if that homeland does not recognise in its legal system that act of renunciation in Australia the new Australian citizen carries with him the nationality of his or her former homeland. At paragraph 30 of the report the Commission states:

Many countries from which Australia derives its immigrants allow their citizens to accept the citizenship of a second country without depriving them of the citizenship of the first country, e.g. British, Greek and Lebanese citizens do not lose that citizenship when taking out Australian citizenship. In those cases , the first citizenship would normally only be lost by a formal act of renunciation. Simply taking an oath which includes renunciation of former allegiance would not amount to such a formal act. Therefore, the renunciation clause itself has no legal effect in the first country.

There is no perception whatsoever in that statement of the fact that if the renunciation is not regarded as effective in the former homeland the new Australian citizen loses the right to the protection of the Australian Government when he or she returns to that former homeland. Therefore, a very serious situation exists in which citizens of Australia travelling abroad who pass through or wish to visit their former homeland are put in a very severe predicament whereby they can be subjected to the laws of that former homeland and have no protection from the Australian consular offices. I have pointed this out during several debates in this chamber. On 29 March 1979 I moved a motion in the following terms:

That the Senate notes with concern the lack of action by the Australian Government to relieve Australian citizens of the disadvantages of dual nationality, particularly as experienced in visiting former homelands, and urges the Government speedily to implement the recommendations contained in the Report of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence on Dual Nationality, tabled in the Senate on 14 October 1976.
An article in the Age of 2 August stated:

A month ago an Australian man who had emigrated from Italy at the age of nine revisited the land of his birth. He was detained there and told he was liable for military service; only after some diplomatic to-ing and fro-ing was he spared conscription.

One recalls that several years ago-I think it was about 1975-the Yugoslav Government refused to allow Australian diplomats access to Australian citizens held in detention for several months. The Yugoslav Government even executed Australian citizens who held Yugoslav nationality. It did so without informing the Australian Government. That is extremely disturbing. This matter was not addressed by the Human Rights Commission in its report. The matter is of grave concern to the various ethnic communities. In fact, one of their leaders, Professor Athanasius Laouvaris, who edits the monthly ethnic affairs journal The New Austral Times-I commend it to honourable senators-said recently that the Federal Government was deliberately pushing the whole issue of dual nationality under the carpet. Professor Louvaris is a most distinguished scholar. He is a very energetic member of the Australian community. Through various publications he attempts to put the point of view of the ethnic communities in relation to this matter, as does Mr Alan Taskunas, who is a senior administrator at the University of Tasmania. Mr Taskunas pointed out in a recent article in The New Austral Times the situation which prevails; it is as I have described it.

The fact is that the Government seems to be taking the attitude that nothing can be done. Yet the fact is that those are models available to us, whether within the European Economic Community or among the Warsaw Pact countries, of arrangements, agreements and formal treaties between governments which require that the government of the former homeland renounce claims that a person is a national of that former homeland should he move to another country and establish residence there. Even more so should that be the case when a person obtains citizenship in a country of settlement and renounces his former allegiance and nationality. That ought to be regarded as effective in international law. It is something to which I hope this Goverment will give attention. As I say, I am disappointed that the Human Rights Commission did not advert to this extremely important aspect of the ineffectual nature of the renunciation clause in the oath of allegiance. I hope the matter will be taken up and acted upon in accordance with the wishes of those in many ethnic communities in our country.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

proctext.para: Withdrawal of Notice of Motion

speech.speaker: Evans Sen G.J.

talk.start.para: —by leave-I withdraw General Business Notice of Motion No. 69 standing in my name.

speech.para: INCOME TAX ASSESSMENT AMENDMENT BILL (No. 5) 1982 [No. 2]
Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.
Second Reading

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
This Bill will amend the income tax law in a number of respects, primarily to give effect to a number of the Government's Budget proposals.

Included in the Bill are the measures necessary to allow a rebate of tax on up to $1000 of certain dividends, to increase the sole parent rebate and the rebate for a spouse, daughter-housekeeper or housekeeper where there is a dependent child or student and to introduce a rebate of tax for those in receipt of taxable Australian social security and repatriation pensions.

The Bill will also reflect the announced reduction in the standard rate of personal tax from 32 per cent to 30 per cent from 1 November 1982 by making consequential adjustments such as to the rate used to calculate various rebates.

Other Budget measures given effect by the Bill include a new rebate of tax for home buyers for the top slice of their interest payments on home loans of up to $60,000, together with a further easing of the dividend distribution requirements for private companies.

It also contains provisions to exempt from tax the rehabilitation allowance payable from 1 March 1983 to persons under treatment or training with the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service and to authorise income tax deductions for gifts of $2 or more made to certain public funds and organisations.
The calculation of provisional tax for the 1982-83 year of income is also provided for.
Dependant Rebates

As announced in the Budget Speech, the rebate for a dependent spouse and the rebate available for a daughter-housekeeper or a housekeeper are to be increased by $200-from $830 to $1030-where there are dependent (including student) children.

The increased rebate will be available to a taxpayer who would have been entitled to a dependant rebate in respect of a child under 16 years of age or a student less than 25 years of age but for the replacement of such rebates by family allowances.
The sole parent rebate will also be increased by $200 from $580 to $780.
Because the increased rebates are to apply from 1 November 1982, the increases for the 1982-83 income year will be $133-representing two-thirds of the full year increase of $200.
As zone rebates are partly based on dependant rebates, entitlement to an increased dependant rebate will mean a higher zone rebate.
These measures will provide additional help to single income families with dependant children-particularly when combined with other personal income tax reductions which I will mention shortly.
Rebate for Pensioners
Another budget decision to be implemented by this Bill is the introduction of a special pensioner rebate for income tax purposes.

The rebate, together with the increase in the tax-free threshold to $4,595 to be effected by the Income Tax (Rates) Bill 1982 that will be introduced shortly, will ensure that persons wholly or mainly dependent on a taxable social security or repatriation pension do not bear tax.

More specifically, the maximum rebate of $167 for 1982-83 (reflecting a 1 November 1982 commencement date for this concession) and $250 in subsequent years will mean that no tax will be payable on taxable incomes of up to $5,007 for 1982-83 and up to $5,429 in subsequent years.

The rebate will shade out above these income levels, but the shading arrangements will result in some rebate being available where taxable income exceeds the above levels but is less than $6,343 in 1982-83 and $7,429 in subsequent years.
Home Loan Interest Rebate
Honourable senators will recall that on 18 March 1982 the Treasurer made a statement in another place following a detailed review by the Government of housing policy.

In that statement he made it clear that the Government is committed to preserving the highest practicable level of private home ownership in Australia and announced a tax rebate for home loan interest to alleviate the burden of housing mortgage payments.
The rebate is available from 1 July 1982 to individuals in the first five years of owner-occupancy of a sole or principal residence in Australia.
As further evidence of the Government's concern the Treasurer announced in the Budget Speech an alternative rebate of tax for interest payments made on or after 1 July 1982.
The existing rebate will continue to be available and can be used by eligible taxpayers where it offers a larger rebate than the new scheme does in a particular year of income.

The new rebate, which is authorised by this Bill, is to be available to an individual taxpayer resident in Australia in respect of interest paid in a year of income that is attributable to such part of the interest rate as exceeds 10 per cent per annum, calculated on a reducing balance basis. In respect of the first $60,000 of a loan or loans on a dwelling.
Unlike the existing rebate scheme the new rebate will not be restricted to the first years of home ownership or by specified upper limits of rebate.
The rebate will be at the standard rate of tax and will not exceed the tax otherwise payable on assessment.
The rebate is to be allowed on interest paid to the extent to which the interest exceeds 10 per cent per annum of the average balance of a home loan in a year of income.

Adjustments may be made to the amount calculated as the averaage loan balance to account for unusual or additional repayments during a year or for increases in the balance of the loan at a particular time in the year.

The proposal to limit the rebate to the first $60,000 of a loan or loans on a dwelling will result in the amount otherwise subject to rebate in a year of income being reduced proportionately if the balance of the moneys owing on the home exceed $60,000 at the end of the year of income.

Interest will be within the scheme if it is paid on moneys lent to a taxpayer and applied for certain specified purposes connected with a dwelling used by the taxpayer as his or her sole or principal residence.
Those purposes include the acquisition of land on which a dwelling is subsequently constructed, the construction of a dwelling or the acquisition of land on which there is already a dwelling.
Interest on moneys used to extend a dwelling may also qualify.

Where moneys are borrowed partly for the purpose of acquiring or constructing a dwelling and partly for other purposes, so much only of the interest as is attributable to the part of the moneys applied to acquire or construct the dwelling will qualify for the rebate. Moneys borrowed on the security of a dwelling will not qualify unless they are expended for a qualifying purpose.
Interest payments that attract income tax deductions under ordinary rules will continue to be deductible and will not attract the rebate.
A taxpayer who is entitled to a rebate under either the new scheme or the existing home loan interest rebate scheme will be able to elect to transfer that benefit to his or her spouse.

The rebate is to be incorporated in the PAYE tax instalment deduction scheme as from 1 November 1982. Taxpayers taking advantage of the rebate by this method will be required to complete a declaration form and lodge it with their employers.
Dividend Rebate

In the Budget Speech the Treasurer announced that the Government had decided to allow a rebate at the standard rate of tax on up to $1,000 of dividends, included in taxable income, that are received by resident individuals from resident companies.

The rebate will not apply to dividends paid by co-operative companies that are accorded special income tax treatment, dividends that are taxed at special higher rates of tax and certain amounts that are deemed to be dividends for limited income tax purposes.
Since the earlier announcement, it has been decided that the rebate should be extended to dividends paid by the limited number of foreign companies that are listed on Australian stock exchanges.
This Bill will give effect to these decisions.
The new rebate will first apply in income tax assessments for the 1982-83 year of income.
This measure will provide some relief from what some see as the double taxation of dividend income, while at the same time giving encourgement to small investors.
Retention Allowance of Private Companies
The Bill also gives effect to the Budget proposal to further ease the dividend distribution requirements for private companies under division 7 of the Income Tax Assessment Act.
It is proposed to increase-from 70 per cent to 80 per cent-the proportion of after-tax business income that a company may retain without becoming liable to pay the undistributed profits tax.

This measure will further assist small businesses in maintaining adequate working capital and mean that this Government has increased the retention allowance from 50 per cent to 80 per cent since it came to office.
Private companies will benefit from the increased retention allowance in respect of income of the 1981-82 and subsequent income years.

It is not proposed to vary the 10 per cent retention allowance for property income or the rule that dividends received by one private company from another must be distributed in full if undistributed profits tax is to be avoided.
Gifts
The gift provisions of the income tax law allow deductions for gifts of the value of $2 or more to specified funds, authorities and institutions.
Details of each of the proposed extensions of this concession have been the subject of previous statements and I need mention them only briefly now.

One extension will authorise deductions for gifts made during the 1981-82 and 1982-83 financial years to a public fund established and maintained exclusively for the relief of civilian victims of the conflict in Lebanon.
Another will authorise deductions for gifts made after 17 August 1982 to the United Nations Association of Australia Decade of Trees Greening Australia and to a range of conservation organisations.
Details of this particular proposal, including the names of the eligible organisations, were announced in a statement of 17 August 1982 by the Treasurer.
Since that announcement the Government has decided that the concession should extend to a further conservation body-the National Parks Foundation of South Australia.

The final amendment to the gift provisions proposed by the Bill will authorise deductions for gifts made after 26 August 1982 to the Centre for Independent Studies, the Playford Memorial Trust, the Boy Scouts and Girl Guides Associations in Australia and Amnesty International in Australia.
Rehabilitation Allowance

Honourable senators will recall the announcement of Budget night that, from the first pension payday in March 1983, persons undergoing treatment or training with the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service who would otherwise be eligible for a social security pension or benefit will be eligible to receive a non-taxable rehabilitation allowance.
The allowance will be equivalent to the invalid pension and subject to the same income test conditions of eligibility as the invalid pension.
Legislation providing for the payment of the new allowance was introduced into the Parliament on 23 September 1982.

Under the existing income tax law, the tax treatment of allowances received by persons undergoing treatment or training with the Commonwealth Rehabilitation Service depends upon whether the pension or benefit to which the allowance relates is subject to tax.

This Bill, by ensuring that the new rehabilitation allowance and associated training and living away from home allowances are exempt from tax, will introduce uniformity of tax treatment for all persons under treatment or training with the service.

The Bill also makes a number of consequential amendments so that no taxpayer will be disadvantaged as a result of a person, who would otherwise be eligible to receive an invalid pension, becoming instead eligible to receive a rehabilitation allowance.
The amendments will apply in relation to payments made on or after 1 March 1983 .
Consequential Amendments

As a consequence of the reduction in the standard rate of tax from 32 per cent to 30 per cent from 1 November 1982, the Bill provides for the adjustment of the rate at which various rebates are allowable, the rate of tax on certain lump sum payments and the rate of withholding tax on mining payments made to Aboriginal groups.
The rebates in question are the general concessional rebate, the health insurance rebate and the existing home loan interest rebate.
These rebates will be allowed at the rate of 30.67 per cent for 1982-83 and 30 per cent in subsequent years.

The rate of tax on certain lump sum payments for accrued annual and/or long service leave made on retirement or termination of employment similarly will be limited to 30.67 per cent for 1982-83 and 30 per cent for subsequent years.

The rate of withholding tax on mining payments made to Aboriginal groups on or after 1 November 1982 will be reduced from 6.4 per cent to 6 per cent- representing tax at the new standard rate of 30 per cent on one-fifth of the gross payments.
Provisional Tax

As provisional tax is part of the broad pay-as-you-earn system and is designed to collect tax on incomes consisting of or including non-salary or wage incomes within the year in which it was derived, it is generally accepted as reasonable that the amount charged should approximate as closely as practicable the amount of tax actually imposed for the year.
This achieves a desirable measure of consistency with the treatment of salary or wage earners.

Incomes for 1982-83 are expected to be higher than for 1981-82 and, of course, due to the changes to the personal income tax rate scale, effective rates of tax for 1982-83 will be lower than for last year.
Accordingly, as in past years, it is proposed to vary the basis of calculating provisional tax for 1982-83 to be notified in assessment notices to issue this year.

The Bill thus provides for 1982-83 provisional tax to be calculated on the basis of 1981-82 taxable income as increased by 10 per cent and applying to the adjusted amount the lower rates of tax to apply for 1982-83.
Generally, rebates allowed in 1981-82 will be taken into account in the calculation.

However, where it appears from the information available in the taxpayer's 1981 -82 return of income that he or she will be entitled in 1982-83 to an increased spouse, daughter-housekeeper, housekeeper or sole parent rebate, the relevant rebates (including zone rebates where appropriate) allowable in 1981-82 will be increased accordingly.

The new dividend and pensioner rebates will also be taken into account in the 1982-83 provisional tax calculation where it appears, from the information available in the taxpayer's 1981-82 return of income, that he or she will be entitled to one or both of these rebates.

It is, of course, open to taxpayers who consider that their taxable income for 1982-83 will increase by less than the notional 10 per cent, or who consider that sufficient rebates have not been taken into account, to 'self-assess' and have the provision tax for 1982-83 recalculated on the basis of their own estimates.
Formal Amendments

Finally, the Bill makes a number of formal amendments to the Income Tax Assessment Act necessitated by the change in title of, and other formal amendments to, the Social Services Act 1947 made recently by the Social Services Legislation Amendment Act 1982.
A memorandum explaining in some detail the technical aspects of this Bill has been made available to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —I mention that it is the Government's intention to move, in the Committee stage of the debate, an amendment to paragraph (a) of sub-clause 5 (1) of the Bill which proposes to provide income tax deductions for gifts to a public fund established and maintained exclusively for the relief of the civilian victims of the conflict in Lebanon. By the amendment, the circumstances giving rise to the deductions will be described in a more general way so as to remove any unintended impression of views of a judgmental kind in relation to the sufferings of the people in Lebanon to whose relief the tax deductible gifts are to be channelled. The amendment will not alter the scope of the measure as introduced in the Bill.

speech.para: Debate (on motion by Senator Sibraa) adjourned.

proctext.para: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Ordered that the Bill may be taken through all its stages without delay.
Bill (on motion by Senator Messner) read a first time.

speech.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

This Bill will declare the rates of tax payable by individuals and trustees- other than trustees of corporate unit trusts and superannuation funds-for the 1982-83 financial year and for the 1983-84 and subsequent financial years.

In declaring these rates, the Bill will implement the Budget proposals to alter the personal income tax rate scale and to withdraw the benefit of the tax-free threshold from non-resident taxpayers generally.

Honourable senators will recall that in the Budget Speech the Treasurer announced that, with effect from 1 November 1982, the personal income tax burden would be substantially reduced by increasing the tax-free threshold from $4,195 to $4,595, by reducing the standard rate of tax from 32 to 30 per cent and by increasing the top of the standard rate step in the rate scale from $17,894 to $ 19,500.
These measures will provide the largest proportionate tax reductions to persons on low to average incomes.
When taken with other Budget decisions, they will be of particular significance to families and those wholly or mainly dependent on pensions.
The increase in the top of the standard rate step will provide incentive to earn additional income without fear of moving into a higher tax bracket.
The changes will apply from 1 November 1982 and will be reflected in lower pay- as-you-earn deductions from that date.

Also reflecting that commencement date, the rate scale for 1982-83 is to be an average of the 1981-82 rate scale and that to apply from 1 November 1982-made up of four-twelfths of the 1981-82 scale and eight-twelfths of the new scale.
Application of this average scale will mean that for 1982-83 tax will not be payable by resident individuals until taxable income exceeds $4,462.
The corresponding taxable income level last year was $4,195.

The average scale will also mean that, up to a taxable income of $17,894 for 1982-83, the rate of tax payable will be 30.67 per cent-compared with 32 per cent last year-while for taxable incomes in the range of $17,894 to $19,500 the rate of tax applicable to the excess over $17,894 will be 35.33 per cent- compared with 46 per cent last year.

The rates of tax declared by the Bill for 1983-84 and subsequent years give full effect to the reduction of the standard rate to 30 per cent and the increases in the top of the zero rate and standard rate steps to $4,595 and $19, 500 respectively.

As also announced in the Budget Speech, the zero rate step in the rate scale ( or tax-free threshold) is no longer to be available to non-residents, other than those in receipt of taxable Australian social security and repatriation pensions .

There is no tax-free amount available in respect of income such as dividends and interest received by non-residents-this income is subject to withholding tax -and the reasons for extending the threshold to residents are seldom relevant to non-residents.

The Bill will withdraw the threshold from non-residents with effect from 17 August 1982 (Budget day), except in relation to those non-residents who came to Australia on or before that date for a short working visit or who had made firm arrangements for such a visit by that date.
Reflecting the date of effect of the withdrawal, a proportionate threshold of $ 585 will be available for 1982-83.

Consistent with the withdrawal of the tax-free threshold, the minimum taxable income levels presently applying to accumulating income of some non-resident trust estates and to certain income of non-resident minor children are also to be withdrawn from 17 August 1982, with proportionate amounts applying for 1982- 83.
The provisions of the Bill are explained in detail in a memorandum that has been made available to honourable senators.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

talk.start.para: —In speaking to the first readings of the customs tariff Bills I want to raise a matter which has caused me grave concern over the last three years, and that is the way that South Australia has been managed under the Tonkin Liberal Government. The LCL-the Liberal Country League- had a very long reign in government until there was a parting of the ways and a bustup, as has often been the case. Now the LCL has one Country Party member in the House of Assembly. I think he still calls himself a Country Party member. However, I understand that after the election that party in South Australia will change its name to the National Party. It changes its suits according to the weather. The LCL remained in government for a long period because we had what was known in the State as the 'Playmander'. The electorates were very much rigged in favour of the LCL.

speech.para: Despite the fact that the Labor Party at election after election got a majority of the votes, it could not get a majority of members in the House of Assembly to form a government. However, in 1965 the Labor Party, under the leadership of the late Mr Frank Walsh broke through the barrier and was elected to government. We were defeated in 1968. The Leader of the Liberal Party, Mr Hall, had a very short sojourn as government leader-two years as a matter of fact-before he was defeated. There was another split in the Liberal Party in South Australia after he was defeated and that led to the formation of what is known as the Liberal Movement. I notice that you, Madame Acting Deputy President, were a member of that party when you came into this place by appointment of the Dunstan Liberal Government. But then you changed your political colours and joined what is now known as the Australian Democrats.

talk.start.para: —I presume you meant the Dunstan Labor Government.
—It was the Dunstan Government that put you here.
—But you said the Dunstan Liberal Government.

—I meant the Dunstan Labor Government. I do not think that anyone would ever pick me up on that slip of the tongue because Dunstan would never be a leader of the Liberal Party. However, we find that in the turmoils of politics the Democrats party in South Australia is now facing another tremendous split. I think because of that split the Democrats can kiss goodbye to the seat of Mitcham on 6 November, and that is very good news for the Liberal Party because that is one seat which it will get back. Mitcham was always a Liberal seat until Robin Millhouse bailed out. Of course, he was a member of the Liberal Movement as you were, Madam Acting Deputy President. Many other people who are now Government members were members of the Liberal Movement.

speech.para: I am giving the Senate a little history about how the politics change with all the parties in South Australia which are vehemently opposed to the Labor Party. Our Party is intact. We do not have these internal squabbles.

talk.start.para: —Ha, ha!

—Senator Baume can laugh but he might be able to explain to me where there have been any problems in the South Australian Labor Party. He cannot point to any. We are a very united party and we will continue to be. However, after we were defeated in 1968 Mr Hall became the premier. We were returned to government as a result of all the turmoil in 1970. We managed the State very successfully until 1979 when we saw one of the most scurrilous political campaigns ever conducted in South Australia. I am very worried that we will see the same sort of thing happen again.

speech.para: My Leader, Senator Button, had to rise in the chamber today and seek leave to make a statement about the commencement of this scurrilous attack which is conducted by the Adelaide News, a paper in the stable of Murdoch who has never been a friend of the Labor Party in South Australia. That paper published an article with the headline 'Threat to pension, dole rises'. This matter has been explained. However, newspapers containing that article appeared on the news stands in Adelaide on Wednesday of this week despite the fact that the social security legislation had been passed through this House at 24 minutes past 5 the previous evening. This is the sort of scandalous attack we are going to be faced with during the election campaign.

But who else has surfaced and come out of the woodwork like a white ant-none other than Nigel Buick of Kingscote, Kangaroo Island, that bloke who was famous for all of the big full page advertisements in both the Adelaide News and the Advertiser prior to the 1979 elections. I do not know from where he gets the money to pay for these advertisements. However, one of these advertisements appeared on Tuesday signed by Nigel Buick of Kingscote. I do not know what sort of payoff he got from Tonkin after he helped him to be elected. But we will be very interested to have a look at this when we get back into government.

talk.start.para: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to the Standing Orders. The honourable senator talked about a payoff being received from Mr Tonkin. I believe that is making an imputation which is contrary to the Standing Orders.
—Senator McLaren, I ask you to withdraw.

—Well, Madam Acting Deputy President, I said that I did not know what sort of payoff there was. I did not make any accusation that there was. But if what I said is offensive to Senator Baume I will withdraw it. I know that he is very touchy about what is happening in South Australia, and well he might be. We are going to be in government in that State after 6 November.
—Is that an unconditional withdrawal?

—Of course it is. If Senator Baume wants it withdrawn I will withdraw it. I thought I did. Worse things than that have been said in this Parliament and I have not asked for them to be withdrawn. But I know, as I have said, that Senator Baume is very touchy on these issues. It is probably the ad to which I have drawn attention which offends him, and well it might because it offends a lot of other people. However, this sort of thing will not help the Tonkin Government to get back into office on 6 November because people had enough of it during the 1979 elections. They have been fed up to the back teeth since.

speech.para: All sorts of outrageous statements were made in these scurrilous ads, some of which were signed by 'concerned electors'. Some of these people did not even live in South Australia. What I wanted to say when Senator Baume interposed was that after 6 November we will be having a look at some of the patronage that has been paid out to these sort of people. We will soon take it away from them. I give a warning that these people who have been used as stooges ought to be prepared after 6 November because they will get no truck from the Labor Government. We believe in honesty in government; we believe in a fair deal for the people who live in South Australia.

The advertisement to which I have referred and which is authorised by Nigel Buick appeared in the News of 19 October. However, on 15 October the News ran an editorial headed 'And so to the polls'. The editorial stated:
There should be no place in this campaign for distorted statistics conveying to outsiders the impression of a bankrupt, hopeless South Australia.
Even less is there a place for the nasty smear politics which disgrace so many Australian elections.

Could there be any more smearing than what we saw on the front page story of the News of yesterday? What could be more smearing by the very paper which saw fit to run that sanctimonious article asking the political parties not to indulge in smear techniques which that paper itself had triggered off? Of course, the paper accepted the ad from Nigel Buick. I suppose his money is good. I do not know what it costs to put a full page ad in the News-I imagine it would be somewhere in the vicinity of $1,500; it would not be much less.

talk.start.para: —Not much if you get a lot of fishing licences.

—I am very pleased that Senator Grimes said that. That is one of the things that we will be looking at after 6 November. People will get fishing licences on their merits and not for being party stooges. I am very proud of the State that I represent. I was reported in the daily Press today as being parochial. I make no apologies for that. I was sent here by the electors of South Australia to represent them. I have done my very best to do that in the eleven and a half years I have been in this place. I will continue to do it while I am here. I believe that the people of South Australia are decent, honest citizens. They need a government that will govern them in a way that will do justice to their living standards and to every other form of quality of life which they expect from South Australia. They have not been getting that sort of government in the last three years, unfortunately. The Government which is now in charge of South Australia's affairs was elected on one of its pledges to stop the job rot. I have had to give notice in this House of 11 motions to point up the chaos that the State is in and the financial situation it now faces. Every one of those notices of motion was based on absolute statistics which I got from the documents published by the Australian Bureau of Statistics. They are not a figment of the imagination; they are absolute fact and I stand by them. I have no reason to doubt what the ABS prints. I take cognisance of the fact that nobody on the Government side has seen fit to bring on those motions since I put them on the Notice Paper. I put the first one on the Notice Paper on 19 November 1981, nearly 12 months ago.
—We had one.

—We might have debated one. But the South Australian Government members could have made moves to bring on all the others. Of course, they did not have anything to argue about. They knew that the figures I put down were correct. I would have welcomed a debate on them. I now look forward to the first Wednesday that the Senate sits after the South Australian election. I will be able to move for the notices of motion to be taken off the Notice Paper because the State will be back in good secure hands under the leadership of John Bannon. Then we can get on with the job of governing the State the way it ought to be governed, the way in which Mr Tonkin said it would be governed in his election policy speech of 1979. Yesterday I mentioned that Mr Tonkin was not too happy with his Federal Liberal Party members and the way they were not assisting him. Senator Teague took umbrage at those remarks. He got quite uptight about them. I was only quoting from Mr Tonkin's policy speech. That is what he said.
—He did not say that.

—He said that he would have a representative in Canberra to engage in closer relationships with Ministers. What else could be inferred from a statement like that in a Premier's policy speech? Nothing could be inferred other than the fact that he was not getting any worthwhile assistance from the Federal members of Parliament who represent the Liberal Party in South Australia . If they were doing their job as the Labor Party members do he would not need to waste the South Australian taxpayers' money by domiciling a representative in Canberra to act as a lobbyist to the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser), Ministers, statutory bodies and their senior officials, as he said he would do in his policy speech. Nothing can be construed from that statement except that he is not getting the co-operation of the people that the Liberal Party sent here. I would think that next time we have a Federal election there will be a few faces missing in this place. The Liberal Party will have to send people it can rely on. It will not be any hassle for Mr Tonkin as he will no longer be the leader of the Government in South Australia; we will be in office.

speech.para: I want to say a few words about some of the things that have happened and some of the things that have been said in the last three years. I will quote briefly from the Advertiser of 3 August 1979-that was prior to the election in September . Mr Tonkin was very outspoken in his criticism of the then Corcoran Labor Government. There is a black headline in the Adelaide Advertiser of 3 August 1979. It reads: 'Population rise lowest-Tonkin'. The article states:
South Australia's population growth rate was the lowest in the State's history, the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Tonkin, told the Assembly yesterday.

That is what he said over three years ago. What is the population in South Australia now? South Australia is in a terrible position in that its population is the lowest of any State on the mainland. Mr Tonkin has presided over that situation. He is a man who, for political purposes, proposed to criticise the Corcoran Labor Government. But what has he done about the problem in three years ? I think he also said during the 1979 campaign that the electors of South Australia were voting with their feet. Well, they are voting with their feet at a much faster rate since he took over the reins of government. Now, our population figures are lower than those of Western Australia. Not only are members of the work force having to leave the State in an endeavour to get jobs but also businesses have left the State at a rapid rate. In the last 12 months not a week has gone by in which we did not pick up a newspaper and find out that businesses were closing down or that people were being put on short time. My colleague Senator Foreman has been raising the matter of Kelvinator Australia Ltd in the Parliament for quite some time. But what answers are we getting from the Government? We are getting nothing at all because it is not prepared to come out and make a statement as to what will happen to the 400 workers at Kelvinator .

We also have a problem in the south-east of the State of which Mr Tonkin should have been aware. In September 1981 a statement appeared in the Australian Forest Industries Journal. It stated that the timber industry in South Australia was still in a depressed state. Mr Tonkin was forewarned about it. It is in a worse plight now because the south-east of South Australia, particularly the Mount Gambier area, has the highest unemployment level of any area in the State. What is Mr Tonkin doing about it? He is doing absolutely nothing. After the Labor Party had to make moves, we found that he got off his whatever one likes to call it and sent a telex to Mr Fraser saying that Mr Fraser ought to do something.

On Tuesday I had the privilege of sitting in on an anti-dumping inquiry. The New Zealand contingent was there in force. It supported the import of softwood timber into Australia from New Zealand, and so did the importers. I hope that in the final washup some common sense will prevail and that the inquiry will actually prove that the import of cheap New Zealand timber is doing great harm to the people who live in the south-east. I am quite certain that after 6 November, when Mr Ken Bonython takes over the seat of Mount Gambier, we will have a strong voice in the South Australian Parliament to look after the interests of people in the Mount Gambier, Tantanoola, Nangwarry and Tarpeena areas. After 6 November South Australia can look forward to an uplift in its standard of living. That is something about which I will be joyous. It will be a sad day for everyone in South Australia if the Labor Party does not win the election on 6 November.

speech.speaker: Hill Sen R.

talk.start.para: —I wish in this first reading debate to speak on the second United Nations Special Session on Disarmament, which I had the privilege to attend for a few days, and Australia's contribution to that Session and disarmament in general. A discussion of that Session might logically start with the first UNSSOD I, which was held four years previously. At that conference the international community accepted certain basic principles which it embodied in its final document. This document has become part of the bible of disarmament. It accepted that it was unreal to discuss disarmament without accepting the legitimate object of security on the part of each state. Security, of course, has been traditionally thought of in terms of more and better quality armaments. However, it was then recognised that the accumulation of weapons, particularly nuclear weapons, constituted much more a threat than a protection to the future of mankind. This was well put by Lord Louis Mountbatten in 1979. He, of course, was a victim of the intolerance and violence of man. He said:

speech.para: Wars cannot be fought with nuclear weapons. Their existence only adds to our perils because of the illusion they have created.

I pause to remind the Senate that the UN recently estimated that there are more than 40,000 nuclear warheads in the world today. Their total explosive strength makes them equivalent to about one million Hiroshima bombs or 30 tonnes of trinitrotoluene for every man, woman and child on earth.
Also, in that final document, the international community accepted the relationship between expenditure on armaments and economic and social development, or the lack thereof. It stated:

. . . the economic and social consequences of the arms race are so detrimental that its continuation is obviously incompatible with the implementation of the new international economic order based on justice, equity and co-operation.
Thus the ultimate goal, it concluded, should be general and complete disarmament under effective international control. Certain priorities were agreed, including :
Halting and reversing the nuclear arms race
Preventing the proliferation of nuclear weapons
Developing and improving measures to prevent the outbreak of nuclear war
Prohibiting or preventing the development, production or use of other weapons of mass destruction
A balanced reduction of armed forces and of conventional armaments

A program of action was determined and the Committee on Disarmament was set up. It was to have the major role in negotiating the implementation of that plan of action during the following four years until UNSSOD II. Australia was selected as a member of that Committee. A brief look at the progress of the Committee gives some indication of the progress of multinational disarmament during that period of four years.

The Committee reported to UNSSOD II that its work towards a nuclear test ban treaty had continued but had not been satisfactorily concluded; that its work towards cessation of the nuclear arms race and nuclear disarmament had similarly continued but an agreed basis for negotiations in the Committee had not been found. It said that fundamental differences over such strategic doctrines as 'no first use' had meant that little progress had been made in this area. The Committee had continued to look for an effective international agreement to assure non-nuclear states against the use, or threat of the use, of nuclear weapons. Again, it had not been able to reach agreement.

In the area of chemical weapons, the Committee had been heading towards the objective of developing a convention and had made some progress. On the subject of new types of weapons of mass destruction, which are being referred to these days as radiological weapons, the Committee said that it had, similarly, been making some progress. In relation to the task of preparing a Comprehensive Program of Disarmament it had achieved, by UNSSOD II, a draft, although heavily bracketted, to be considered by the Special Session. It had looked to and made some progress in other areas such as the prevention of the arms race in outer space.

Thus the progress made by the Committee in the last four years could at best be described as modest. Unfortunately, it fell foul of the international climate. As was said in the report of the Australian delegation to the 1981 session of the Committee on Disarmament:
The main impediments to the Committee achieving quicker and more tangible results do not lie in the Committee's own procedures or composition but in the general international climate.

Of course, the timing of UNSSOD II in many ways could not have been worse. I refer to the Falklands war, and to the Iran-Iraq war, and to the war in the Lebanon. The United Nations General Assembly President, Ismait T. Kittani of Iraq, put the failure in perspective when he noted that the session had taken place, 'during one of the most disturbing junctures in international relations'. He correctly surmised that it would be an illusion to expect the United Nations to insulate itself from the general climate and relations among states-where mistrust, conflict, a growing sense of insecurity and resort to force continued to prevail-and to produce miracles.

UNSSOD II met for five weeks during June and July of this year but, regrettably , the Special Session was largely a failure. It was unable to adopt a document on a Comprehensive Program of Disarmament prepared by its first working group. It was not even able to agree upon a statement concerning the progress made since 1978, which was the function of its second working group. However, it was able to agree upon a world disarmament campaign and the granting of certain fellowships. The Special Session noted that developments since 1978 had not lived up to the hopes engendered by the First Special Session on Disarmament. In its final communique, it stated:

The objectives, priorities and principles (laid down in the Final Document in 1978) have not been generally observed. The Program of Action contained in the Final Document remains largely unimplemented. The arms race, however, particularly nuclear arms race, has assumed more dangerous proportions and global military expenditures have increased sharply. In short, since the adoption of the Final Document in 1978, there has been no significant progress in the field of arms limitation, disarmament and the seriousness of the situation has increased.
In fact, the communique observed deterioration in some areas:

The past four years have witnessed increasing recourse to the use of, or threat of use of force against the sovereignty and territorial integrity of States, military intervention, occupation, annexation and interference in the internal affairs of States and a denial of the inalienable rights of self-determination and independence of people under colonial or foreign domination.

The General Assembly did, however, unanimously reaffirm the validity of the Final Document of the First Special Session-for what that is worth-and the solemn commitment of member states to it, with a pledge to respect the priorities in disarmament negotiations, as agreed upon in its program of action.

In light of the failure of UNSSOD II, it appears to me to be necessary to review the contribution and responsibility of Australia. Australia played a significant role in that Special Session as a member of its planning committee, a member of the Bureau, and in chairing one of the three working groups. This is consistent with the quite prominent role it has played in the Committee on Disarmament. I pause to commend the Australian delegation for its professionalism and dedication. There was untiring effort by our delegation to achieve something constructive from the session and for that it deserves commendation.

Australia has always accepted that disarmament is a security issue. Its contribution to the disarmament process has therefore been from the stance of a member of the Western alliance. It does not take positions contrary to the security interests of that alliance. That is a stance with which I would agree. But within that contest Australia has supported the goal of disarmament and the negotiation of balanced and verifiable measures of arms control. Australia has recognised the need for a step by step approach. In particular, it has laid great emphasis on developing verification procedures. States will not agree to a mutual disarmament, consistent with their security obligations, unless they can be satisfied that such disarmament is, in fact, mutual. Thus Australia has been contributing in the area of seismic verification and also as part of the international satellite monitoring system. This should continue.

More specifically, Australia has given the highest priority to preventing the spread of nuclear weapons-first by its continued support of the nuclear non- proliferation treaty-which is concerned with horizonal proliferation-secondly, by advocating the conclusion of a comprehensive nuclear test ban treaty which would ban the testing of nuclear weapons by all states in all environments; and thirdly, through the development of an international consensus on the peaceful use of nuclear energy. The first two points it has pursued in the Committee on Disarmament and UNSSOD II. Also, its research in the verification area is contributing to slow progress. That progress should continue.
In regard to the third point, it is of interest to note that the final document of UNSSOD I stated:
International co-operation in the peaceful uses of nuclear energy should be conducted under agreed and appropriate international safeguards applied on a non -discriminatory basis.

Australia has played a leading role in the development of appropriate international safeguards and should continue to do so. Australia supports the concept of a comprehensive program of disarmament but has realistically recognised the disparity of views on the subject and the difficulty of obtaining a consensus. This work will continue in the Committee on Disarmament and should be directed, particularly, towards limiting the areas of dispute.

Additionally, Australia is committed, and has significantly contributed, to the objective of negotiating an international convention which would ban the production of chemical weapons and require existing stocks and their means of production to be destroyed. This effort also is obviously worth continuing. Any treaty success will be based on greater mutual respect and trust in the world. Therefore, Australia has a diplomatic role to play. Since it enjoys considerable respect in Third World countries particularly because of its stand on the North- South dialogue, Australia should be prepared to upgrade its role in this field. Algeria is showing a lead as an arbitrator.

Furthermore, we must be prepared to support peacekeeping forces, monitoring forces and the like such as we have in Zimbabwe, in the Sinai, and will have in Namibia. We have a particular responsibility in relation to localised disputes and difficulties in our region. Regional disputes have the potential to flare into major international crises. The problems concerning the Indonesia-Papua New Guinea border and certain Pacific nations come to mind. Australia supports the Association of South East Asian Nations, concept of a zone of peace, freedom and neutrality in South East Asia and also subscribes to the objective of establishing a zone of peace in the Indian Ocean. It is aware of the difficulties in this regard and is approaching the matter realistically. It is interesting to note that in the report of the delegation to the Thirty-sixth Session of the United Nations General Assembly it was stated that we are attempting to work towards a 'harmonisation of views' in relation to the Indian Ocean.

We also have a responsibility with our natural resources. We must be prepared to accept, on reasonable terms, that our natural resources must be shared, particularly with those countries which are experiencing shortages. The realisation that the peace, security and development of Australia depends on the security and development of other countries in our region is also important and a pragmatic justification for the North-South dialogue if one is needed. Australia should continue to support and in fact play a leading role in disarmament conferences. The emphasis of the super-powers towards bilateral negotiations should not allow the role of the international community as a whole to be usurped.
Security through disarmament to replace security through armament is a challenge that cannot be avoided, notwithstanding that it is alien to conventional security concepts.

How can it be better understood? Arguments are mounting for an Australian peace research institute to invigorate public debate on a better informed basis, to provide government with researched alternatives to conventional policy, to look to the effectiveness of multilateral organisations, research alternative co- operative approaches to conflict solving, more effective systems of international arbitration and the like. One could look at the Peace Research Institute in Oslo, the Centre for Peace and Security Studies of the United Nations University, the Stockholm International Peace Research Institute and others. Conventional answers to problems of security and peace are no longer sufficient in themselves. Community education in the area is vitally important and the world disarmament campaign, which we support, should help.

As an ally of the United States, one of the two major nuclear powers, Australia should press its ally towards consideration of peaceful alternatives, particularly so in view of the massive size and strength of the armaments industry within the United States and the vested interests of that lobby in perpetuating the arms race. We will do so more effectively if we are better informed. That shows the importance of research bodies. The final report of UNSSOD II concluded with a somewhat plaintive cry:
It was the hope of member States that UNSSOD II and its failure would, in itself, provide a powerful impetus for the international community to re-double its efforts in the cause of disarmament.
This applies also to Australia and to all of us.

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

speech.speaker: Elstob Sen R.C.

talk.start.para: —I take the opportunity of the debate on the motion for the first reading of the Customs Tariff Bill 1982 to raise a matter which I believe is important. The majority of the population of this country today is living in an ever present fear-a fear of doing without. This fear has been brought about by Liberal governments, whether they be State or Federal governments. There is no security today for the people in this country. I believe that is a great disgrace to any government, whether it be State or Federal. Australia has approximately 15 million people. The majority of those people are very well educated and healthy people. On top of that, we have great natural resources. Australians should feel that they have some security because of those natural resources. A country such as Australia that has a very small population and huge natural resources should be in far better shape than Australia.

speech.para: Let us examine what is happening to the ordinary people in this country. Everyone in the community-from managers to the people who sweep the floor-fears that he will lose his job. Because of the fear that is raging throughout the community everyone has stopped buying. People are putting off buying a refrigerator, a motor car or any other product. Consequently, if there is no confidence in the country a lot of people are automatically put out of work. This is what is happening today. I believe that politicians, whether they be State or Federal, have relied far too much on the academics and taken far too much notice of people with academic qualifications instead of relying on people with some common sense. I believe that we could overcome our problems if we did that. There is no need to import large quantities of material into this country.

During the war we were cut off from the rest of the world. A great proportion of the supplies for not only our troops but also the American forces came from this country. Everyone was employed as a result of the use of Australian resources. We had very little industry at the start of that conflict. We had to build up industries in a very short time and we had to rely on our own resources . In that period we had the only true Australian government. We did not rely on England; we did not ask America what to do or what not to do. We used our own initiative and got on with the job. We fought a war that was very costly. As I said, we provided supplies to the armies that had to fight that war. We manufactured all the munitions, we produced the food and we manufactured the materials that were needed to fight that war and that were needed by the community. Even after the war everyone was in full employment, simply because we did not import many products; we manufactured them ourselves. We relied on our own resources.

Australians on the whole show a great deal of initiative. They can do jobs which it is difficult to do. Governments today are not giving young people or anyone else in the community an opportunity to fulfil a role in society. Many people are out of work today and unnecessarily so. I believe that is the worst thing that is happening in Australia at the present time. We are destroying people. I believe that people are the most important asset of any nation. Without people a nation is nothing. Life is meaningless if we do not look after our children and grandchildren. If we, as politicians, cannot create a place in our society for our people we should not be here. I believe that politicians in my State of South Australia have done a terrible job in trying to employ people. They have driven industry away. Federally, we are not taking up the cudgels for those who are unemployed. Australia needs a Bill of Rights. That Bill of Rights should not be a politicial football. It should not be a privilege to have good health, education or a job; it should be a guaranteed right. Until politicians start to think along those lines we will not get anywhere.

As I said, today we are destroying our people, whether they be young, middle aged or elderly. The people of this country feel that they are not wanted. Unless people are prepared to go out and expand their knowledge they develop bad habits. If young people-I do not care whether it is the children of honourable senators opposite or my children-are unemployed and feel that they are not wanted by our community, naturally they will adopt bad ways. I believe it is a disgrace and a criminal offence to destroy our young people in this way, which is what we are doing to them. We have in this country the knowledge to turn the raw materials available to us into the goods that we require. I believe that it is possible, with the help of the Government, the trade union movement and management, to employ everyone in this country. There has never been an honest attempt to bring together all sections of the community. We are in trouble now and we are doing very little about it. Irrespective of what point of view one holds in politics today, we are true Australians and we must raise some spirit of nationalism. It has been raised; we saw it at the Brisbane Commonwealth Games . We should be proud to be Australians.

Senator Hill talked about defence and disarmament. Australia, through its governments, is not trying to preserve peace. We send people to attend conferences and do many things but we do not take up the initiative to slow down the arms race. That is essential. The world cannot afford to spend more than $1m a minute on arms. People are being destroyed not only in this country but throughout the world. We must reduce the amount spent on armaments. We must have a better understanding between people in the world. Unless this comes about we will get nowhere. If every one of us took one-third of our pay and burnt it every week we would be in financial difficulties. Yet this virtually is what countries of the world are doing with expenditure on armaments-taking huge sums of moneys and throwing them into the fire. There is no security for working people, small business people or even large enterprises. There is no confidence in this country and in many others.

I believe that this country can overcome its problems. We take the attitudes of professional people. That is the worst thing to do. What is lacking in this country and in the world is common sense. It is about time that we got back to common sense. It is about time that we got back to realising that people are valuable and that we should do something about them. The situation cannot go on. If we allow it to go on we will create the greatest turmoil, ills and violence et cetera. We have created them. We cannot blame people for turning against society. That is the great cost. We must take note of the mistakes that have been made in other countries. In any city anywhere in the world one sees pockets of poverty. Unless governments direct finance and people into those areas where great poverty exists that poverty is self-perpetuating. It passes from father to son. Eventually it is a festering sore. It should be cleaned up. We should not have pockets of poverty and ignorance. We should spend more money on education and ensuring that people are healthy. Without security, people feel that they are not contributing to a country. Life must be purposeful and meaningful.

Unless people have that attitude we cannot expand and advance as a nation. We should be a great nation and we could be a great nation. We should be an example to many other countries. Australians have a very good attitude to life. We should be setting an example to the rest of the nations of the world. It worries me that there are only 22 democratic countries left in the world. That is a frightening thought. I am a democratic socialist but I do not have any truck with dictatorships or such things. That is the worst sort of government. I cannot, never have and never will accept that. The Australian attitude of giving the other person a fair go is marvellous. We have much to offer and much to show the rest of the world.

We are not doing enough in the fields of foreign affairs and disarmament. We should play a more positive role in those fields. We should not worry about whether a person is from the Right or the Left or whether a country is following some of the communist countries. If we went out to show some positive thinking we would probably drag some of those countries away from that line of thought. It would be in our interests and in the interests of the world to do that. It disturbs me that we are not doing sufficient in this field. In my State the economy is sinking lower and lower. There are more young unemployed people than ever before. That disturbs me. I am not trying to score a political point. I think it is about time that we all started to think of people as being valuable. It disturbs me when a person is young and unemployed in South Australia, or in any other State. We are totally destroying them.

We can make everything that we need in this country without running to import everything. We should try to increase our productivity. We should go to the unions and to management to try to get sensible industrial agreements instead of knocking this one and that one. Certainly, we have differences of opinion; that is good and healthy. But we should think of one thing: We are Australians and we should be very proud Australians. The only way that we can achieve some sort of future for our people is to get together and learn to manage our country better. In the first place, Australia should be for Australians. I do not mean that in the narrow sense that we should not help other people; we have a moral duty to do that.

talk.start.para: —What do you mean?

—The benefits from the development of our national resources are going overseas. Australians are not getting the real benefits from those resources. That is disturbing. Some time ago we were told that the huge mineral boom would be of great benefit to Australia. It has not happened. More people are becoming unemployed. That is very disturbing. We are not getting the value out of our minerals that we should be getting. We should be manufacturing more, and learning to do it more professionally. If there were an honest attempt to do this we could compete with any country in the world. I have seen Australians pull together in time of war and in very difficult times. No people in this world are better than Australians. Australia is a great country and Australians are great people. It disturbs me that we are so poorly managed. It is about time that Australians started to think and to pull themselves up by their boot straps . We can do it and we should be doing it. One day it will come about.

speech.speaker: Foreman Sen D.J.

talk.start.para: —I wish to raise a matter of importance to all South Australians-the tragic unemployment situation in South Australia which has developed under the Tonkin Liberal Government and the deliberate attempt by that Government and its supporters to deceive the voting public of South Australia. Since the Tonkin Government came to power in 1979 employment in South Australia has grown by only something like 1,800 while employment in Australia as a whole has increased by a total of 300,000. In other words, as my colleague Senator Bolkus pointed out yesterday in his notice of motion, South Australia has had only a miserable one half of one per cent of total employment growth in Australia, while it accounts for something like 9 per cent of the Australian work force. For nearly three years now, South Australia has had the highest unemployment of all Australian mainland states. The latest figures confirm the disaster.

speech.para: In the twelve months to August 1982 a total of 7,100 jobs have gone in South Australia. These job losses have been worse among full time workers. In the year ending August 1982, 12,000 full time jobs were lost in South Australia. Over the last 12 months South Australia has fared much worse than any other State with the exception of Tasmania. Total employment fell by 1.3 per cent compared to only 0.5 per cent in New South Wales and 0.1 per cent in Victoria.

Since January this year there has been an increasing number of retrenchments. Let me list them. Since the beginning of 1982, 330 workers have been retrenched by General Motors-Holden's Ltd; 47 workers have been retrenched by Gerard Industries Pty Ltd; 75 by Sapfor Timber Mills Ltd; 279 by Kelvinator Australia Ltd, with the possibility of another 400; 125 by Broken Hill Proprietary Co. Ltd , and another 340 on the way; 100 by NEI Engineering at Whyalla; 100 by the Mount Barker Tannery; 12 by Clyde Engineering (S.A.) Pty Ltd; 50 by Kenwood Pty Ltd; 95 by Tubemakers of Australia Ltd; 30 by Adelaide and Wallaroo Fertilizers; six by Wunderlich Windows; 20 by Messenger Press Pty Ltd; eight by Hannaford and Co.
