Pty Ltd; five by Parcelboard Pty Ltd; 105 by Atco Industries (Aust.) Pty Ltd at Elizabeth; 27 by Dulux Aust. Ltd; and three by Simes and Martin Pty Ltd. Only yesterday, hundreds of workers at Adelaide's Kelvinator plant decided to accept a 4 day working week with a cut in pay to save their jobs. So much for industry' s confidence in the South Australian Government. So much for Mr Tonkin's promise in his 1979 election policy speech to create 7,000 new jobs.

The latest Australian Bureau of Statistics figures confirm the downward trend in South Australia. In September of this year, unemployment reached a record 51, 200 people, which is 8.5 per cent of the work force. This is more than one percentage point above the national figure and represents an increase in unemployment over the last 12 months of a staggering 7 per cent. August and September 1982 will certainly not be forgotten because they represent the first time since the Second World War that South Australia has had unemployment figures in excess of 50,000. The most horrifying aspect of South Australia's unemployment situation is the fact that the unemployment rate amongst 15 to 19 year olds has reached a whopping 29 per cent. This is the highest youth unemployment rate of any Australian state. It is even higher than Tasmania. Twenty-nine per cent of young South Australians are now out of work, that is, one in every three. No wonder our young people are leaving.

Under the Tonkin regime, South Australia's population has fallen below Western Australia's for the first time ever. During 1980-81, a record 7,700 South Australians left the State to go to other parts of Australia, notably Sydney and Melbourne where there are Labor governments, of course. South Australia has rapidly gone to the dogs under Mr Tonkin.

The latest job vacancy figures show clearly why many people are leaving the State. In August there were only 1,000 new jobs in South Australia, just 4.7 per cent of the national total. This meant that for every job vacancy there were 50 unemployed people, compared to the national average of 21 people. Since 1979, the number of unemployed people for every job vacancy has risen from 20 to 50. That is an increase of 150 per cent. No wonder people are leaving.

Many concerned people I have spoken to have also complained about the erosion of civil liberties under the Tonkin Government. They point to the Attorney- General's banning of films at the International Film Festival two years ago, which in effect put an end to the festival for all time. They point to the harassment by the police of gay people which is now taking place, no doubt under the direction of the Minister for Wowsers, as he is sometimes known, Mr Griffin, and his friend Mr Olsen. They point to the introduction of new laws which give police greater powers to search anyone they believe may be infringing the law.

Mr Tonkin's only so-called claims to achievement are the rather hastily constructed international terminal funded by the Federal Government and the new Hilton Hotel, which was labelled by Mr Tonkin when in opposition as a 'socialist dream'. Adelaide has Mr Dunstan and the former Labor Government to thank for the Hilton Hotel. While this incompetent State Government boasts about its non- achievements, small businesses have suffered badly in South Australia under the Tonkin regime. The hotel and restaurant trades in South Australia have been badly affected by the introduction of random breath testing. Many small businesses have been affected by the refusal of the State Government to lift the general payroll tax exemption. I notice the Liberals have attempted to bribe small businessmen by promising to lift the exemption if they win the election. The fact that it has taken an election to do this is a measure of the Tonkin Liberal Government's concern for small business people.

The building industry has also been a victim of the Tonkin regime. In the 3 months ending August 1982, new dwelling approvals in South Australia totalled 1901, down 8.5 per cent over the same period last year. For houses in the private sector, approvals were down by 10.5 per cent. Dwelling commencements in South Australia in the June quarter represented only 7 per cent of the national total, well below South Australia's share of the national population.

One of the most significant factors affecting home building in South Australia, apart from interest rates, is the fact that under the Tonkin Government the State has had the highest increase in building costs in Australia. Apart from skyrocketing mortgage repayments, there has also been a whole host of increases in State charges.

Every single family or household in South Australia has been affected by the huge increases in electricity and gas bills, water rates, council rates, bus and train fares and motor vehicle registration fees under the Liberal Government. Mr Tonkin had the audacity to claim in his 1982-83 Budget speech that the Government had avoided increasing State tax rates in 1982-83. What he did not say was that he actually put up motor vehicle registration rates in April and licences, under the Business Franchise (Petroleum Products) Act, went up in May. What he also omitted to say was that in 1982-83, as a result of his Government actions, total State taxes in the form of the electricity trust levy, land tax, motor vehicle registrations, and so on, will rise by $12.5m. State taxation revenue will actually increase by 11.5 per cent in 1982-83. If we look at the figures for taxation per head of population, it is quite clear that there has been a massive increase in taxes under Mr Tonkin. Taxation per capita increased from $296 in 1978-79 under Labor to $414 in 1982-83. This represents an increase of 40 per cent. No wonder retail sales in South Australia and new motor vehicle registrations are still below the national level. So much for the achievements of the Tonkin Government.

Our manufacturing industries are falling apart at the seams, yet all the Tonkin Government can do is talk about pie-in-the-sky programs for 1990. What is Mr Tonkin doing about the 400 workers who face possible retrenchment at Kelvinator? What about the 100 workers that GMH is poised to retrench after the election? Where are these people going to get jobs? What about 1983, 1984, 1985 and all the other years?

Once again, the Liberals are engaging in a dishonest, muckraking campaign in an attempt to deceive the voters of South Australia. Already we are seeing some of the Liberal Party's members and supporters inserting emotional and pathetic full page newspaper advertisements.

A Mr Nigel Buick, a farmer from Kangaroo Island whom Senator McLaren mentioned a few moments ago, is again being used by friends and members of the Liberal Party to insert scaremongering advertisements in the daily papers. I am told that the cost for these is being met by a wellknown Adelaide car dealer, who is probably a member of the Liberal Party. I wonder whether these people will be offered discounts by the News as they apparently were during the last State election campaign. As far as I am concerned there is no need for this sort of emotional hogwash in an election campaign. There is no need for the scaremongering and brainwashing of the type perpetrated by Mr Buick and his car dealer friends. The South Australian public deserves to be treated with a bit more respect than is being shown by these so-called friends of the Liberal Party . What is more, they deserve a bit more honesty and integrity from their Government.

Never before have South Australians been subject to the sort of incompetence and brainwashing that the Liberals have indulged in over the last three years. Time and again the airwaves have been full of the corny jingles devised by business friends of the Liberal Party to try to convince South Australians that their State is great. If all of this money were put into promoting South Australia outside its borders, interstate and overseas, the tourists would pour in by the thousands. If South Australia's business leaders were more progressive and less bogged down with the past, perhaps South Australian industry would be better placed to ride out the recession.

The Labor Party is committed to revitalising the South Australian economy. It will provide jobs now and in the forseeable future, not just in 1990; not just in rural South Australia but also in Adelaide. It is committed to giving every possible assistance to our small business people because we recognise the vital role they play in the South Australian economy. It is committed also to giving every possible assistance to our ailing manufacturing industries to help them through these bad times and to project them into the next decade with a feeling of confidence. I hope, for the sake of all South Australians, that common sense will prevail on 6 November and that the people of South Australia will elect a Bannon State Labor government.

speech.speaker: Gietzelt Sen A.T.

talk.start.para: —I take advantage of this first reading debate to refer to a problem which an increasing number of Australians feel ought to become the responsibility of government, as well as the community and the popular Press. I commend the initiative taken by the editor-in-chief of the Sunday Telegraph, Ita Buttrose, who in the last four issues of the Sunday Telegraph has dealt with the problem of junk food and obesity in children. Obviously attempts are being made within the fast food industry, and in the food industry generally, to put us in a defensive position as far as school canteens are concerned. Ita Buttrose has dealt with a matter which I have raised with the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume), who is at the table this afternoon , and his predecessor, the present Minister for Finance, Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle. Both are on the public record as having expressed some three or four years ago the view that the Commonwealth Government should take a great deal more initiative in respect of preventive medicine. We can only say that in the intervening period the Government's activity in this area, despite attempts by the Commonwealth Department of Health, has been insufficient and inadequate. The Government has failed in its responsibilities.

speech.para: There is abundant evidence to show that the problems of public health, particularly as they relate to heart problems, begin in the very early years of life. This pattern of health behaviour and development starts largely at the school canteen. Therefore, the attempts of Ita Buttrose to draw the attention of the community at large to these problems are to be commended. In fact, they are an indictment of the Government's inability and failure to act in this important area of diet. Ita Buttrose, in her articles beginning on 26 September, draws attention to the endeavours of the medical profession to create a public awareness, a public concern, in the hope that attempts will be made by governments to enter this area and intervene in such a way as to protect the community from the commercialisation and influence of television, which creates in the minds of many of the members of our community a belief that they are acting properly and responsibly when purchasing junk food. She says in her original article:
There is wide medical concern about the health of Australian children and I fear the root cause of the problem is that parents are less fussy than my mother about what their children eat and drink.

Studies of Australian children have shown that they suffer from poor dental health, obesity, underweight, poor physical fitness, constipation, high levels of fatty substances in the blood and elevated blood pressure.

In subsequent weeks she has continued to draw the attention of the readers of this large-circulation Sunday newspaper to this problem. That has led a number of people to write letters to her. Some have condemned the campaign being run by the editor of that paper and others, such as those in last week's edition, showed that she enjoys a great deal of public support from those members of the community who are concerned about this problem. Since she has raised the issue a couple of articles have appeared in the Sydney Morning Herald. They indicate that her campaign is having some effect, because within the school system itself there is, I suppose one could say, a revolt by more conscious students about the sort of food and drinks sold in canteens. She has enjoyed a remarkable response from the people involved in the area of nutrition, and that leads me to express my dismay that the words uttered in this place in regard to preventive medicine by both Senator Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and Senator Baume several years back have not been carried into effect at all. They can only be regarded as being rhetorical and an abdication of responsibility by the Government because of the vested interests that clearly exist in this area.

This brings us to an understanding of the role that television plays in the promotion of fast food. In that respect, a paper was presented at the 1979 Australia and New Zealand Association for the Advancement of Science Conference by Josephine F. Rogers in which she drew attention to a major effort being undertaken at that stage by the fast food outlets, using the television medium to promote their articles for sale, and the fact that that was having an undue influence on the thinking of parents and children. In her paper she drew attention to the fact that, whilst most people eat to satisfy psychological and sociological needs, few are concerned with health and nutrition. She drew attention to the fact that American fast food chains had arrived in Australia. She stated that, surprisingly, the three big operators in Australia-McDonald's hamburgers, Kentucky Fried Chicken Pty Ltd and Pizza Hut Australia Pty Ltd had moved very heavily into the area of sale via the influence of television.

In a position paper entitled 'In Support of a Nutrition Policy for School Canteens' which was prepared by the Australian Nutrition Foundation and the Dental Health Foundation of Australia delivered only in September 1982, the attention of the general public was drawn to the fact that the school canteen is seen as an integral part of the school and it should illustrate and complement classroom programs. The paper pointed to the need to have an educational role in our multicultural society. The paper stated that nutrition is important to health throughout life and it is particularly important at times of rapid growth and development, which include the school years. The paper continued:
For the many students who use the canteen regularly the food purchased there makes a significant contribution to total food intake and nutrition.
In spite of our abundance of food and comparative affluence there is much evidence associating health problems and disease with the diet pattern of Australians.
Although most lifestyle diseases are diagnosed in adulthood, early risk factors and symptoms begin to develop in childhood and the eating habits of children may contribute to diseases later in life.

Another report which is available through the Parliamentary Library shows that studies on the relationships between a diet and coronary heart disease indicate that elevated blood cholesterol levels begin during childhood and adolescence. An article was written by Elizabeth Fanning, who is a reader in Preventive Dentistry at the Department of Dental Health of the University of Adelaide, entitled 'The diet of school children: role of the canteen'. Sydney newspapers a month or two ago reported the manner in which the Coca Cola organisation was going out of its way to fight against the attempts being made by the South Australian Minister of Education and the New South Wales Minister for Education who have taken steps in recent times to exercise a greater degree of interest in and control of the sorts of food and drink that are sold in school canteens.

If we are really concerned about the growth in medicine and health care costs generally in Australia, I do not believe we can ignore the fact that so much of this begins at the establishment of canteen facilities in our schools. Therefore , there is a need for governments, in the State and Federal spheres, to take much more interest in the development of what is happening and the influences that do exist which lead children and parents to be overinfluenced by cultural and other aspects through per force of the media. This brings us to the conclusion that there is a need for some government interest in this area I understand that we have a time problem; therefore, I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 20 October, on motion by Senator Chaney:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Scott Sen The Hon D.B.

talker.name: Senator SCOTT
talker.role: Leader of the National Party in the Senate)

talk.start.para: —I rise briefly to draw my remarks to a conclusion. I began them last evening when I spoke on the Drought Assistance (Primary Producers) Bill 1982. I emphasised the generous nature of the proposed measures and the promptness of the Government's response to drought circumstances which have probably never before been seen in this country either in regard to the duration of the drought -running from between two and three years in some areas and up to four years in others-or in regard to the fact that the measures cover very significant areas of at least four Australian States. This has mean that there is none of the normal relief that is generally available in a drought situation. There are literally no places to go. I highlighted, I hope, the appropriate guidelines and criteria that have been developed concerning the establishment of a proper eligibility for the interest and fodder subsidies. In circumstances where taxpayers' funds are being committed, it is important that there is a very responsible attitude taken in relation to drawing the lines of eligibility for whatever provisions are required.

speech.para: During the debate there has been some comment on the need to establish a system of drought insurance in this country. This is an interesting and an important concept. The Government looked at it many years ago-from memory, I think it was as far back as 1967-in the form of drought bonds. In a large measure these have been superseded nowadays by income equalisation deposits. That represents another means of holding some form of power in reserve, as it were, for these extraordinary, one would hope, circumstances.

Whilst the idea of drought insurance is worthy of in-depth investigation, I think it is reasonable to recall some of the measures which this Government has taken over the past six or seven years in the form of incentives which are very significantly designed to aid the development of primary industry and particularly to aid its capacity and determination to look after itself in conditions of drought and in the many difficult situations that occur in the conduct of primary industry. The industry experiences difficulties not only as a result of climatic conditions by also because it is so dependent on world markets. The industry has little control over the very areas and circumstances in which it seeks to sell its produce.

Legislation such as that which implemented an investment allowance and a generous depreciation scheme-which was recently made more generous-and tax deductibilities for the conservation of fodder, soil and water, represents a direct contribution to the capacity of primary industry to defend itself against drought, although these measures have proved to be not quite equal to the task in the circumstances which confront us today. Equally the abolition of the estate duty and the averaging of incomes are areas which have enabled the primary producing units to remain of basically viable size and a large amount of the dismembering of economic units has ceased.

I close my remarks by saying that the drought, serious as it is, has made Australians aware of at least two things: The dependence across the board, particularly in extra-metropolitan Australia, on primary industry and the interdependence of all those who live and operate in the towns, villages and provincial cities of Australia and ultimately of the cities themselves. I commend the legislation. I believe it has been a fast and comprehensive response to a most unfortunate circumstance.

speech.speaker: McLaren Sen G.T.

talk.start.para: —In speaking to the Drought Assistance ( Primary Producers) Bill 1982 I want, firstly, to refute a remark which was made in this chamber yesterday by Senator Carrick in dealing with another matter. When the Opposition sought to have some matters referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Finance and Government Operations for examination, Senator Carrick said:

speech.para: There is nothing that the Labor Party dislikes more than helping the farming community.

That is a complete untruth. Senator Carrick knows it is but he persists, as do honourable senators behind him, in making the same statement both in and out of this place. The Australian Labor Party has a very fine record over many years in helping the farming community. I go right back to the days of the late Mr Reg Pollard as a Minister in a Labor government. He introduced the superphosphate subsidy bounty. I also remember what was done by a colleague who was my leader in this place for some time and who is now the Leader of the Opposition in the State Parliament in Tasmania. It was under his guidance as the Minister for Agriculture that the Labor Government introduced the floor price for wool.

There are many other things that I could go into. We have endeavoured at all times to assist the farming community on a fair and equal basis wherever possible. I emphatically deny the statements that have been made by honourable senators opposite in trying to gain a cheap bit of kudos in the electorate and in trying to hoodwink farmers into believing that we are not concerned. One has only to look at the honourable senators on this side of the House. At least four of us in here at the moment have been practising farmers. Senator Walsh, who came in for some very severe criticism by the previous speaker, Senator Scott, was a practising farmer in Western Australia for many years before he became a member of this place. My colleague Senator Primmer was a dairy farmer. I was a poultry farmer, but prior to that I was engaged for many years in the pastoral industry as a shearer. No one would know better than I about the effect of the ravages of drought on sheep. I have had to handle sheep which were nothing better than skeletons and which were brought to the shearing sheds in spring carts, lorries and drays to be shorn. I have viewed the effect of those traumas on not only livestock but also the people who endeavour to eke a living from the land. The Labor Party is concerned to ensure that the very wealthy section of the community does not get some benefit at the expense of the people on lesser incomes. I refer to the Pitt Street, Collins Street and Rundle Street farmers who, in the true sense, are not real farmers; they are investors.

I took umbrage at the statement made by Senator Scott in speaking about the amendment which was moved by my colleague Senator Walsh. I wrote down the words he used. He claimed that the amendment was insulting. There is nothing insulting about the amendment which was moved by Senator Walsh. It states:
At the end of motion, add ', but the Senate is of the opinion that-
(a) a limit should be set on the sum that any individual may receive in any one year;

What is insulting about that? Why is it insulting to try to place a limit on what the taxpayer has to pay to people in desperate circumstances because of the drought? If we do not place a limit on it the possibility is that many people will have access to this drought relief money while other people will have very hard times trying to get any. The amendment continues:
(b) eligibility should be determined by a ceiling on total assets instead of the proposed liquidity test; and
(c) those persons who are predominantly dependent on their farm for their living should be objectively defined'.

What is so insulting about trying to define the people who are predominantly dependent on their farms for their living? I go further and say that there should be a register of the recipients. Honourable senators on the other side of the chamber continually complain about dole bludgers. These so-called dole bludgers have to line up in a queue every fortnight to put in their work sheet at the Department of Social Security to enable them to continue to get their dole payments. They have to do that in the full glare of the public wherever there is a regional or main office of the Department of Social Security or the Commonwealth Employment Service. They have to parade in front of the public because of their unfortunate circumstances-they cannot get jobs. If they have to do that, there is no reason why the people who will be recipients of the drought relief should not be listed on some register which is available for public perusal. After all, something like $360m of taxpayers' money is involved in this matter. If my memory serves me right, Senator Carrick said yesterday that it could be as high as $600m. There has to be some record kept of the names of the people receiving this drought relief so that everyone in this Parliament will be able to see who the recipients are.

We have had problems in this regard before. I will mention one man who was mentioned by Senator Walsh yesterday as a person who may well be in receipt of drought relief. This is a matter which Senator Walsh raised before an Estimates committee. I was there. That person is none other than Harry M. Miller, a gaolbird who got away with taxpayers' money. He might well find himself in the position of benefiting from this legislation. Of course, whenever we asked many questions about this person who had offices of patronage under this Government we were told that Harry M. Miller was serving in a voluntary capacity. After many weeks of hard grind in here we found out that, whilst he might not have been getting a salary, he was getting a lot of perks on the side, such as free telephones, free trips overseas and so on-all at the taxpayers' expense. These are things that honourable senators on this side of the House are concerned about. That is one of the reasons why this amendment has been moved. There ought to be some ceiling. There also ought to be a register so that we will know who is getting the money.

I am pleased to see the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) in charge of this Bill. His office puts out in June of every year a document which shows how many people are in receipt of a pension, whether it be an age, or widows pension, or supporting mothers benefit or unemployment benefit. That is all listed under the postcode areas. If that can be done by the Department of Social Security, with the hundreds of thousands of people involved, there is no reason why a similar register or publication could not be made available to the Parliament showing how many people in each postcode area are in receipt of money under this scheme and the amounts of money involved. There might be some reason of confidentiality or embarrassment as to why the names should not be in the documents. But at least responsible people on this side of the House-say, the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Button) or the shadow Minister for Primary Industry-ought to have access to those names on a confidential basis to see that the scheme is operating above board and that everyone is getting a fair go.

I refer again to the statement made by Senator Carrick that we on this side of the House are always trying to have a shot at primary producers. I say again, as I have said many other times, that in my State of South Australia two country seats are held by Government members. They are the seats of Wakefield and Barker . They are so concerned about the interests of primary producers and country people that they do not even live in their electorates. They do not even have an office in their electorates. They have decided to live in the metropolitan area, within sight of the Adelaide Town Hall clock, and to have their offices in King William Street. So again I say that we on this side of the House have given conclusive proof by supporting legislation to assist farmers and by our members living in country areas.

My colleague Laurie Wallis, the honourable member for Grey, has two offices, one at Port Augusta and the other, following a recent decision by the Government to give him another office because he represents about 92 per cent of the area of South Australia, at Whyalla. I am the only senator in South Australia who lives and has an office in the country. I have two offices. The office at Mount Gambier is at my own expense. So the proof of the pudding is in the eating. Members of the Labor Party are concerned about country people and farmers. We proved that by our actions not only by way of legislation but also by where we domicile ourselves to try to give service to these people.

The Labor Party has a drought policy. Although the Labor Party has been criticised, there is no justification for that criticism. I just want to read to the Senate part of our drought policy. We say in the preamble to this policy:
Drought is a frequently recurring problem for Australian agriculture. Yet it often seems to catch governments by surprise.

I think Senator Macklin said during the debate last night that there have been about 22 droughts in this century. I will have to have a look at those figures to see whether they are correct. I am using his words; I hope I am quoting him correctly. In any case, droughts are nothing new in Australia. Therefore all governments, both State and Federal, should be aware at all times that a drought is around the corner. They should not have to make, as in this instance, a hasty decision, as we were told during an Estimates committee hearing, at the whim of the Federal Government. We were told that there were no rules and regulations when the Government suddenly decided that it would make this money available. I can just imagine the problems that the people working in the Department of Primary Industry had in trying to draw up some rules and regulations to administer this piece of legislation.

The ALP's drought policy aims to put an end to the ad hoc approach to drought relief which has characterised the response of the Liberal-National Party Government. This is an ad hoc response in terms of the way that this piece of legislation came so hurriedly into the Parliament. Labor's drought policy reads:
At the farm level the ALP's policy is designed to encourage producers to protect themselves against the adverse consequences of drought.

In the event of severe, sustained drought, primary producers will be provided with income support so that the farm family and farm business can be maintained, and valuable resources not lost to agriculture.

Great emphasis is placed on that part of our drought relief policy on the farm and the farming family. They are the people about whom we are concerned because they are the backbone of the country areas. The practical farmers who live in country areas buy their goods in country towns and also employ local labour. This is something about which we are very concerned. We will be taking further steps after the next election to bring about a better method of implementing drought relief when such a step is necessary.

I am also concerned that every time honourable senators opposite get up and talk about legislation they are prone to refer to those on this side of the House as 'you socialists'. There is no bigger offender in this respect that Senator Lajovic. He says we are socialists. I would say that this is a very good piece of socialist legislation. It is real socialist legislation under which the taxpayers of this country are providing finance to help people in need. That is what socialism is all about. I am very surprised that Senator Lajovic's name was not on the speakers list because I would have thought that he would have been here espousing his views as an anti-socialist and saying that the Government should not be making available the money that is embodied in this piece of legislation and perhaps the extra money which will be required to increase the amount to $600m. But he is very silent on that. Of course, he and most National Party people and many of the Liberals who have country seats have a philosophy, which Senator Webster espoused in this place on many occasions; they capitalise their profits and socialise their losses. That is the philosophy of these people .

As I have said, we have no objection to using taxpayers' money to help people in need. But let us be fair about it. Government members should not come in here and criticise Labor Party members because of our socialist policies. As we have said on many occasions, those policies are designed to help people in need. The strong have to help the weak. Honourable senators on the opposite side are always prepared to engage in legislation of this sort when they can see some benefit for themselves. However, if we support other legislation in which there is some benefit for the working man, we are criticised as being socialists, as helping bludgers. That is not the case at all.

I do not want to take up the time of the Senate. The Labor Party is not opposed to this legislation. Government senators have inferred, but have not actually said, that we are opposed to the legislation. We support it. However, in supporting it we have taken the opportunity to move an amendment which in my view and in the view of my party, as I said in my opening remarks, is necessary to ensure that people will not be able to take unfair advantage of the money that is made available. I hope that the Government will take on board what I have said about compiling a register. From looking at the sky every morning when I get up, I think that the drought is still going to be with us when we come into government next year.

If this Government does not act, I will be moving very strongly to see that a register of recipients is set up, as happened when we were in government and Senator Murphy, as the Minister for Customs and Excise, used the powers that were available to him to have compiled a register of recipients of superphosphate bounty payments. Of course, we found that people opposite fought tooth and nail to ensure that those names were not publicised. I think it took me three days to get the list that was available to us put on the public record. Many people were surprised when they found who was on the list. We were not supplied with the total amount that people received. However, we found that the now Prime Minister, Mr Fraser, was a recipient of some $5,000 from the superphosphate bounty. It is no wonder that members of the Liberal-National Party Government wanted to hide this information. Many members of the Cabinet of this Government are primary producers. We have only to look around at how they hold out both of their hands if there are any perks about. We have only to have a look at Mr Anthony getting a home loan at 4 3/4 per cent and-a lot of people were not aware of this-letting the home out to a member of the Central Intelligence Agency at probably an enormous rent. That is something that we will be pursuing at some later date. We want to see whether in fact he declared as income the rent he received on a house which he purchased with a cheap home loan .

Therefore, let it not ever be said again that we on this side of the House are opposed to giving assistance to the farming community or, for that matter, people who live in country towns. That is one of the main planks of our platform . We realise that no one side of the community can exist without the other. If the enterprises of farmers of this country are not profitable they will not buy the goods which are manufactured by the workers on the assembly lines. Likewise, if the workers do not have an income and are short of cash thay cannot buy the produce that the farmers grow. So each side depends on the other. Whilst we have a lot of criticism of this Bill and the way in which it is being implemented in such an ad hoc and hasty fashion, we will support it. We hope that honourable senators on the other side of the chamber will support the amendment that has been moved by my colleague, Senator Walsh.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Scott for his support of the Drought Assistance (Primary Producers) Bill and in particular for bringing out a point which I am surprised needed bringing out and which in light of the debate clearly had not really come to the attention of some members of the Opposition. Senator Scott laid very heavy stress on the severity of the drought conditions facing most of Australia, in particular the eastern two-thirds of Australia, and the fact that that introduces considerations which are not normally the concern of government in a more limited drought. The extensive nature of this drought means, as Senator Scott pointed out, that there are few alternatives available for farmers. There is little agistment available. Farmers are in such a position that their stock will be difficult to sell. There is nowhere else to send them and the only option is either to destroy them or to purchase feed. So it is the severity of this drought which had led the Government to introduce these special measures which stand as a supplement over and above the normal provisions which are allowed for under the general natural disasters relief scheme which applies throughout Australia.

speech.para: It is in that context that I want to be very critical of some of the points made by Senator Walsh in his attack on the legislation. As I understand it, all parties in the Senate are supporting the passage of this Bill. The complaints were in the nature of complaints that in detail the Bill is deficient or that it lacks sufficient detail. Senator Walsh was at pains to point out that there could be opportunities for very considerable benefit to well off people under this legislation. I think the points he made and the examples he raised ignore part of the realities of drought Australia 1982.

I will pick up one of those examples. Senator Walsh referred to a farmer with a mortgage of $1m, carrying interest at 16 per cent, and 20,000 sheep for whom a fodder subsidy would be sought. Senator Walsh picked out that very atypical example. I think there would be general agreement in the Senate that very few farmers would carry that sort of debt. The average level of debt that I have seen in the papers supporting this legislation is about $32,000. A $1m debt is a very atypical example. Let us assume that there is a very small number of people in drought affected Australia who are capable of carrying that sort of debt. Senator Walsh pointed out that such a person, paying 16 per cent on a mortgage of $1m, would be obtaining an interest subsidy of $3,333 per month and a fodder subsidy of $16,000 per month. A fodder subsidy on 20,000 sheep at a maximum of 80 cents per sheep comes to $16,000. One gets the picture of a person with very substantial assets-and they are very substantial debts, one would have to say- getting a subsidy of up to $20,000 per month or close to $250,000 per year.

It is important to note that even in that extreme and unusual example, assistance will be provided by the Government-that, of course, means by the people of Australia-in circumstances when, although the farmer might be receiving an interest subsidy of $3,333, at the same time he is liable for an interest payment of $10,000 per month. He is receiving merely the top 4 per cent of his interest. He is liable for the remaining 12 per cent. He will qualify for that interest subsidy only if he has liquid assets of no more than that amount of 12 per cent. In other words, he is required to denude himself of available liquid assets. That means shares and all of the things which can readily be turned into cash. He is incurring personal liability month by month at a rate of $10,000.

The fodder subsidy is, of course, a subsidy which at maximum provides 50 per cent of what is required for the purchase of fodder. That is the maximum rate of subsidy that can be provided. So, if the drought relief program is providing $16 ,000 per month, by definition, the farmer himself is providing $16,000 per month or more. His liability, therefore, in this drought situation where, by definition, he is eligible for the interest subsidy only if he has restricted liquid assets on which he can draw, is a commitment of $26,000 per month. That figure is, of course, very considerably in excess of the amount of subsidy he is receiving. That sort of extreme example is put forward by Senator Walsh to incite envy and cause division when we, as a country, ought to be showing a bit of unity and attempting to pull together. A considerable subsidy could be available in that very odd and unusual example when the farmer is subject to quite enormous outgoings-in this case well over $300,000 per year-which are in excess of the liquid assets to which he has access. I stress two things: The very unusual nature of the example that Senator Walsh chose to draw on and the fact that his example did not bring out the fact that that farmer would not merely receive a subsidy; he would have to eat into his remaining assets to a very considerable extent during the period of the drought. I stress that if a farmer with very large assets had liquid assets in excess of the interest requirement of 12 per cent, he would not qualify for the whole or part of the interest rate subsidy.

Another point of division in the debate was the question which was raised both by Labor speakers and the speaker on behalf of the Australian Democrats about the failure of the legislation to assist wheatgrowers. I stress that the assistance which is provided under the Drought Assistance (Primary Producers) Bill is, for a start, supplementary to general drought assistance measures which are, of course, available to wheatgrowers as they are to other farmers. The only new measure which is not available to wheatgrowers is the fodder subsidy. In fact many wheatgrowers own sheep or cattle which they run in conjunction with their wheat properties. Practice does vary from region to region in Australia. The interest rate subsidy is available to grain farmers. For those who run both grain and stock of course the fodder subsidy is also available. Wheatgrowers have access to all other assistance which is provided including, as I said before, the interest rate subsidy.

The precise provisions which might apply to grain growers vary from State to State. In New South Wales there is also a special cereal growers advance under the Commonwealth-State arrangements which helps a farmer to plant his next wheat crop. New South Wales is the premier or leading wheat State, although this year I think my State of Western Australia, thanks to the good fortune of good weather, carries that crown. But New South Wales is the major wheat State and the most drought affected. That is a very relevant provision to wheatgrowers in that area. In my State of Western Australia which happily has just come out of a long period of drought, special provisions for carry on finance were made with respect to the grain growing areas which were particularly hard hit. I mention the northern wheatbelt in Western Australia as an area which has suffered very substantial hardship over a four-year period.

The concern expressed by Senator Macklin about there being no national drought insurance plan in a country where there is drought in some part of it in 78 out of 100 years is understandable but it appears to ignore the fact that regular drought assistance programs are available. I have already mentioned the natural disasters scheme in which the Commonwealth participates with the States on a three for one basis after the States have undertaken initial expenditure up to a limit which varies according to the size of the State. It is simply not true to suggest that there is no regular procedure for dealing with drought in Australia . Another aspect of the matter is that the Commonwealth has encouraged drought proofing measures through the tax system. Considerable tax advantages are available for primary producers who choose to improve the water supply, and so on, on their properties as a drought proofing measure. In response to Senator Macklin I simply say that, whilst no government would wish to put out of its mind the possibility of improvement in the way that it deals with drought, it is a fact that we have had for some years measures which farmers know will be brought into action in the event of significant drought.

Senator McLaren raised an issue which at first I thought involved his wanting to have produced some form of McCabe-Lafranchi report on drought relief which would give him a great list of names which he could peruse to his heart's content. Subsequently, it became clearer from his comments that he was looking for rather more limited advice. There would be little difficulty in producing broad district statistics of the kind that the honourable senator suggested ought to be generally available. I have not had a chance to take advice on the matter but, when public moneys are used for any public purpose, it is usual for statistics to be made available as to where that money has gone. In a broad sense, reference has been made to my own Department and to its ability to produce details of expenditure according to postcode areas. I am not in a position to guarantee that one could provide that sort of detail but I will certainly ask the Department of Primary Industry and the Minister to take note of the request. I believe that the nation and the Parliament would be interested to learn in which areas expenditure was being incurred.

On the question of names being available, on any basis, I would be less positive in my response. There again, I will take the matter on notice and refer it to the Minister for consideration. I understand that Senator McLaren is seeking a much more limited exposure, if I may use that term, than his opening remarks conveyed to me.

My only other general comment concerns the point made by Senator Walsh, that if we were to have drought assistance measures of this type we might be moving to a situation in which a farmer could say: 'I should never put myself in a position in which I have cash or fodder reserves and should never utilise income equalisation deposits because if I fail to do all these things I will be more eligible for the sort of assistance that is provided under this scheme'. I do not deny that there is some logic in the point that the drought relief measures proposed are to be available generally to people who are without other liquid resources. But I point out again that the Government's proposals are made in the context of an unusually bad and general drought situation across virtually the whole of agricultural Australia other than, I would have thought, Gippsland and Western Australia.

Thus, we are in an unusual situation in which the Government sees it as quite important to ensure that there is no requirement that people walk off properties on a wholesale basis, or destock on a wholesale basis. We face an unusually difficult situation. To impose on the assistance provided a limit based on some measure of prudence to be judged by the public servants who have to administer the measure might well leave us in the situation of providing assistance for those who have been prudent and denying it to those who are perhaps on marginal land or, alternatively, have managed their affairs less well, so that such people would be forced to lose their property or significantly destock them. They are circumstances such as the Government believes should be avoided. I should have thought that it would be fairly clear that in farming in Australia generally one could not rely upon similarly generous measures being brought down by the Government when less severe drought conditions were generally evident around the country.

I refer now to a matter that has been raised by way of inquiry but has not been aired in debate. A number of farmers have made representations, I believe through Senator Hill, about the exclusions which relate to the offsets against subsidy entitlement when farmers are sellers of fodder as well as purchasers. The rationale underlying the exclusions laid down is that the Government does not consider taxpayers' funds should be used to subsidise fodder purchases at the same time as farmers are selling fodder. However, in the case of the exclusions, it is considered that the product of a grain producing enterprise on a farm is not, in normal circumstances, used or sold for stock feed. Such grains are used for either human consumption or, in the case of seed, for replanting. It would be inconsistent with the general approach and philosophy adopted to require that revenue from these sales be deducted from subsidy entitlements when fodder is purchased. For example, if a farmer owns wheat of a grade lower than GP, it is demonstrably wheat which could only be used for feeding. Consequently disposing of it would represent a fodder sale and it is only correct that such revenue should be offset against any subsidy entitlement.

The amendment proposed by the Opposition, which the Government opposes, raises a series of matters. It is what we may term a pious amendment. An attempt is not being made to deny the Bill a second reading but rather to express views of the Senate concerning it. The views laid down in the amendment that has been moved by Senator Walsh are threefold: Firstly, that a limit should be set on the sum that any individual may receive in any one year; secondly, that eligibility should be determined by placing a ceiling on total assets instead of the proposed liquidity test; and, thirdly, that those who are predominatly dependent on their farms for a living should be objectively defined.

If I may comment on the proposed amendment, it is true that neither the interest subsidy scheme nor the fodder subsidy scheme are subject to an absolute upper limit. However, in a practical sense both have limits. I touched on one of these in my remarks earlier. The fodder subsidy is restricted to $8 per month per head of cattle and 80c per month per head of sheep. This is quite clearly a limit that is related to the number of stock being carried by the farmer. If one placed an absolute limit on the subsidy, regardless of the number of stock carried, it would defeat the purpose of th scheme. If the purpose is to avoid destocking, those with large flocks or herds would not be eligible for the subsidy and may well have to destock. The purpose of maintaining our flocks and herds, particularly of breeding stock, is one with which there is no quarrel, although the Opposition says that it should be restricted to breeding stock. But what the Opposition's amendment is really saying is that we should retain the stock that happen to be in small herds and flocks but not that which happens to be in larger herds and flocks. Alternatively, the Opposition is saying that, by definition, those who have larger herds have the resources to maintain them- which is not, in my view, a self-evident truth.

The interest rate subsidy applies only to farm debt before 31 August 1982 or to carry-on loans obtained after that date. The size of the farm enterprise itself determines, in practical terms, the maximum amount of interest that a farm operator could be required to pay and, accordingly, the maximum amount of subsidy that the Government could be required to meet. Earlier I made the point that when a person is receiving an interest rate subsidy of, say, 4 per cent as in the example that Senator Walsh gave, that person is himself directly responsible for the initial 12 per cent of interest. The size of a primary producer's problem, as far as debt is concerned, is often related to the size of his enterprise and the Government's concern is to prevent viable farmers being forced off their properties. In that sense, the size of the operation is irrelevant. Therefore, the Government opposes that part of the proposed amendment.

The second proposal is that eligibility should be determined by placing a ceiling on total assets instead of imposing the proposed liquidity test. If I may be brief, where the objective of the exercise is to prevent the need for properties to be disposed of in drought circumstances, clearly, if one requires a farmer to exhaust or dispose of other than readily realisable financial assets , the objectives will not be met. The subsidy applies only in the case in which the 12 per cent interest payment, which is the responsibility of the farmer, is available from his readily realisable financial assets. So, in the view of the Government, the ceiling imposed is appropriate, given the desire to avoid the need for people to leave their properties because of this very severe and, we hope, unusual drought.

As for the proposal that those who are predominantly dependent on their farms for their living should be objectively defined, there is no problem in defining who is eligible for the fodder subsidy. Of course, any person who has purchased fodder for feeding to drought affected sheep or cattle which he owns is eligible to make a claim.

The philosophy of the interest subsidy scheme, as I said earlier, is to assist full time farmers to stay on their properties during a drought. Consequently, one of the eligibility conditions will be that a farm enterprise must have at least one person dependent on that farm's income for his or her livelhood. That is the judgment which will have to be made by those administering the scheme but it is not expected to create any great difficulty. It is the view of the Government that an objective definition is unworkable because the combination of circumstances is so wide as to almost certainly ensure that any tight definition would exclude some of those needing and deserving help and include others in another category. There is an element of discretion here which the Government believes it is not possible to avoid. I am grateful that the Senate supports the legislation in the broad. I regret that it is seen as defective in some respects by the Opposition. I take it from the speeches which have been made that there will be no desire on the part of the Senate to deny the Bill passage today.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be added (Senator Walsh's amendment) be added.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

speech.para: Original question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order. I should like to report to the Senate that I missed the division because I was in the office of the Minister for Health (Mr Carlton). In his secretary's section, the bells were not ringing. The lights obviously had been flashing for a while when it was brought to my attention that they were flashing. The bells were not ringing. I would like to have that matter examined. I offer that explanation to the Senate.
—Order! There is no point of order but the point has been taken. I hope that the Whips will take that into consideration.
—I seek leave to make a brief statement.
—As long as it is not on that subject.
—It is on that subject.
—You are pushing it a bit.
—I am sorry; I was just--
—Order! Is leave granted? There being no objection, leave is granted.

—The last time when I can recall an honourable senator making a similar explanation involved a Labor senator from Tasmania who was caught in the same circumstances. As I recall, we redivided on that basis. He was the yachtsman from Launceston, former Senator Devitt. That is my recollection. It occurred some years ago. In the light of that explanation, I wonder whether, by the leave of the Senate, the record of the division-it would be irrelevant to the result-might be amended to show Senator Walters as voting on the side of the noes.
—by leave-I do not think there is any need for that. Senator Walters's explanation has been noted and accepted. It is in Hansard immediately after the division.
—by leave-If one looks at the pairs for the last division one will see that the Government's numbers were correct-31 to 24. Maybe the Government Whip can tell us what happened.

—by leave-Just to have the record correct, the voting was 31 to 24. With the Democrats voting with the Government, the count should have been 32. Four senators from each side were paired, the Government having sent someone out to make the pairing equal with the Opposition . So, in effect, the vote should have been 32 to 24. In any case Senator Walters has made an explanation. It does not make any difference.
—I respond from the Chair by saying that the point has been taken. The explanation by Senator Walters is recorded in Hansard. I think the attitude of the Government Whip is such that she is forgiven.

proctext.para: The Bill.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: —I wish to make a few remarks on clause 5 of the Drought Assistance (Primary Producers) Bill 1982 which authorises the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) to make agreements with the States. I think the comments will be appropriate. We do not yet know what type of agreement the Minister will make. I criticised the Bill at the second reading stage for that reason. It is customary, in circumstances such as this, to append to the Bill a schedule which lays down, at least in broad terms, the conditions of the agreement that will be made. That has not been done in this case for reasons that I made clear last night.

speech.para: I have considerable sympathy for the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney) for being sent in here on behalf of the Government to defend the indefensible. Under those circumstances, it is not surprising that he resorted to spurious or specious arguments. I will cite just one example of such an argument. Senator Chaney gave an excuse for imposing a liquidity test on eligibility, instead of an asset test. He stated that it was necessary to apply a liquidity test because, if an asset test were applied, people would be forced off farms, forced to slaughter all their stock, which would result in a substantial portion of the national breeding herd being destroyed, and so on.

Let us consider the situation of someone who owns a farm worth $1m or $5m-the same conditions still apply. Providing he has no cash, Senator Chaney has actually suggested that the alternatives facing such a farmer are either to receive the subsidy from the Government or to walk off the farm and destroy the animals. Really, what are banks for? A person who is without cash but who has very substantial collateral can borrow from a bank. A person who is already heavily indebted-particularly as banks might take a more pessimistic view of what collateral and equity a would-be borrower has in time of drought-qualifies for special finance anyway under pre-existing joint Commonwealth-State arrangements.

Senator Chaney also said in defence of this extraordinary measure-I do not think he actually put a time frame on it but he implied it-that it was a once in 30 years drought, a once in a lifetime drought, or something of that order, and that everybody knows that it will not be repeated every time there is a drought somewhere. I can tell Senator Chaney of one person who does not know that and that is the Minister for Agriculture in Western Australia, who was quoted in the Press last week as asserting-not just saying that he hoped it would happen, but asserting-that this is what would happen. Mr Old said that this is the ground rule for the future; that the next time there is a drought in Western Australia the Western Australian farmers will get the same conditions, will receive assistance identical to that now being provided in the eastern States. So certainly everybody does not know that it is a one-off, once in a lifetime, situation. I will certainly ensure that Mr Old and other people in Western Australia are aware that they have now been told by Senator Chaney, on behalf of the Government, that the next time there is a drought in Western Australia, say of the type there was in 1980, assistance identical to this certainly will not be made available.
Senator Scott made a point regarding the ludicrous suggestion that came from this dopey Minister-

talk.start.para: —Order!

—I withdraw, Mr Chairman. The ludicrous suggestion or demand that came from Mr Nixon that a $3 per head subsidy be paid to farmers who destroy their sheep was followed by a great deal of criticism from Mr Nixon of the New South Wales and Victorian governments for not going along with such a silly idea . Senator Scott attempted to defend the proposal on the most extraordinary grounds. He said:

speech.para: At least with a $3 slaughter subsidy there will be a base in the market-place and a stop to any form of needless slaughter.

It is extraordinary to suggest that if we pay somebody $3 to destroy a sheep he will be less likely to destroy it than if he is not paid $3 to do it. The structure of incentives that is supposed to govern a market economy has just been stood on its head by Senator Scott. I am not particularly surprised that that sort of illogical reasoning or divorcement from reality is a popular view, or at least a view that exists, in the National Party. However, it is much more serious and much more alarming when views marginally less irrational than that are reflected in legislation, as they are reflected in this legislation.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —The points raised by Senator Walsh are really more points in reply than perhaps points in Committee debate. He posed the interesting question: What are banks for? I did meet one cynic who said that banks are there mainly to lend you money when you do not need it and send you to a finance company when you do. I do not adopt that attitude. The question of the availability of finance when one is in severe financial difficulty is one which I know has been addressed by the Minister for Primary Industry (Mr Nixon) who, in a recent release, has indicated that in the past the banks have been prepared to look at the interests of the rural community in these circumstances and expressed either the hope or the confident expectation that they would on this occasion.

speech.para: As far as assistance to Western Australia is concerned, recently I looked at the measures of drought relief extended to Western Australia during a period of what was very significant drought in that State. In some of the grain producing areas there were farmers who did not get a crop for four consecutive years and, bearing in mind the cost of sowing, that is a very significant and severe situation. I cannot recall precisely all of the measures which were extended with respect to drought relief in Western Australia during that period but I can at least remind the Senate of the fact that carry-on finance and the limits to carry-on finance were increased significantly as that drought continued over a period of years. In other words there was then, as there is now, a preparedness on the part of the Government to respond flexibly and to introduce measures which are not standard measures. I made the comment in the response to the second reading debate that we do have a national system for dealing with drought relief. It is principally within the bounds of the policies which we have with respect to natural disasters. We accept that the States substantially administer drought relief measures. We stand, as the Commonwealth, prepared to contribute on a regular three for one basis once the States have made their own preliminary contribution.

Western Australia had a severe drought. It was not part of a nation-wide drought. Measures were taken to respond to the particular difficulties which were faced in my State of Western Australia at that time. I have put the view that the measures which have been introduced this year in a case of drought across most of the pastoral and agricultural areas of Australia have been introduced to meet the particular needs of 1982 and that these are not measures which are put forward as standard drought relief measures for every drought circumstance which might arise in the future.

I do not think there is anything further on which I wish to comment. I do not wish to recanvass the limits which exist for the provision of assistance with respect to both the interest rate subsidy and the fodder subsidy. The interest rate subsidy is one which is geared to picking up a part only, that part in excess of 12 per cent, of debt related to the farming activity in circumstances in which there are limited liquid assets available to the farmer. The fodder subsidy has its own inbuilt monthly limit per head of stock. This represents the maximum that any farmer can seek and obtain.

speech.speaker: McLaren Sen G.T.

talk.start.para: —I will not take the time of the chamber for very long. Firstly, I should like to thank Senator Chaney for the way in which he responded to my proposal that a register should be kept of recipients of drought relief. I think he said in reply that there might be some difficulty in breaking down such a register into postcode areas. I would not think that would create a great difficulty. It we can get it down into regions, it is not a very great step from there to getting it into postcode areas. This is a matter which has been brought to my attention by people in drought areas, not in this drought but at other times of drought, when drought relief has been administered by the States. People have come to me wanting to know why certain other people have been the recipients of certain drought relief. I was not able to tell them whether the people mentioned got drought relief or not. It might be that some recipient or non-recipient has been bragging about the amount of relief he got and this has created a certain amount of jealousy in a person who really needs relief and for some reason or other did not qualify and did not get it. So if we are able to have the register kept, I think it would be of assistance. My suggestion was that the names be made available, if need be to either the shadow Minister for Primary Industry or the Leader of the Opposition in either House on a confidential basis, to overcome the problem. It would probably save a lot of heartburning for many farmers who have complained to me-I might say that there have been more than one-and who are in desperate straits. They may be told by some of their neighbours that they in fact are getting X amount of dollars in drought relief when the people who see me have found it very difficult to get any assistance at all. I look forward to Senator Chaney's proposal going forward to the responsible Minister. We will see what happens in the future. I hope that we do not have to take any action to have that information made available to us.

speech.para: Bill agreed to.
Bill reported without amendment; report adopted.

debate.title: DIESEL FUEL TAXES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 19 October, on motion by Senator Sir John Carrick:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —May I take this opportunity to suggest a cognate debate? There is a series of diesel fuel excise Bills, three in all. I understand that it would meet the convenience of the Opposition and the Government if we had a cognate debate on the three Bills.
—There being no objection, I shall allow that course to be followed.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: —The package of Bills now being debated gives effect to the diesel fuel rebate arrangements that were outlined by the Treasurer (Mr Howard) in the Budget in August. Under the old system, nearly all of the distillate consumed for other than road transport purposes was exempt from the excise by way of a certificate of exemption. The new arrangements ensure that the purchaser will pay the excise at the time of buying the fuel and a number of eligible purchasers will subsequently have that excise refunded to them when they complete the required forms and clerical work. All diesel fuel sold since 17 August has had the excise to all consumers added to it. An amendment was made by the Government in the House of Representatives to enable faster lodgment and processing of the claims for rebate and, more importantly, to allow the rebate to be paid after the fuel is purchased but before it is actually used, whereas the original Bill required that the fuel be consumed before the purchaser became eligible for the rebate. Some other amendments were made to expedite the processing and lodgment of claims by small users.

speech.para: The major categories of off-road users who are eligible for the new exemption arrangements are in the industries of mining, agriculture, forestry and fishing, and in a few other areas such as domestic hospitals, aged persons homes and nursing homes. There was another amendment added to the Bill in the House of Representatives to provide a rebate for sawmills. It is estimated that a total of $112m per year will be claimed under the rebate arrangements.

I notice that Senator Scott, who spoke on the Drought Assistance (Primary Producers) Bill, is not to speak on this one. For many years it has been the custom of the National Party to take the credit for everything popular in the countryside which coalition governments introduced-which, I suppose, Senator Scott was doing last night-and then to leave the Liberals to carry the can when they introduce something that is not popular, such as this Bill. To be fair, I do note that Senator Collard is listed to speak on this matter later on. Senator Thomas is also on the list to speak. But I am interested to hear what Senator Collard will have to say. The point I was making was that Senator Scott apparently represents the old Country Party style-let the Liberals carry the can for everything that is unpopular and take all the credit for everything that is popular. I am happy to note that Senator Collard, at least to some extent, has changed that rule.
Debate interrupted.

debate.title: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

debate.sub1.title: Report on Retail Trading Hours in the Australian Capital Territory

proctext.para: Debate resumed.

speech.speaker: Colston Sen M.A.

talk.start.para: —The Senate has before it the report of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory on Retail Trading Hours in the Australian Capital Territory. The Chairman of the Committee, Senator Reid, has moved that the Senate take note of the report. This report had its genesis in the Review of Commonwealth Functions, which now seems to be a long time ago. The Review of Commonwealth Functions mentioned that shopping hours should be deregulated. Subsequently legislation-which became the Commonwealth Functions ( Statutes Review) Act of 1981-was brought before the Senate to bring that deregulation into being. It is worth while reporting that at the time that legislation was brought forward the new senators elected at the 1980 election had not taken their places. So, although the electorate had given an indication that it wanted the composition of this place to be changed, the Government took the opportunity while it still had a majority to pass that legislation. Section 90 of the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act repealed the Trading Hours Ordinance of 1962. After the legislation was passed the Parliamentary Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory inquired into trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory. The terms of reference given to the Committee were:

speech.para: The Committee is asked to consider and report on:

'The manner in which deregulation of retail trading hours in the Australian Capital Territory pursuant to Section 90 of the Commonwealth Functions (Statutes Review) Act 1981, might be implemented having regard to the effect on retailers, employees and consumers'.

I stress the words 'might be implemented'. The Committee did not have to consider that it would be implemented; it had to inquire into how it might be implemented. After the Committee was given its terms of reference it carried out an extensive inquiry. Public hearings were held in Canberra, Sydney and Melbourne, and the Committee also travelled to the Northern Territory to examine retail trading in Alice Springs and Darwin. The Committee went to the two latter places because of the peculiar situation pertaining to them in that they allow trading to be almost deregulated.

I dissented from the majority decision outlined in the Committee's report. My dissent was the same as that of Mrs Kelly and Mr Fry, members of the House of Representatives. In particular, we dissented from paragraph 225 of the Committee 's majority report. That paragraph states:
. . . the Committee recommends that:
(1) the present Trading Hours Ordinance 1962 be repealed and replaced by an alternative ordinance.
(2) a new Trading Hours Ordinance be drafted to include the following provisions:
The sale of all goods in the ACT be permitted at any time except that a major retailer may not open for business between midnight Saturday and midnight Sunday .
A major retailer is defined as a retailer employing more than 100 people in the ACT or elsewhere in Australia in any number of shops.

Those of us who submitted the dissenting report believe that the evidence presented to the Committee is contrary to the recommendations in paragraph 225 of the report. In fact, in our dissenting report we said:
The evidence did not establish any demand for changing the present Ordinance; rather it overwhelmingly opposed deregulation.
We went on to outline the extent of opposition to deregulation. In paragraph 2 of the dissenting report we said:

Approximately 4000 shoppers, 200 small traders, the Australian Association of Independent Businesses and the Shop Distributive and Allied Employees Union wrote to the Committee to register their total opposition to deregulation.
As well as that, we pointed out in our minority report that there was no demand in the evidence for change. We said:
In contrast with the strong opposition to deregulation, there has been no public demand for a change in Canberra's trading hours.

Those who submitted the dissenting report were concerned about price increases which might take effect if deregulation took place. It is pertinent that I quote from paragraph 8 of the dissenting report because it is important to all consumers in the Australian Capital Territory. We said:

We consider that the evidence indicated that the cost of goods to consumers will rise if trading hours are extended. David Jones provided evidence that Saturday afternoon trading would result in an increase in the price of goods of around 1.5%. Waltons has calculated a 13.3% increase in payroll costs associated with Saturday afternoon trading. Such an increase would put pressure on prices. As well, small traders argued strongly that increased overheads as a result of increased trading hours would inevitably result in higher prices to consumers.

We could see no evidence that enabled the Committee to conclude that increased sales would offset these increased costs. I refer honourable senators to paragraph 9 of the dissenting report which takes that point to greater length. I refer also to paragraph 12, in which Mrs Kelly, Mr Fry and I point out the social effects of deregulation in Canberra. We said that deregulation would:
(a) reduce opportunities for full-time employment;
(b) increase the price of goods to the consumer;
(c) seriously disadvantage and threaten the viability of small traders; and
(d) cause disruption to family life of employees and reduce opportunities for sporting and religious pastimes on weekends.

I could expand on those at great length but unfortunately, although we were told when the tradng hours inquiry started that we would be allowed in this place to have a full debate-we were given that assurance by the Minister for Veterans' Affairs, Senator Messner-we now have only 10 minutes each to speak to this report. Therefore, in conclusion I would like to say something about the dissenting report submitted by my colleague, Senator Georges. I do have some sympathy with one of the recommendations in his dissenting report. In paragraph 1 (b) he says:
the present trading Hours Ordinance is to be gradually re-enforced and that sufficient resources be made available for this purpose.

Although I have sympathy for the remarks of Senator Georges, a pattern of retailing has been established in the Australian Capital Territory due to a lack of enforcement by the Department of the Capital Territory and, in my view, and I am sure in the view of my two fellow dissenters, it would create hardship to revert to what should have been enforced. In view of my dissenting report, I now move:
At end of motion add:
', but the Senate agrees with the views and the conclusions expressed in the Dissenting Report by Mrs R. J. Kelly, MP, Mr K. L. Fry, MP and Senator Colston'.

speech.speaker: Harradine Sen B.

talk.start.para: —I understand that an arrangement has been made-it is satisfactory to me-that honourable senators will be allowed 10 minutes in which to speak on these issues. This is due to the pressure of Government business. I make the point that the Government, through the Minister for the Capital Territory (Mr Hodgman), gave an undertaking not to do anything before full debate takes place on the report of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory. That being so, I expect that nothing adverse to the current situation will be done. The Minister can take a course of action which is in support of the current situation, of course, but he should not do anything that would be considered adverse to it until we complete our debate next week. I hope that the Minister will do what is suggested in this report; that is, refer the matter to the Australian Capital Territory House of Assembly- and will go further and, as has been suggested in one of the minority reports, reinforce the current ordinance. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.

speech.para: Leave granted; debate adjourned.
