debate.title: STANDING COMMITTEE ON EDUCATION AND THE ARTS

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 9 September, on motion by Senator Teague:
That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.speaker: Ray Sen R.

talk.start.para: —The report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on the tenure of academics was put down in the Senate on 9 September. Because we have had Estimates committees to attend and a variety of other activities to perform on Thursdays this is the first opportunity that a member of the Australian Labor Party has had to respond to the report and to highlight what we regard as important in it. I think that the initial reason for the inquiry into the tenure of academics came from a belief that many young potential academics had no future at all. Very few job opportunities are available for young people seeking a career of an academic nature. It was claimed that that was partly due to having tenure for academic positions, that such tenure blocks out younger people because, with tenure, people can continue in employment until they are 60 or 65 years of age.

speech.para: I think that the main conclusion in the Committee's report on tenure is that tenure is not the reason at all for the blockage for young academics. In the 1960s and the 1970s we saw a very rapid expansion in higher education not only in universities but also in colleges. That expansion has come to a halt. There is stagnation now in those areas. Therefore, there are no opportunities for many potential staff members. There are several reasons for this lack of opportunity. I believe the first is that there is a very low turnover in academic staff. Most people who become academics like the lifestyle; they are committed to that lifestyle and do not leave it readily. Whereas one might expect a turnover of 10 or 15 per cent in certain occupations, the tendency is for it to be 5 per cent or lower in institutions of higher education.

The second reason there is not that sort of expansion any more is simply that the Government has embarked on a program of financial stringency. The higher education areas have suffered fairly drastically because of that. I am not saying that in all cases financial stringency was not warranted; nevertheless, it has contributed to very few increases being made in staff. I will not explore what that has meant to the community as a whole-it has limited higher education to 10 per cent of the total youth of this country-as it would be more appropriate to do that at another time.

I now turn to the recommendations in the report. The Committee recommended that there be continual review procedures. We recommend two types of procedures: Firstly, that an academic's performance be monitored after a year, mainly to see whether that academic is performing as the institution requires. There is no doubt that it would be envisaged that at the start of the year the duties of an academic would be outlined by the head of the department or the professor concerned and that at the end of the year there would be some monitoring to see whether that academic had performed as required. The second procedure we recommended was that there be a seven-year review of academic performance. One of the criticisms that the Committee received, I think, was that once an academic got a job he was basically there for life and there was no review of his position. In virtually no other area of employment in Australia is there no review. Therefore, we recommended that every seven years some sort of a review occur.

We are not suggesting that witch hunts be launched, that people be driven out of their jobs or that they should be persecuted in any way. I think that this is the only recommendation that has received criticism from academics. They are not entirely happy with it, although it appears to me that they are generally happy with the report. The report does support tenure as a concept. It supports that because on all the evidence we heard we were convinced that for the continuation of academic freedom and higher education tenure was an essential aspect. Without tenure we could go to a situation that exists in many of the more totalitarian countries where people are not free to research and teach in the fields in which they want to.

I turn to some of the other points that came out of the report. The first concerns the Academic Salaries Tribunal. At the moment that body exists in Australia but really only has powers over a university in the Australian Capital Territory. All the other universities and colleges use that body as a body which actually makes recommendations. The Tribunal has only those recommendatory powers over salaries. It does not have the power to rule on other industrial conditions. It seems to me, and I think to other members of the Committee, that if we want a rational industrial relations atmosphere in higher education we can achieve it by vesting in the Academic Salaries Tribunal powers over all universities and colleges. We do not recommend that the Commonwealth Government try to impose that. Of necessity, to achieve that end would require negotiation between the States and the Commonwealth.

The second area we would like to emphasise where we found some resistance in certain witnesses is the importance of teaching in higher education. This is especially so in universities where most of the emphasis in terms of promotion and evaluation of an academic's performance tragically has been related to his or her performance in the research area. This is a trend which is changing. In the report, we highlight the fact that teaching has equal importance with research in terms of reviewing how well an academic is performing in any institution. We say that there should be some form of teacher training for academics. We hint that the ability to go out and teach others is not an inherent quality and say that there needs to be a development through in-service and other methods to develop those skills.

The main factor that the Committee has tackled in relation to tenure and its related subjects is the need to try to get more flexibility into the system to enable far greater numbers of people to be employed in that area over a period. The first recommendation in that regard relates to superannuation. There are already moves in the direction of setting up a national portable superannuation scheme. The sooner that is done, the quicker we will have far greater flexibility within the higher education area. There are problems inasmuch as some academics are in State schemes. Work needs to be done to ensure that any national scheme equates with those State schemes if people are to move.

The second area on which we recommend concerns fractional appointments. I think that they will do a lot to increase flexibility. Not every academic wants to work full time. At the moment they do not have the opportunity to accept fractional appointments. The third recommendation is in relation to early retirement. That option should at least be available and if there is proper superannuation that can be encouraged. If young academics are to be brought into higher education, that cannot be done unless more positions are made available by people retiring. Of all the trends we have examined, of all the future age profiles, that is going to be a very difficult aspect in the next 10 or 15 years . If we do not start bringing in young academics now, there will be a crisis in tertiary education where suddenly all those who joined in the 1960s and the 1970s will in a short period be resigning from academia and we will be left with a similar burst of having to get in at that stage replacements who perhaps will not be the very best people.

One of the other points that the Committee makes is the importance of retraining academics. It is not always possible, given the varied disciplines that exist in higher education, for that to occur easily. But one presumes that, if there were a surplus of history teachers and history academics in this country, there might be some way one could rewire them to go into philosophy or some related subject. That would not be easy. It is hard to take a Latin teacher and make him a maths teacher or anything else. Nevertheless, that sort of retraining should be one of the steps.

Overall, I think the tenure report has come up with a fairly bland set of recommendations. We did not set out to sensationalise the issues involved or to aggravate any particular section in higher education. The one point I would like to make is that the various accusations that were made that a lot of academics are bludgers was not proved to my satisfaction in any form. Certain suggestions were made that many people were time serving in higher education. I did not find evidence of that. I have no doubt there may be one or two but in general the academics have performed in a very capable and dedicated manner. The retention of tenure for them is a condition, almost an industrial condition, that makes that area attractive. The salary ranges in academia do not necessarily match those in the outside community; so a factor such as tenure does a lot to maintain the very best in higher education.

speech.speaker: Reid Sen M.E.

talk.start.para: —In relation to the report of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts on tenure, I certainly agree with the latter remarks of Senator Robert Ray that we did not find evidence of the suggestions that he just referred to. I think that is worth recording. The first of the general arrangements for tenure in the report states :

speech.para: The arrangements for tenure in universities and colleges of advanced education should ensure that tenure is only granted after exacting and sound appointment and probation procedures have been fully met.

I think that that point is something that needs to be noted. That is not to say that we found that it had not been; but it needs to be re-stated that tenure is not something that should be taken for granted: It is something that must apply and must be available for the security of academics. It should not, I repeat, be taken for granted.

The matter I wish to refer to in particular is the question of portability of superannuation. To create the security needed to enable or encourage people in academia to shift from one university to another, security in the form of portability of superannuation is required. There is a risk of stifling academic achievement if people feel that once they have gained tenure in a university they need to stay there to secure their future. I think that is a pity and something that is not desirable. It seemed to me, from the whole of the inquiry, that the one element that was of prime importance was to see that those responsible sit down and put as their very highest priority the working out of a superannuation scheme which can be flexible and portable among the various institutions. The technicalities which make that impossible must be ironed out. They can only really be technicalities. With good will, the administrators of the tertiary institutions can find a way around this problem to the benefit of all.

There is one academic in particular to whom I refer. He is Dr David Cohen who, apparently, is associate professor of education at Macquarie University. The Daily Telegraph of 11 September 1982 stated that he hit back at the review plan that the Committee put up. The Committee recommended that there should be a review of academics who were tenured and that their performance should be monitored by the peer group from time to time. The article stated:
Politicians who want to make university academics go through an annual ' inspection' to keep their jobs, should be subject to the same, says a senior academic.
That is Dr Cohen. That, of course, was not the recommendation of this Committee.

I would like to tell Dr Cohen that, although he may be worthy of the greatest respect as a professor of education, it is fairly clear that he knows nothing about politics. If he knew anything about politics, the system of endorsement by one's party and the requirement to face the electorate at all too regular intervals, he would know that the system of inspection that we are suggesting for academics is just not in the same class as we face at very regular intervals . It is the sort of comment-I know it is amusing in that sense-that just is not helpful when it comes to looking at a report like this, which Senator Robert Ray has described as bland, and perhaps it is. I think this report is a responsible review of the tertiary institutions that goes into the matter in depth. I recommend the conclusions that we came to. It does not really add anything to have an academic come out in the Press with a statement as absurd as that. It reflects rather badly on academia and, as I said, I think that is rather a pity.
All of the recommendations I support, but the one I have briefly referred to- portability of superannuation-I see as a very significant one that I do recommend to those responsible.

speech.speaker: Macklin Sen M.J.

talk.start.para: —Those honourable senators who have spoken in this debate on the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts report on tenure of academics are members of that Committee. I suppose in some way they feel a certain priority right over their report. I feel that possibly Senator Robert Ray's comments that it is a bland report may be praise. Certainly, I do not think one could find terribly much in it to take great exception to. Indeed I think the way in which it has been received by various bodies, such as the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations and by the various vice- chancellor committees and most of the universities, would suggest that they also do not find terribly much to object to in it. However, I think my disappointment with the report is that the problems that the Committee had to face have in some way been put aside.

speech.para: There are very real problems which come through time and again in the Hansard reports of the Committee's discussions about a steady state situation and developing talent to enter universities at a steady rate so we do not have what might be called a bulge occurring at certain stages followed by a dearth of qualified people. What types of arrangements are able to be made so that young academics are able to train in a rigorous atmosphere and in their turn take on a teaching role within a university? That poses very difficult problems and I acknowledge that difficulty.

I suppose I was hoping that the Committee, after all its deliberations, would have been able to come up with a breakthrough suggestion in its report. I do not have one. I think that yet again we will have to wait for that breakthrough suggestion on what is an exceedingly difficult problem confronting our entire tertiary sector. I think that, in a sense, the tenure element of this matter is peripheral. I do not believe that if tenure were not available we would have a much greater turnover than we currently have. I do not believe its removal would solve the problems concerning the younger enthusiastic academics coming along. It would not provide a large number of places through senior academics being moved on because in some way they are unproductive. This sort of thing does not occur in these organisations. It is exceedingly difficult in private enterprise to move the top cookies. Once they get on the boards they stay there. Whether or not they are producing the goods, they certainly produce the reports which say they are producing the goods and there is not much that one can do about it. I do not think this situation applies only to the universities as such. Possibly it is a reflection of institutional arrangements more than anything else. I suppose that in that sense, having read the report, I was disappointed that the Committee was not able to come up with a breakthrough suggestion in that area.

I think the Committee probably dropped into the too hard basket problems about voluntary retirement and how it might be dealt with. It did not deal with something that one of the people who gave evidence before the Committee talked about; that is, the less effective academic. In fact, Professor Harcourt said that, taken as a whole, blind Freddie could get a job in the 1960s. I do not think that is an accurate statement but I believe that in any organisation there are people whose effectiveness falls off. Unfortunately, I have always felt that the only people who can do a thorough job of getting rid of such academics are the people in the institutions themselves and they are the people who are less capable of doing it.

A previous speaker commented that if we were looking at getting rid of the ineffective people in this Parliament the people who work in the Parliament probably would be able to draw up a range of criteria and point the finger at whom it might be best to get rid of. They would probably be more effective than anybody else, particularly if the decisions were not taken on party lines. This is simply because those people know the institution, know how it works and know which people are working effectively within the institution. Likewise, in the case of academia, I think the institution itself would contain the best people to get rid of academics. Therefore, I support the notion of peer assessment. I looked in vain for a reasoned, comprehensive suggestion about how this might be done. Again, I am not suggesting that I know the answer. I know that this is one of the most difficult industrial problems into which one could wander. But it is a problem that at some stage we will have to tackle. Therefore, on that count, I again express my disappointment that the Committee was not able to find a way around this problem.

The incremental creep in terms of cost structures was dealt with only in a peripheral way. I suppose it was in fact tangential to the purpose of the Committee and hence the Committee did not take a comprehensive view of it. Therefore, I do not think the Committee can be criticised in any way in this regard. However, I believe that if one looks at the economics of tertiary institutions one will find that this is likely to become one of the most telling problems. Indeed, within the last week the Vice-Chancellor of the University of Queensland, while congratulating the Government for picking up the latest problem in terms of the rise granted by the Academic Salaries Tribunal, said that probably all the Government has managed to do is shift the problem to next year's Budget. At some stage the crunch is going to come. That can be put off by making ad hoc decisions each year, but the incremental creep in terms of cost structures, as the entire academic community gets older, within institutions will necessarily add to costs. We had stability previously because there was a greater turnover and as a result people came in at the bottom rung of a lectureship situation.

I know of one faculty within the University of Queensland that has not appointed a new lecturer, senior lecturer, reader or professor in the last 15 years. That is absolutely amazing. This problem has roots which go a fair way back. If one contemplates that this situation is more widespread than in one or two faculties, one is really confronted with an enormous problem of finding jobs and providing training for these people. Indeed, if one knows the structure of those institutions, one must assume that there must be a dramatic falloff in research activity. This is simply because, although the professors may put their names to a lot of work, the tutors, the post-graduate students and the young lecturers who are trying to get tenure are the ones who do a lot of the scrabbling and the furious paddling under the water. In a sense the research activity, the innovative work, is done between the older experienced people and the younger enthusiastic ones who need to earn a living. If we break that balance we break the institutional methodology of doing research in universities . I believe that this has been broken simply by the economics of what we are now talking about. Unfortunately-this is not a criticism of the Committee-the Committee itself was not able to come up with anything more than suggestions such as 'we should give favourable consideration to' or 'we should look very deeply at' or a range of other propositions.

However, I think that the Committee has offered one extremely useful and important element in that it came down on the side of tenure in a very firm and definitive way. If we can put aside the fear that that is threatened, we may clear the air enormously. This report may have done a great service in that regard. We can then move on to the other serious problems, having put aside that rather contentious area.

speech.speaker: Teague Sen B.C.

talk.start.para: —in reply-It falls to me as Chairman of the Senate Standing Committee on Education and the Arts and the person who tabled the report in the Senate on 9 September to sum up the debate and to make some final comments of my own. About 12 months ago the Senate referred to the Committee this national inquiry into the tenure of employment of academics in Australia's universities and colleges. We conducted the inquiry and a month ago we brought down the report. There has been a degree of public response to the report and we have reflected on that in our remarks here today. Three members of the Committee have brought particular matters to the attention of the Senate with more emphasis. For example, Senator Robert Ray referred to the Academic Salaries Tribunal and Senator Reid referred to superannuation. We could also have referred to important sections of the report, such as women academics and how to ensure that there is greater participation by women in our university and college staffs, and to important but minor matters such as the importance of student opinion and of taking into account, when teaching and other academic matters are being assessed, properly or conducted student surveys and other student opinions.

speech.para: In my mind there are really two themes in this report-renewal and accountability. How are we to ensure by our staff appointment processes and the arrangements for tenure that renewing, lively, creative, innovative and truly worthy academic staff will be engaged in teaching and research in our universities and colleges? To ensure accountability, are we able publicly to give assurances that the academics employed in our universities and colleges are living up to the highest traditions of teaching and research and are accountable to one another as corporate universities or corporate colleges? Insofar as public funds support universities and colleges are they accountable to the public at large?

These matters are, I believe, sensitively and soundly dealt with in the report. It is certainly gratifying to the six senators who conducted the report and the staff who assisted us that there has been such an overwhelmingly positive response from all sections of the Australian community. The Australian Vice- Chancellors Committee, the Commonwealth Tertiary Education Commission, the colleges of advanced education principals and their staff and the university governing bodies and senior staff have been amongst those who have written or spoken directly to me as Chairman of the Committee in a very positive way. Some students too have made positive statements to me. Apart from Professor Cohen, whose comments Senator Reid noted had been reported in a Sydney newspaper very briefly and tangentially, the only bodies which have been critical, and then only of some aspects of the report, have been the Federation of Australian University Staff Associations and the Federation of College Academics- understandably so. They always want to shore up in any negotiations or developments what they feel would be best for their members. They have been a little critical on a few matters.

We now look to the Australian Government to give a direct response to this report. Normally that would be expected within six months. I urge the Government to respond, if possible before the end of this sitting but only if that gives sufficient time, in the Government's judgment, for public responses to be taken into account by it. The Government should respond very soon. The Committee's direct recommendation is that the Government fully endorse the 39 recommendations which the Committee has arrived at. As a government senator wearing other hats I see no difficulty in the Government endorsing the 39 recommendations because I believe that would give the final seal of support to a report that has been well received by the public and, as has been seen by this debate, in the Senate. With that seal of approval or endorsement it would then be a question of the governing bodies of our 19 universities and our 40 or so colleges, by their own lights and judgments and with their understanding of the report, implementing it in the coming months.

I say 'in the coming months' because I believe the recommendations in the report for the most part can be achieved by the middle of the next academic year . There are some bench-marks concerning the proportion of academics who are tenured, tutors and other academic staff that may not be achieved within a year or two, but certainly the trend can be established. The governing councils can determine that the goal of an institution is to reach in a practical way the goals that have been set out in this report. I will not quote letters that I have received as Chairman, many of them addressed to the whole body of the Committee, but phrases such as 'excellent report' and 'sound analysis' have even been a little embarrassing. I believe that the Committee which has built up a sound reputation within Australia for careful and considered reports has reinforced that reputation with this report on tenure.

Very briefly, there are five matters on which there have been particular comments to which I will respond. Some people have said that we have not allowed sufficient flexibility in universities and colleges having as our bench-mark that no more than 90 per cent of academics should be tenured, the other 10 per cent being on contracts. Some people have urged that this proportion could well have been 85 per cent. I can say only that the Committee has carefully and responsibly urged that the figure of 90 per cent be accepted because we believe it is achievable and realistic. If after a few years the monitoring of the tenure aspect of our acedemic institutions by the CTEC leads us to have a further discussion in the Senate, I am sure we will be quite flexible and open to see whether there is merit in moving towards 85 per cent as an amended bench- mark.

Some people felt that the Committee was not firm enough on the question of redundancy because, in our recommendations, we have urged that where there is financial exigency in an institution and if there is not enough money to pay salaries, the first staff to go should be those seen to be most redundant. However, we have not directly recommended that if a tenured staff member seems to be redundant in that the student load in an area has gone down markedly his appointment be terminated on that ground alone. I believe we will again see what case can be made by institutions. We may reconsider that question because certainly we do not want to see staff inactive and not achieving the purpose of their institutions. It seems that my time is up. I can only urge the Commonwealth Government in its response to endorse fully the recommendations of the report.
Question resolved in the affirmative.

debate.title: SELECT COMMITTEE ON INDUSTRIAL RELATIONS LEGISLATION

debate.title: JOINT COMMITTEE ON FOREIGN AFFAIRS AND DEFENCE

debate.sub1.title: Report: 'An Aircraft Carrier for the Australian Defence Force'

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 26 August, on motion by Senator Sibraa:
That the Senate take note of the report.

speech.speaker: Collard Sen S.J.

talk.start.para: —On 26 August, when this report was first introduced, I spoke for two minutes about paragraph 2.23 on page 25, which rather offhandedly discards the abilities of the Sea Harrier. On that day I mentioned that the paragraph talked about range and made the comment that range can be whatever we want it to be, particularly when we are dealing with military aircraft. It depends on the configuration of the aircraft, the ordnance being carried, the drop tanks being carried and whether aerial refuelling is available . I understand that two Sea Harriers which served in the Falkland Islands were replenished at one stage by means of aerial refuelling: Firstly, while being flown from England to the Ascension Islands and, secondly, while being flown from the Ascension Islands to one of the carriers. They arrived, as I understand it, over the Falklands in the middle of an air raid. So merely to say blithely that an aircraft has limited range is a rather too casual attitude to take. As I said, they proved that given the right conditions, with aerial refuelling, they had a far greater range than have a lot of civilian aircraft.

speech.para: The paragraph is also critical of the aircraft's radar capabilities. I repeat, everybody recognises that it is a pulse radar system, with all the limitations that that involves, but it is the best that the state of the art can offer. Indeed, it proved itself in all-weather operations in the Falklands. Another all too casual comment was that the radar was 'incompatible with modern weapon systems'. Yet, the radar and the Sidewinder missile proved a good combination, as some of the Argentine pilots found out. I have been privileged to have had discussions with one of the pilots involved in that conflict. He said that within 15 seconds he had two Argentine aircraft to his credit. So the radar and missile system of the Sea Harrier proved pretty formidable indeed.

I found very hard to comprehend the statement that the Sea Harrier was 'alleged to have lesser agility than contemporary aircraft'. I have yet to find a more agile aircraft. To my knowledge, no other fixed-wing aircraft can go up or down, backwards, or come to a complete stop in flight, yet that statement is made. The last part of the paragraph states:

Because of the absence of any large-scale demand for the aircraft, although the US Marine Corps remains interested in a ground attack variant, it is unlikely that there will be any significant development of the aircraft in the short-term .

I do not know where the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence got its evidence. To my knowledge at least 800 Sea Harriers; including both the AV8A and now the AV8B-variants of the original theme-are on the order books; probably more than that are on order. So we are looking at a production run of probably close to 1,000 aircraft, which is a pretty fair run for any sort of aircraft in use today whether it be in regular public tranport work, in the civil mode, or in defence.

As for the comment that 'it is unlikely that there will be any significant development of the aircraft in the short term' I understand that the Royal Navy is already planning an improved radar, probably of a pulse Doppler type, with which it will be possible to use AMRAAM-the Advanced Medium Range Air to Air Missile. This provides a very formidable weapons system indeed. In addition, Rolls-Royce-this information was obtained from discussions with that organisation-is looking at the re-heat possibilities. It has in mind a different type of re-heat-we know it as afterburning-from that used in all other aircraft, in which the afterburning is done in the tail pipe. This will be known as plenum chamber burning. It will use the bypass air from the front nozzles of the Harrier. This means that one begins with a base of very cold air, so the plenum chamber burning will be far more effective than effected by tail pipe afterburning.

Therefore it worries me to see in a report a paragraph with many glaring inaccuracies. Unfortunately, that calls into question the whole report. Obviously, it is the report of a Joint Committee. I do not believe that a Senate Standing Committee would have permitted such a large number of inaccuracies in one paragraph of a report. The inaccuracies worry me because the standard of the committee work undertaken by the Parliament, particularly that done by the Senate, is generally very high. When such inaccuracies can be pointed out the basis on which the whole report was prepared is called into question. I am particularly worried about that aspect. I seek leave to continue my remarks later.
Leave granted; debate adjourned.
(Quorum formed).

debate.title: PETROLEUM RETAILING MARKETING SITES AMENDMENT BILL 1982

proctext.para: Debate resumed from 23 September, on motion by Senator Chipp:
That the Bill be now read a second time.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen G.J.

talk.start.para: —With the apparent unwillingness of the Minister for Social Security (Senator Chaney), on behalf of the Government, at this stage to open up debate on the Petroleum Retailing Marketing Sites Amendment Bill 1982 which was introduced by Senator Chipp, I guess it falls to me to indicate what the Australian Labor Party's response is to Senator Chipp's Bill. I say at the outset that the subject matter of this Bill seems to have been the subject of a fairly intense Press release war conducted between Senator Chipp and the Labor party spokesman on business and consumer affairs, Mr John Brown, in recent weeks . I think it would be unfortunate if some aspects of that paper warfare were to intrude into this debate this afternoon. I refer in particular to an allegation which Senator Chipp has made about Mr Brown and the Labor Party which, I suspect , he might be tempted to make again this afternoon-that is, that any change of attitude on the Labor Party's part, as compared with the position we supposedly took on this issue two or three years ago, can only be the product of our being prisoners of the oil companies or our having sold our principles for some mess of pottage in the form of financial remuneration from the oil companies.

speech.para: All I say to that-I say it at the outset of my remarks-is that if Senator Chipp persists with that approach in his reply to the debate this afternoon he simply will be demeaning himself and certainly will be demeaning the quality of this debate, which is on an issue of some considerable community importance. There is no foundation whatsoever for any such allegation-that scarcely needs to be said. To the extent that the Labor Party may, for the moment anyway, be perceived as having in some respect modified its position on the question of support for the divorcement principle-

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order. I am finding it extremely difficult to hear the honourable senator and he is as close to me as he is to any honourable senator in the chamber. It must be very difficult for him.
—I take the point, Senator Robertson. There is far too much audible conversation in the chamber.
—I have now lost the thread of that sentence. To the extent-
—You were going to give us the reasons, other than money reasons for changing your mind.

—There will be plenty of other reasons to explain what is exactly the Labor Party's position. I hope right at the outset to set at rest that canard because I think it does nobody any justice, least of all Senator Chipp, to pursue it.

speech.para: The fundamentals of the Bill introduced by Senator Chipp concern the retail petroleum market and the question of who is entitled to control retail outlets in that market. I make the point, right at the outset again, that one cannot make judgments about the market in this respect in the abstract. One has to consider the economic forces that are at work in the petroleum cycle as a whole- oil prices, refinery production, consumer demand-and to consider the way in which all of these are affected by the regulation proposed at different stages in that cycle and, more particularly, the way in which they are affected at the particular time at which the regulation is being proposed.

I make it quite clear that the Opposition's primary concerns in deciding its approach to regulatory legislation in this area of petroleum marketing are twofold. First, the position of consumers-at the moment, those people who are prisoners of the prices at the petrol pump-and, secondly, the interests of those small business men and women who are the independant operators or franchisees in this area and who, obviously, have a great stake in the way in which this petroleum pricing regulatory legislation operates. Not only do they have a stake in it but also a large number of employees who work on the driveways of service stations around this nation have a stake in it.

The thrust of Senator Chipp's Bill, which will be familiar to those who have taken the trouble to study its very short compass, is to apply, with effect from 1 July next year, the principle of 100 per cent divorcement in the retail marketing situation. That is to say, from that date it is proposed by Senator Chipp that the oil companies will no longer be in a position of directly retailing, through commission agents, petrol on the service station driveways. We in the Labor Party oppose that proposal by Senator Chipp to the extent that it would require the more or less immediate achievement of the full 100 per cent divorcement principle. I will say something more later about our attitudes to divorcement generally and about where we think we ought to be going. We oppose Senator Chipp's immediate proposal although we will be making it abundantly clear, by the way in which we express that opposition and more particularly in the amendment which I hope has been circulated and which I will move at the Committee stage, that we are certainly not in any way interested in selling out or undermining the interests of the small business proprietors by virtue of a passionate enthusiasm for the predatory activities of the major oil companies.

The debate on this Bill makes sense only if one understands some fundamental things about the structure of the retail petroleum market. The situation is that , apart from the relatively small independent operations run by wholesale-retail groups such as ACTU-Solo, XL Petroleum Pty Ltd and one or two others, there are three basic categories of petrol retail outlets. In the first place, the largest category consists of lessee-operated stations owned by the oil companies themselves. The operators of these stations are known generically as franchisees . They lease the stations from companies and buy some, although not necessarily all, of their petrol from the company which owns the site that they lease. They pay a wholesale price to the oil company and set their own retail price. The second category is that of the independent owner-dealer stations who have no direct ties with any particular oil company, although almost invariably they have purchasing arrangements with a particular company. Again, they pay a wholesale price for the petrol from the major oil companies and set their own retail price.

The third category-it is really quite small in terms of numbers-is the category about which this whole debate revolves today. It represents only about 6 per cent of the total number of service station outlets-at the moment that is something like 600 out of 11,500 service station outlets in the country. These are the company-owned stations operated by commission agents. The commission agent collects a fixed amount on each litre of petrol sold with the retail price being set by the oil company itself. I will refer to these sorts of stations as company sites or directly-operated company sites. This is the category about which we are concerned in this Bill. This is the category of service stations which Senator Chipp's Bill seeks to wipe out from the marketing scene and to ensure that for the future or, as the Bill puts it, from July next year all service stations are run either as franchisee operations or on the basis of independent owner-dealership arrangements.

The wholesale price in the petroleum marketing industry is regulated by the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority which was established in December 1981 out of the wreckage of the Prices Justification Tribunal. That is the operation at the national level. In addition, we have some State government regulation of wholesale prices in South Australia and New South Wales. Retail prices are not controlled except in New South Wales and South Australia and, as I have said, can be set by individual retailers, although there are growing moves around the place-this is part of the problem of fragmentation in the industry at the moment -for Government intervention directly in the retail pricing.

Further background to the debate, particularly important in the light of the allegations made by Senator Chipp about fundamental changes in the Labor Party's position, is the 1980 legislation which followed upon the 1976 report of the Royal Commission on Petroleum and the famous Fife package of proposals of 30 October 1978.

That 1980 legislation dealt with two out of the three categories of retail outlet which I have referred to; namely, it dealt with the position of franchisees and it also dealt, in a way that Senator Chipp now seeks to amend, with the position of commission agents or company sites. That legislation contained nothing about the independent owner-dealer stations. As to franchisees , the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act of 1980 laid down certain rules to ensure that oil companies-franchisors-could not exploit franchisees, with protection given in the areas of obligatory disclosure, minimum terms for the operation of the franchise, and prohibitions on price discrimination by the oil companies.

So far as commission agents are concerned, the situation was established by the 1980 legislation as follows: Section 10, which Senator Chipp's Bill now seeks to amend, created a general prohibition on oil companies-or the so-called prescribed corporations-operating retail outlets. That absolute prohibition, however, was subject to a stated exception in sub-clause 10(3) and that exception was a provision that the companies were not to operate more than the maximum prescribed number of retail sites. In further provisions of the legislation, the prescribed number of sites was stated in a quota formula in such a way as to achieve a target of a divorcement of 50 per cent of the industry; that is, a divorcement, a cessation, of the direct selling role of the oil companies and 50 per cent of those companies' sites by September 1982.

There has been a series of complications and further developments as that process has worked itself out but basically that is what has happened. There has been a very significant divorcement, but it has not been achieved to the extent originally proposed and required in the legislation, and the September 1982 target date has not in fact been met. I understand it is proposed by the Government to introduce legislation quite soon to amend retrospectively that particular quota situation so as to allow until May next year for the number of company-owned sites to be reduced to the target of 50 per cent. A total of 401 sites is proposed to be achieved by May next year.

The Australian Labor Party's position on the 1980 legislation when it was introduced has been stated by Senator Chipp as amounting to support not only for the legislation but also for something rather more than that legislation provides, that is to say, the principle of complete 100 per cent divorcement. Certainly there have been statements by some ALP spokesmen from time to time which could be construed in that way.

talk.start.para: —By Chris Hurford.

—But not by Chris Hurford, the Labor spokesman on these matters, in the course of his presentation of the Opposition's response to that 1980 legislation. I specifically refer Senator Chipp in that respect to the full text of Mr Hurford's speech in the House of Representatives on 16 September 1980 when he made it perfectly clear and explicit, in the then detailed opportunity open to him on behalf of the Labor Party, what our position was.
—I will be quoting him in full; don't worry about that.

—Mr Hurford stated on 16 September that he doubted the legislation would survive two years in its present form. He moved a second reading amendment proposing that a review of the legislation take place within 18 months of its commencement with a view to deciding upon a further reduction of the number of sites operated by the major oil companies. That is true. That amendment also called for regulation of the prices charged by oil companies through their own sites. However, it did not in terms call for total divorcement, nor did Mr Hurford at any stage in that speech-I challenge Senator Chipp to point to any passage-call for total divorcement in the industry. The speech makes reference to total or partial divorcement as being an appropriate goal or target that ought to be pursued by all good men and true who are interested in getting some rationalisation in the industry and the protection not only of consumers but also of small businessmen whose activities were then undoubtedly being prejudiced by the behaviour-and the often predatory behavioir-of the major oil companies.
—He described the legislation as only a half measure. Half divorcement is only a half measure.
—He may have done so, but I am not going to swap arithmetical gambits with Senator Chipp. I make the point that there is a quite explicit reference in Mr Hurford's speech-
—Half divorcements are half measures; it is very clear.

—Senator Chipp can construe that in any way he likes. He will have plenty of opportunity to do so when he replies. I simply make the point that on that occasion Mr Hurford did not explicitly commit the Labor Party to do anything more than to set in train a review within a couple of years, to see how the process was working out, with a view undoubtedly to increasing the percentage of divorcement, given the situation as Mr Hurford, and indeed as the Labor Party, then saw it. However, there have been pronouncements from time to time by various spokesmen, I readily acknowledge, which have expressed our attitude to this matter-not in recent years; they tend to go back two or three years-in terms which make clear our commitment to the general principle of divorcement and which have gone further than this particular parent legislation now before us.

speech.para: But if Senator Chipp seeks to extract from the formal Labor Party statements at that time, or at any subsequent time, an absolute, unequivocal commitment to 100 per cent divorcement of a kind which reflects the situation that now prevails in the market-place, he will have a very difficult task. But that is all simply swapping debating points. The main thing we need to do is come to grips with the situation as it prevails at the moment. The main thing I need to do in order to advance this debate to a slightly more rational plane is to explain why at this time we oppose Senator Chipp's proposal for complete 100 per cent divorcement by July next year. We do so for what I think I can describe fairly succinctly as three basic reasons. Firstly, we do so in terms of the protection of the interests of consumers, at least so far as price protection is concerned. The second point relates to the protection of consumers in relation to other aspects of concern to them. Thirdly, I express our opposition in terms of concern we have about the unreality of the timetable contained in Senator Chipp's Bill.

Let us begin at the beginning with the position of the consumers-an interest group which extends over the nation at large. Reference to them and to their interests was conspicuously lacking in Senator Chipp's public pronouncement on this issue. He has been very vociferous, naturally and understandably, in support of the interests of the service station proprietors and the independent operators. But it seems to the Labor Party that he has not given equally enthusiastic attention to the interests of the consumers who, after all, are an even larger group of people in the Australian community. I am not suggesting for a moment that the interests of the operators should be ignored. But certainly the interests of consumers ought to rank rather higher than they seem to in Senator Chipp's approach so far. What we say so far as consumers are concerned is that, first of all, they are undoubtedly benefiting in price terms at the moment, although I readily acknowledge that that situation may change, from the direct presence of the oil companies in the retail market.

As we all know, there is a glut in the supply of petroleum products at the moment, much more so than was the case in 1980. That, in itself, would tend to force prices down in the retail market. But the reality is, as we all well know, that the main force in the market at the moment for keeping retail prices down, as can be confirmed by anyone who simply drives around the streets of the cities and towns of this nation with his eyes open, is the big gallonage outlets, by and large self-service, run by commission agents directly on behalf of the major oil companies. Each of them sell, on average, something like three times the volume of the other categories of service station outlets.

In the absence of these company sites, the likelihood seems to be that in the main service station operator associations, gathered as they are under the umbrella of the Australian Automobile Chamber of Commerce, would combine their forces to drive up the retail price of petrol. That has been, so far as we can discern, the experience elsewhere. In particular it has been the experience in the American State of Maryland, although the facts of that matter have been, I know, the subject of some disputation between Senator Chipp and Mr Brown. Certainly that seems a plausible expectation and it is one that, as far as I am aware, has not significantly been denied by any serious minded commentator on this whole difficult subject.

So on the immediate specific question of the price benefit that consumers are getting, looking at that criterion alone, it seems to me that Senator Chipp has a very difficult argument to beat in terms of the role that the major oil companies are playing through their direct selling outlets in keeping those prices down. I am not suggesting for a moment that that is the only relevant criterion to apply, but it is certainly an extremely important one so far as the consumers of this nation are concerned.

The second consideration which I think ought to come into question and which I think is a relevant touchstone for debate here is the extent to which consumers are arguably suffering in other than price terms at this stage. To the extent that they are suffering as a result of the presence in the market place of the direct selling companies, that is a situation that would cause profound concern and would undoubtedly demand the closest possible monitoring on our part and would almost by itself be a significant enough consideration to make us change our attitudes to Senator Chipp's Bill. But we take the view that there is no evidence that consumers are suffering in other than price terms at the moment.

We acknowledge that there is more to consumer protection than simply price levels. We acknowledge that there is a consumer interest which in this respect overlaps with that of the independent proprietors in maintaining a reasonable number of accessible sites and maintaining driveway service for those unhappy about the glittery self-service environment of most of the direct company outlets. And there is a consumer interest, of course, in maintaining a composite service, with garage service facilities available on as many driveways as possible around the nation. But it becomes a question of how one weighs the evidence of the impact of the direct company sites in this respect, and what weight one gives to these components of consumer protection against the competing element of the price interest for consumers.

It has been acknowledged by everyone who has ever had a look at this matter that there has been, over the years, an undoubted need for rationalisation of the service station environment. It has been acknowledged that there were too many stations operating on marginal returns and that that was not to the benefit of the consumer because of the way in which prices were being maintained at an artificially high level. It has been the case that a significant rationalisation has occurred. Whether now, with the number of sites below 12,000 nationally, we are still in the rationalisation phase or whether, rather, we are starting to bite into the consumer interest in maintaining a large number of stations around the place, an interest which is shared by the independent operators themselves, is a matter for reasoned argument. It is not a matter for slogan swapping or shouting abuse at each other. It is a relevant consideration and something which needs very close monitoring. It is also matter for argument and for further evidence as to just what extent the independent operators have been forced out of business by the operation of the direct company sites and, as a result, the extent to which consumers have been prejudiced by not having readily available access to the number of driveway operations that they would like to have. On this aspect, I think, the ball is back in Senator Chipp's court to produce the evidence. The company sites represent, as we have said, about 6 per cent or so of the total number of sites and, however strategically located those company sites may be, and undoubtedly most of them are, and however aggressive their marketing policy may be, it is difficult to believe that those 6 per cent of outlets, even if they represent closer to 20 per cent, as I suspect they do, of the total gallonage sold-or litreage, as we now have to say-can be causing the casualties and wreckage on the scale that is asserted by Senator Chipp and those who take or share his particular--

talk.start.para: —Haven't you heard of price cutting by multinationals? What are you talking about?

—I am talking about price cutting by the companies which has benefited the consumer. I am talking also about a situation in which there are only about 600 of these sites operating and there are something like 11,500 to 12,000 others still in business. If you are wanting to exaggerate the situation to the extent that you obviously are and get yourself emotional to the extent that you obviously are about this issue, you are entitled to do it.
—Order! The honourable senator will address the Chair.
—We are taking a much more reasoned and rational approach to this matter. I hope that that will be appreciated by the Senate.

speech.para: The final point I make to explain our opposition is that even if it is accepted that 100 per cent full divorcement is an immediately desirable objective and even if one buys Senator Chipp's line, with all its passion, hook line and sinker it seems to the Opposition that the 1 July 1983 deadline is a hopelessly unrealistic one. It has already beccome the case, as we know, that the September 1982 deadline has been subject to slippage and it will not be until May next year that the number of company sites will be down to 400. We are concerned about that because we are anxious that that divorcement of at least 50 per cent be achieved as soon as possible. But the reality is that by May next year there will still be at least 400 company sites in operation, and it is just wholly unrealistic to think in terms of being able to fully wipe out these sites from the market place within a mere two or three months after that.

Having said all that, it is clear that all is not wholly rosy in the petroleum retailing situation at the moment. There needs to be additional protections. There needs to be additional forms of assistance to the independent operators. I will identify two areas in particular that we think are appropriate. One of them is the subject of the amendment to be moved in the Committee stage. The other is something that does not lend itself to amendment but certainly lends itself to appropriate government action.

The first thing that is going wrong and needs to be radically changed is the operation of the Petroleum Products Pricing Authority. There is an enormous amount of dissatisfaction around the place with the maximum wholesale price levels being set by that authority. There needs to be an immediate government review, not just of the legislation, which on the face of it is basically satisfactory, but of the way that that particular authority is operating. There needs to be a fundamental reconsideration as to whether it has been much too generous to the oil companies in the way in which it is assessing what are justifiable wholesale prices. There needs to be a consideration of what seems, on the face of it, to have been a failure sufficiently to take into account productivity gains in shipping, refining and other areas which have been to the benefit of the oil companies. If the maximum wholesale prices were reduced below the levels that the PPPA is currently allowing, that would be to the manifest benefit of the independent operators whom not only Senator Chipp but also ourselves are anxious to protect. In this respect also, as the Labor Party has constantly said, there is a real concern around the place, which we certainly share, about the fragmentation in pricing policy, not only at the wholesale level with some of the States getting into the act but also with the anticipation on several States getting into the area of retail price limit setting. Basically this has to be a national function performed by a national body. The PPPA is the one to do it. We have argued constantly for the need to get all the relevant parties together to try to devise an appropriate national policy. We will certainly be monitoring the situation very closely with that in mind.

The remaining thing that needs to be done by way of protecting the interests of the independent operators is to beef up the legislative protection that they have from the predatory or potentially predatory activities of the major oil companies. There are protections against price discrimination and so on in the Trade Practices Act. There is also in the Trade Practices Act a generalised protection, in section 46--

talk.start.para: —Do you believe they are working?

—No, I do not believe they are working effectively and that is why I will move the foreshadowed amendment-to get rid of some of the threshold requirements that apply particularly in relation to section 46 and make that an inoperative protector of the interests of independent operators. It is for that reason, because we do believe they need some more muscle, some more counterweight in the legal environment, that we will move our amendment. I will say more in the Committee stage on what the amendment is about and how we propose that it work. I just hope that the Senate, and in particular Senator Chipp, will acknowledge that this is a sincere attempt on our part to demonstrate our concern not only with the interests of consumers but also those of the independent operators. One simply cannot approach a topic as complex as this with the totally blinkered or one-eyed approach that has so far prevailed within the Australian Democrats. I repeat that we are not totally, wholly, finally or irrevocably opposed to the concept of full divorcement. Quite the contrary; we have a totally open mind on the subject. We certainly would hope that as the situation changes-in particular, the market-place situation-further rational consideration will be given to this by everyone. Certainly we will be doing that in government. Nothing that we say today in opposition to Senator Chipp's Bill should be taken in any way as a final statement of Australian Labor Party opposition to the concept of full divorcement. We just believe that the way the system is operating right now, the way the market-place is operating right now, it is the wrong Bill at the wrong time.

speech.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —I rise on this occasion to exhibit a degree of unanimity with Senator Evans, who has just resumed his seat. This fact is sufficiently unusual for me to draw attention to it. Like him, I will endeavour calmly and dispassionately to address myself to the reasons why. I think it would be accepted in the chamber that this is a matter which is not without difficulty. We have had certain legislation before us in the last few years and many honourable senators would have been involved in the very lengthy discusions and considerations which preceded that legislation. I do not think there is any need to apologise for those lengthy discussions, as the complexities arise in part because there are many different legitimate interests involved in this area. The difficulties arise because those legitimate interests are sometimes in conflict and there is not necessarily a totally right solution to some of those conflicts. I suppose it can be said fairly simply, and certainly very accurately, that out prime concern needs to be for the consumers because in this case the consumers affected are the great bulk of the Australian people. We are a country which depends very substantialy on motor transport and the delivery of fuel to the private motorist is a very important factor in the general welfare and operations of our community.

speech.para: So, in assessing how we should approach the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Bill introduced by Senator Chipp, we have a primary obligation to the consumers. They are the people who are most numerically affected. I do not for a moment suggest that they are the only people afected. That view is a view which it seems to me is in part the basis of what has been put before the Senate this afternoon by Senator Evans on behalf of the Opposition. He has laid emphasis on the present interests of consumers and how they are being served by the system as it is operating in 1982. I respectfully agree that that is a proper consideration for the Senate. Indeed, it is a major consideration which we must take into account.

Vertical integration is the subject matter of this amending legislation today and, in part, of the Government legislation introduced a couple of years ago. In this context it has the potential to bring about anti-competitive or non- competitive conditions. That is why the legislation is of significance to the consumer. At the same time, obviously-the Government has done this-we must take into account the interests of the very large number of small businessmen who are operating service stations. The number of service stations in Australia has varied from time to time but we are dealing with in excess of 10,000 individual businesses and obviously they are of considerable significance. Those small businessmen have their own interests to be concerned about and the Government, and the Opposition, should look to the proper protection of their interests. They, too, have a foot in the door of the public interest argument. After all, the maintenance of competitive elements in this industry is important in maintaining competitive services to consumers. That has an effect on price and an effect on service, and therefore the welfare of those myriad small businessmen who are involved is a matter which again affects the public interest .

The major oil companies, which I suppose because of their relatively small number are the easiest to dismiss in an argument about the public interest, do on the other hand have some legitimate interests to be considered also. I would have thought that there would be agreement from the Australian Democrats, if not from the Opposition, that the oil companies that are restricted by the existing legislation in a quite severe way, and would be affected more severely by the proposed amendment, do have legitimate interests, and that they are entitled to enter freely into commerce limited only by the expectation or requirement that they should not act in a way which is against the public interest. In particular , we would be concerned in this situation that they are not acting in a way which is destructive of competition. Having said that, I think it is important that those parties that acknowledge that private capital and private business- private enterprise-have their part to play in our economy, acknowledge also that they are entitled to have their legitimate interests protected.

I adopt one of the very substantial reasons put forward by Senator Evans for opposing this Bill. The Bill proposes what I regard as a dramatically sudden divestment of the remaining oil company sites. It proposes to insert into the existing legislation a date which would require very severe and rapid divestment . That alone is a reason for opposing the amending legislation brought forward by the Australian Democrats.

I now turn to a little background to explain the Government's position on this legislation and why we propose at this stage to maintain the stance we maintained up to the introduction of Senator Chipp's Bill. We did, as is common knowledge, legislate in 1980. The legislation which we put through requires the major oil companies to effect a reduction of approximately 50 per cent in the number of directly operated retail outlets that they operated at 30 May 1980. That objective has been substantially achieved. It may be slightly obscured by a technical problem in that it appears that the oil company depots have been caught within the definition and so there has been a need to provide an extension of the numbers under the regulations to prevent the oil companies being required to divest themselves of their own depots. Subject to that, the divestment required by the law has been achieved, if not completely then very nearly.

When the Government introduced its petroleum marketing legislation-the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act and the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act-it did so after very detailed and careful examination of the problems confronting the petroleum industry. In particular, the Government considered that some degree of divorcement was necessary because first the trend towards vertical integration in the petrol retailing industry had caused a lot of concern due to its effect on independent small business in the industry. I think the small business part of the industry was most effective in drawing those concerns to the attention of the Government and, I am sure, the Opposition . Secondly, there was concern that increased vertical integration would have long term anti-competitive effects. Clearly, the concern was that if the wholesale suppliers of petrol were able to drive the independent operators from the market place in the long term they would be in the position where because of reduced competition they were able substantially to increase the cost of fuel to Australian consumers. The Government was conscious that some oil companies might unjustifiably react to the Petroleum Retail Marketing Franchise Act by converting outlets from franchise operations to company operations. They are all matters which were in the mind of the Government and which affected the legislation which was brought in several years ago.

The decision on the level of divorcement was, of its very nature, arbitrary. There is no magic number and there is probably no way even with the most detailed attempt at government regulation to set a figure which will produce a perfect degree of balance of the different objectives which we are seeking. The Government was faced with a need to decide on a level which would achieve its objectives with the minimum practicable degree of intervention in the industry. I think that is an important point because, as I said before, the three areas of interest are the consumers, small business and the oil companies. Each of those, by their nature, are legitimate interests. The degree of interference with them ought to be the minimum that is required to achieve the proper objectives of protecting the public interest. The Government did not believe, when it introduced that legislation-it does not believe it now with the basic premise that has been put forward by Senator Chipp-that the complete divorcement of major oil companies from direct operation of service stations is either necessary or desirable. The restriction of oil companies to a small number of sites in proportion to total site numbers prevents any danger of excessive vertical integration or market power.

I do not want to delay the Senate unduly, but Senator Evans gave some figures in relation to this matter. A very small proportion of petrol station sites are controlled by the major companies. That is a factor in determining the Government's attitude that there is not at this stage excessive vertical integration. At the same time, I think there are positives in the present situation. Again I advance a point which is common to the point put forward by Senator Evans on behalf of the Opposition; namely, that the present arrangements do in practice appear to work in favour of consumers and do induce a quite strong competitive element in the present retailing of petrol in the market place in Australia.

The divorcement that we decided upon in 1980 was a phased-in operation. That was a simple concession to the practical realities of making substantial changes to commercial operations. Some companies had to convert the method of operation of a large number of sites. That had to be done in an orderly and efficient way and without disturbing our existing contractural arrangements. So it was not possible to make overnight changes; they had to be done gradually. The 1980 legislation provided for that. In the result it is only now that we are further along the track that the full effect of that divorcement is beginning to be felt . We are now being asked, as a Senate, to catapult into a further stage which would completely divorce the oil majors from any petrol retailing.

I mentioned earlier that there is one difficulty in the legislation that has come to light. It is essentially a difficulty of a technical nature rather than of substance. The Act has a wider than intended application to oil company agent operated depots where some fuel is sold at the site. I suppose any of us who have campaigned as senators are familiar-even if we are not rural dwellers-with the spread of oil company depots around Australia. Pending amendments of the legislation to rectify the problem the Government, as an interim measure only-I stress that it is an interim measure-and to avoid disruption of the industry has increased company site allocations to take account of depots. That increase is solely due to the need of companies to have quota cover for depots. It in no way represents a stepping back from the divestment requirements of the 1980 legislation.

The Government believes a level of divorcement of about 50 per cent based on 1980 figures is sufficient to be effective. We are committed to the petroleum retail marketing legislation and will ensure that it operates fairly and effectively. We do not believe that complete divorcement of oil companies from petrol retailing has been shown to be needed for the benefit of the public or the industry at present.

I should perhaps comment very briefly on the fact that Senator Evans has brought into the debate quite separate considerations and concerns other than those which are dealt with under this legislation. I do not wish to offend the Standing Orders by going beyond the bounds of the legislation with which we are dealing now; suffice to say that, as I have just indicated to the Senate, we are interested in the effective operation of the legislation. We are anxious to see the public interest protected and the legitimate interests of those three groups protected. The sorts of concerns which have been raised by Senator Evans are concerns which can be addressed in that broader context. I will certainly draw them to the attention of the Minister for Industry and Commerce (Mr Peacock).

To conclude, the Government is opposed to the amending legislation which has been put forward by Senator Chipp. It does not believe that a requirement that on or before 1 July 1983 there should be a total divestment by the oil companies of their remaining sites is a reasonable thing to impose upon them at this stage . The Government does not believe it is necessary to protect the competitive position or to protect the basic interests of retailers. Accordingly, we will be opposing the amending Bill.

speech.speaker: Haines Sen J.

talk.start.para: —I rise today, not unsurprisingly, to support Senator Chipp's Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Bill which sets out to amend the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act which was one of two Acts which the Government introduced after considerable pressure from the industry-that is, from the retailing section of the industry-to allegedly, at least, incorporate the proposals in the Fife package. I support this Bill and the amendment that it contains because, like Senator Chipp, I have been closely involved with the problems inherent in this area. Indeed, Senator Chipp and I had a friendly struggle earlier this year to decide which of the two of us was the more intimately involved with the problems of petrol resellers and which of the two of us would introduce the Bill.

speech.para: It is not unnatural to find a South Australian senator or member of parliament concerned with the problems that have arisen over the last few years, to crisis point, within the petrol retail marketing area. South Australia is in a vulnerable situation, given its size and its isolation, when it comes to the provision of fuel. It is not surprising that the impetus of the action that was finally taken to try to force the Government to pay attention to the problems came from South Australia. The South Australian Automobile Chamber of Commerce Incorporated, concerned as it was with the unstable conditions that were increasingly manifesting themselves in the industry, with the decline of services that were being provided by service stations with the influx of self- serve stations and, of course, with the increasing number of bankruptcies in the area, arranged for a series of motions to be put at its annual general meeting which was held in March 1980. To attract as much attention as it could from among its member resellers, it sent out a number of advertising leaflets. Included in those leaflets were comments such as: 'Do you think you have a profitable future in the petrol retail industry as it is running now?', and 'You won't have any future if you don't unite as a force and implement action-in this election year-to secure that future'. Here is a group, whose members are predominantly men, who are almost to a person Liberal voters, taking what must have been to them both radical and drastic action, since they received considerably less than sympathetic hearings from both State and Federal politicians until then. One of the leaflets stated:
The public and the politicians must be clearly told now of the frustrations we have borne for years.
The Oil Company Lobby will remove the Fife Package from your grasp unless you act NOW to fight for your rights.

By May 1980 they had decided on a series of meeting and rolling strikes. Inserted in the Motor Trade Journal of April 1980 in preparation for that was a leaflet entitled 'Petrol retailers national action campaign'. Included in that were the following statements:
In December 1977 just prior to the General Election-
That is hardly surprising-
Mr. Fraser issued a press statement and said 'he understood the difficulties faced by small service stations-
How on earth he would, I do not know-

in maintaining their position in the industry' and went on to say that 'it would be understood by all the parties to the discussions that the Government can legislate to achieve a fair solution.' Since that time-
That is since prior to the 1977 election; this was put out in 1980-
nothing of value has been done by the Federal Government to eliminate discriminatory pricing practices or to remove oil companies from the retail scene.

talk.start.para: —Another election promise, Senator.

—Yes, yet another election promise that was never brought to fruition by Malcolm Fraser. The organisations concerned, and in particular the Australian Automobile Chamber of Commerce, then took the unprecedented step of retaining the services of a Canberra-based professional lobbyist. That organisation intended it to be his job to ensure that every Cabinet Minister was deluged with all the information necessary to convince them that protective legislation had to be enacted prior to the election. It was concerned that the active lobbying that had been undertaken by petrol retailers in all States in the previous two years had had amazing results with their Federal parliamentarians on an individual basis but had apparently not produced the required legislation at the Government or Cabinet level. The pamphlet stated:

speech.para: With the exception of a few who say 'I don't have to worry about your problem because I am in a safe seat', we have received 100 per cent support, and all Politicians have agreed that measures such as those proposed by the Hon. Wal Fife are urgently needed to ensure the survival of the legitimate petrol retailer.
Unfortunately the Fraser Cabinet, in the face of the massive oil company lobby-
which has apparently reached beyond the Liberal Party-
has been reluctant to take the legislative steps necessary.

But there were politicians-senators, members of parliament-at both the State and Federal levels who were prepared at least to go and listen and to make statements and indicate what they would do given the opportunity to assist these people. An Adelaide Advertiser clipping dated Saturday, 7 June 1980, gives an indication of what Mr Hayden, the Leader of the Labor Party-I suggest he would be speaking with more authority than even Chris Hurford-went to South Australia to talk to these people and, as I said, made some commitments. The article started off:
The Federal Opposition leader, Mr Hayden, learnt a few things in Adelaide yesterday when he faced a meeting of about 40 petrol resellers at the headquarters of the SA Automobile Chamber of Commerce.

Mr Hayden was told of pressure tactics applied to resellers to sack staff and convert to self-serve, of long-term leases being withdrawn, of instructions being given as to what price to sell petrol, and of massive rent increases on properties.
Many said the rent increases would force them to lay off staff.

Those are guerrilla tactics which, of course, can be undertaken by multinational organisations which know that the cards are stacked entirely in their favour. Mr Hayden, having listened to all this and having attended the meeting, was reported to have then said:

. . . if Labor were in power, the total Fife Package-a proposal by Mr Fife, a former Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs-which would provide protection for resellers and control over oil companies, would be brought into force within six months.
