Presumably in saying that, in referring to the Fife package, he was indicating quite clearly that given the opportunity Labor would support 100 per cent divorcement in the retail petroleum industry. He said he would do all he could to pressure the present Government to take action on the package. The article continued:
He said an unhealthy relationship existed between the Government and the major oil companies--
Again an unhealthy relationship which may well have gone beyond that between the major oil companies and the Liberal Party-
with the companies reaping in thousands of millions of dollars a year.
Most of this money was finding its way out of the country.
The only loyalties of the companies were to maximise profit and export that profit overseas.

Clearly in September 1980 a Labor back bencher, Mr Les Johnson, the honourable member for Hughes, took to heart what had been said there because he is recorded at page 1323 of the Hansard of that year to have said:
Full divorcement is the only acceptable and workable situation to prevent the emergence of artificial situations in the future.

So there were Labor politicians, from their leader to back benchers, who were quite adamant and open in their support of the need for 100 per cent divorcement -at least they were in 1980. The Government, however, was another kettle of fish altogether. In response to the pleas of the retailers the Government reneged on the divorcement proposals which were an integral part of the Fife package and instead chose not to eliminate altogether retail marketing by oil companies but to introduce only 50 per cent divorcement on the grounds that it believed it would be sufficient to achieve its aims of stabilising the industry. There was in addition, of course, the theory that the elimination of company operated sites by 50 per cent would radically reduce competition in the market. In other words, it had bowed to oil company pressure and was prepared to leave the oil companies in a still substantially powerful position in the market. The policy decision by the Government was to cut down rather than to eliminate owner- operated sites and could only be seen as a half-way measure, pandering, if you like, to the demands of the oil companies and putting those beyond its alleged concern for both the consumer and the small businessman in the market.

I will refer a little later to recent events in South Australia, but it has been patently apparent since 1980 that cutting back by 50 per cent the involvement of the oil companies directly in the retail marketing section has not had the results that the Government thought it would. I refer honourable senators to an article in the Sydney Morning Herald of February this year entitled: 'Proprietors going to wall-companies get the blame'. One of the arguments that the Government put for introducing 50 per cent divorcement was that this would be sufficient to stem the tide of bankruptcies and the consequent lack of employment. Unfortunately, it was not the case. The author of the article, Peter Freeman, began by saying:
The next time you drive into a petrol station, spare a thought for the proprietor: if the fate of many of his counterparts throughout Australia is any indication, his business days are numbered.
So by 20 February 1982 the situation had changed very little from what it was in March, April and May 1980. He went on to say:
In the past 10 years 7,435 petrol stations have shut up shop, cutting the total number from 18,883 in 1972 to 11,488 last year.
Frequently the initiative has come from the companies themselves with the goal of rationalising their distribution networks . . .
On other occasions it was the proprietor, whether an owner-operator or a lessee to the oil giants, who closed down in the face of dwindling profits.

Irrespective of who took the final decision, most service station operators have no doubt where to lay the blame-it is all the fault of ruthless, money- hungry oil companies which in the search for ever bigger profits, squeeze the little man dry.
This was admitted by at least one oil company official who said:
'What we want is the maximum possible cash flow to help finance diversification , especially into other resource areas.' . . .
'This means selling as much petrol as quickly as possible even if we can only make a quarter of a cent per litre.'
Company-owned self serve outlets operated by commission-paid agents serve this end: prices can be cut quickly whenever a company has a big surplus of petrol to unload.

Even given that situation, not satisfied with the problem not being solved by the 50 per cent divorcement measure, in August of 1982 the Attorney-General ( Senator Durack) put out a Press release saying that, because of a variety of administrative problems, the Government was going to extend the time that the oil companies had to divest themselves of even half of their sites. The following point was made in that Press statement:

Senator Durack said the Government had decided to postpone the date when the new site allocations took place on the grounds of equity and to prevent disruption to the supply of petrol and diesel fuel, particularly in rural areas.

Clearly, he had no awareness of, or if he did he had no concern for, the disruption that was still being caused in the industry by the guerrilla tactics of the oil companies as occurred when Caltex pulled a stunt in South Australia.

In September of this year, Caltex-Golden Fleece decided that it would drop the price at its seven company-owned sites in the Adelaide metropolitan area. The Advertiser ran a story headed 'Caltex cuts petrol price' with a sub-heading '34. 9c a litre set in sales ''gamble'' '-a gamble, of course, which oil companies with their massive profits, with their international ownership, can afford to take. They can afford to sell petrol at ridiculous losses for days on end until they have wiped out their opponents because they know that the franchisees and independent owners cannot hope for any length of time, given their mortgages and various other debts, to cope with the sorts of pressures that these sorts of price-cutting wars invoke.
The article in the Advertiser stated:
The Caltex-Golden Fleece company yesterday took a 'business gamble' to regain lost petrol sales in South Australia.

If it is prepared to do that in South Australia where petrol sales would probably have to be the lowest of any State, imagine what it is likely to do when it puts its tiny mind to the problem in States such as Victoria and New South Wales? The article continued:
The company set 34.9c as the retail price for super at its seven company-owned or operated sites in the metropolitan area and lessee sites quickly moved to match the price.

The lessee sites were able to do that because the company gave rebates or discounts on the wholesale price to lessee operators who came to it saying that their business was being affected by the lower retail prices, which were being offered at sites owned by the same company which was providing them with their petrol. The State manager of Caltex-Golden Fleece admitted there was quite a risk involved, that his company would be losing a substantial amount of money but that it could, of course, afford to. Fairly clearly, if seven company-owned sites out of the 450 service stations in Adelaide can produce a price-cutting war, even 50 per cent divorcement is demonstrably not sufficient.

That in itself would be bad enough. But the end result of this little attack by Caltex-Golden Fleece on the petrol-retail marketing area in South Australia was a considerable amount of violence against property and intended violence against people. On 27 September, two days after the Advertiser carried the story and two days after Caltex put its move into operation, the Advertiser ran another story, this time headed 'I'm carrying a gun, says petrol vendor'. The article began with the statement:
A Caltex-Golden Fleece service station lessee says he is carrying a gun because he fears violence this week over the company's decision to cut the retail price of its petrol.

Mr R. W. Skipper said yesterday he believed there could be bloodshed at service stations this week because of angry petrol-industry reaction to the company's price of 34.9c a litre for super-grade petrol.
He called on the Government to set fixed prices for petrol in South Australia ' to restore some sanity to the petrol industry and avoid what could turn into a real nasty situation.'
The article continued:
Mr Skipper's Caltex service station at Fullarton Road, Fullarton, was one of two service stations where pumps were damaged on Friday night following the price change.
Mr Skipper believes people from a rival service station smashed glass panels and control units on five of his eight pumps, causing $15,000 damage.
The article continued:

The executive director of the South Australia Automobile Chamber of Commerce, Mr R. A. Flashman, said he could understand the angry reaction to the price of petrol at Caltex-Golden Fleece service stations. 'Lessees from other companies believe they are faced with either watching their businesses and savings go down the drain or taking the law into their own hands,' Mr Flashman said.
'We do not condone the damaging of pumps, but the action is not surprising.'
Mr Flashman said he believed one of two things would happen.
'Either Caltex will call the whole thing off or the other companies will follow and there will be a disconting war in which the main casualties will be the lessees,' he said.
In fact what eventuated was that Caltex called it off, having achieved what it said at the outset was its aim-that was, of attracting customers back.

In his speech Senator Evans stated the attitude of the ALP this year, this month, today-perhaps we had better not take it any further than that since the Labor Party is likely to change its mind again tomorrow in the light of some of the comments that Senator Evans made about that party's determination in this regard. But he did state the present minute ALP attitude to the concept of 100 per cent divorcement. He feels that it is something that is likely to need to be looked at, that it is no doubt something which may well concern us in the future . But at the moment he said piously: 'We are concerned with beginning at the beginning', which was the way he put it 'and looking at the interests of the consumers and of the small businessman'. I would suggest that the consumers' interests are not being served in any way at all by 50 per cent divorcement when we have the sort of latent violence that is contained in the reports in the Advertiser of September of this year and when we consider that the influx of self-serve stations into the retail marketing area has meant a considerable loss for other services-not just driveway services but mechanics' services and so on- to motorists who are, after all, the consumers about whom Senator Evans was talking.

Furthermore, the ALP's concern for the businessman or businesswoman and the people whom they employ would be touching if it were not for the fact that, as the Sydney Morning Herald indicates, people are still being forced to the wall, forced to give up their businesses and to put off their staff because of the predatory behaviour of the oil companies. Senator Evans said that the ALP had an open mind. I would suggest that the ALP's mind is more a palimpsest than anything else and that its amendment is in fact mealy-mouthed, chicken-hearted and lily-livered and any other anatomical analogy that one cares to bring up to describe something which indicates only that it is wriggling out of a commitment made by Mr Hayden in 1980. Indeed, from what I have seen of the amendment that the ALP hopes to move at the Committee stage, having forgotten that to do that first of all the legislation has to be passed at the second reading stage, it would appear that what the Labor Party is trying to do is a sort of petrol bottom-of-the-harbour stunt. It would remove entirely our clause 3, which is the only necessary clause in this Bill, and substitute its own. All that would remain of our legislation would be a shell, having been stripped of its assets to be left a vacuum by the tortuous amendment of the ALP. I support this Bill in the interests of stability in the industry, in the interests of security for the many small businesses in the industry and the thousands of people they employ, and for the ultimate benefit of the consumer.

speech.speaker: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

talk.start.para: —in reply-In summing up there is little for me to say after that comprehensive and penetrating speech by my colleague Senator Haines. The Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Amendment Bill has been introduced for philosophical and practical reasons. The philosophical reason is that the Australian Democrats believe that it is basically wrong for a monopoly or oligopoly to control a scarce resource and petrol is a scarce resource. In fact, it is a resource which is becoming scarcer each year at a frightening rate. To have an oligopoly which in the past has been notorious for restrictive trade practices controlling the wholesale and retail outlets of a scarce resource is, we believe, philosophically wrong.

speech.para: Secondly, we believe that the record of the oil companies in this country, particularly the multinational oil companies, has been one of deliberate destruction of Australian small business people who have owned, managed and operated service stations with the clear aim of having the total market to themselves. For this reason, I find it incomprehensible that the Australian Labor Party should oppose this Bill, which calls for 100 per cent divorcement. That means that it would not be legal for an oil company to own a service station. We could then have a separate industry retailing petrol, owned and operated by Australians with fair dinkum competition between them all so that the consumer is best served. We regard it as short-sighted and myopic to think, as Senator Evans illustrated, that because the odd price war between the oil companies goes on now and then and here and there that in the end is good for the consumer. Our view was illustrated by Senator Haines. Of course the consumer loves a price war in the short run. But what happens in a price war? Who are the casualties while the consumer temporarily benefits? The casualties are the Australian owned independent service stations. With every price war more and more fall and less and less competition is left in the way of the multinationals .

Let us look at the history of the industry. Both Senator Evans and Senator Chaney had a strange unity ticket on the question of multinational oil companies . They said: 'Chipp's Bill proceeds with indecent haste to bring about a certain result'. Indecent haste? This matter has been talked about and discussed for six years. In October 1978, after discussions had continued for two years, the then Liberal Minister for Business and Consumer Affairs, Mr Fife, brought in a statement-it was called the Fife package-which stated that full divorcement was essential. The Fife package went even further. It said: 'When we bring in the legislation we will backdate it to October 1978'. That statement had shades of retrospectivity. But then the multinational oil companies got busy. They lobbied public servants, politicians, Ministers and ministerial staff.

We did not see the legislation that was promised in the latter part of 1978. We did not see it in 1979. The clout of the international oil companies is enormous . Finally, a half-baked package was produced in 1980 which allowed the oil companies to divest themselves of only half their sites. That Bill, instead of penalising the oil companies and giving the Aussie battler a fair go, played into the oil companies' hands because it allowed them to rationalise their expenses. It allowed them to reduce the number of sites they had and at the same time to indulge in price cutting to an extent that sent independent Australian operators bankrupt by the thousands. Now two more years have passed.

This Bill would simply put the multinational oil companies out of the retail business. Is anything wrong with that? Senator Evans and Senator Chaney have not stated one aspect of what is wrong with competition among small business people. I can understand the Labor Party not becoming euphoric about small business people or any sort of business people. But what passes my comprehension is the action of the people who sit on the other side of the chamber-the Liberals and the National Party members-who espouse themselves as champions of private enterprise, of the small business people. At the next election it will make me want to vomit to hear members of the Liberal Party say: 'We champion the small business person', when, to a man and woman, they will vote against this legislation today. Such legislation has already been proved successful in the State of Maryland in the United States of America. I felt sorry for my friend Senator Evans today. No one but a consummately complete lawyer, as he is, could have handled such an impossible brief without breaking into laughter. What sort of brief was handed to him by Mr Brown, the Labor spokesman on this subject? I also find Mr Brown incomprehensible. I do not want to be too rude to the gentleman, but he said that the experiment in Maryland is a failure because prices have gone up. I do not want to be too savage on him but I think someone like Senator Evans who has a talent for imparting knowledge ought to tell Mr Brown that there is a thing called inflation in this world and that it has hit the United States of America and therefore the State of Maryland.

talk.start.para: —It went up relative to other States.

—Senator Evans ought to tell Mr Brown that if he has a look at the prices in Maryland he will see that they have gone up less, relatively, than they have in other States. If that were not the case why is it that 23 States of the United States of America today are contemplating full divorcement? They are contemplating legislation identical to my Bill which is now before the Senate. If the Maryland experiment has been such a disaster, as Mr Brown suggests, why is it being copied by 23 other States in the United States of America?

speech.para: The decision of the Liberal Party and all its members to vote against this Bill today represents on their part an overt, provable, palpable broken promise-a promise made in 1978. Without making too much of a point of it I wish now to talk about the attitude of the Australian Labor Party and why I find it incomprehensible that that party should vote against the Bill today.

talk.start.para: —Actually, we are not. We are going to support it at the second reading stage.

—The honourable senator gave me a lecture on morality while he was speaking. Let me now give him one. He and his party will be voting in such a way as to destroy totally the thrust of the private member's Bill that I have introduced today. I wish to place on record the fact that the Labor party will be voting to destroy totally the meaning, thrust and purpose of the Bill. Senator Evans has circulated an amendment which looks innocent enough. It may be one which, if made to the principal Act, we might eventually see fit to support. It states:

speech.para: Page 1, clause 3. Leave out the clause.

In other words, Senator Evans wishes to delete clause 3. The casual reader of my speech might not realise the significance of leaving out clause 3-what it would do to my Bill. The Bill-it is not the thickest that has ever been brought before the Senate-consists of one page and has three clauses. The first comprises the title. The second states that it will come into operation when it receives assent. The third is the clause which provides for complete divorcement. That is the one that Senator Evans and the Labor Party want to knock out.

talk.start.para: —There is not much left.

—That is a proper way of describing the actions of Senator Evans or, more particularly, his friend Mr John Brown in the other place. What has the Labor Party said on this matter? I will not impugn that party, because I have been admonished in that respect by my friend Senator Evans. I will simply say that I find incomprehensible that there should have been a 180 degree change in direction. In 1980 Mr Les Johnson, a former Minister, said:

speech.para: Full divorcement: The only acceptable and workable situation to prevent the emergence of artificial situations in the future.

talk.start.para: —The shadow Minister for-?
—I refer to Mr Les Johnson, the honourable member for Hughes who, I understand, is the party Whip and was formerly a Labor Minister.
—But with no responsibility for this portfolio, you would acknowledge?

—Let me quote someone who does have responsibility. I refer to the Labor Party's shadow Minister for Industry and Commerce, Mr Chris Hurford, who described the Government's 1980 legislation as 'only a half measure'.
—He is a real Whip too.

—Yes. I do not pretend to put myself beside Senator Button when it comes to knowledge of mathematics but what we have at the moment is half divorcement. I want full divorcement. If Mr Hurford says that the Government's 1980 legislation, which involved half divorcement, represented only a half measure I would think, without being a graduate in mathematics, that it would be fair to conclude that in 1980 Mr Hurford and the Labor Party wanted full divorcement. Mr Hurford attacked the Bill as providing:

speech.para: A permanently discriminating market structure to prevail insofar as the oil companies themselves are concerned.
He said also:
Very soon the oil companies will be able to command as much of the petrol retail market with 400 sites as they do today with 800.
He made the further prediction that the 1980 Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act would not survive for two years, adding 'I doubt that it should'.

What Senator Evans has overlooked today is that although the oil companies have 400 sites or so, a relatively small number, if they are consistently selling petrol 1c, 2c or 3c a litre cheaper than does the independent operator opposite, the latter will not get one customer; they will get the lot. That is exactly what has happened in the short time since half divorcement has come into being. The oil company operated sites are now selling up to three and four times as much as is the independent operator next door. And why would not the consumer, in the short term, buy the cheaper petrol?

Mr Brown in explaining this about-face stated that it was because 'conditions have changed'. We are told the complete vertical integration of the petroleum market by the oil companies is helping competition and is bringing lower prices to consumers. I would agree with him on one thing-conditions have indeed changed ; they have become a lot worse. I invite Senator Evans, as he drives his vehicle around Melbourne at the weekend to ask any independent operator or lessees who run the service stations what they think of 50 per cent divorcement. He should ask that of the independent operator who is forced by the oil companies to leave a blank cheque at night under a rock next to his bowser because that is the only condition under which an oil company will deliver petrol to him. That is a deliberate, diabolical plot to send him broke, as they have done to thousands of others.

Let me quote the statistics. In 1979-80 the number of service station sites in Australia fell from 12,900 to 12,053, a loss in one year of 847 Australian small businesses. That represents 7 per cent of the total retail market. Yet, we find this Liberal Government allowing that to continue. The so-called, self-appointed champions of the small business person are allowing operators who account for 7 per cent of the retail market-847 Aussie battlers, if one may use that term-to be sent bankrupt deliberately, by foreigners, in one year.

In 1980-81, following the implementation of the 50 per cent divorcement law, the position was worse. Some 1,028 small businessmen were driven out of the petroleum retail market. They represented 8.5 per cent of the total market. The success of the predatory practices of the multinationals is increasing, not decreasing. Although I admire and share Senator Evans's concern for the consumer I ask: What sort of price is being paid to give consumers, temporarily, 1c or 2c off a litre of petrol? The figures for 1981-82 are not yet in, but I invite honourable senators to ask their local service station operator, or their colleagues, how the private sector is coping. Examples of the actions of the oil companies in sending the independent operators bankrupt have been detailed by my colleague, Senator Haines.

In conclusion, I must say that I am bitterly disappointed with the attitude of the Labor Party. I confess that I did not discuss the Bill with it before it hit the deck, so to speak. I knew what the attitude of the Liberal Party would be- that it would be clearly on the side of the multinationals-but I would have thought that the last political party in the country that would have come into this chamber to bat for multinational oil companies would be the Australian Labor Party. I took it for granted that, because of its stated policy, it would support the Bill. The Labor Party, even more than the Democrats, knows the form, the behaviour, of multinationals and their predatory activities against smaller business people. But no, for some extraordinary reason-all I can say is that my friend Senator Evans, and his colleagues have been very badly advised by their spokesperson on this question-the Opposition is saying that this Bill which would force multinational oil companies out of the retail market is not worth supporting.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

proctext.para: The Bill.

speech.speaker: Evans Sen G.J.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: Page 1, Clause 3, leave out the clause, insert the following clause:
Restriction on operation of retail sites ''3. Section 10 of the Principal Act is amended by adding at the end of sub-section (3):

'and if the corporation does not take advantage of the power it has, in relation to the market for the retail sale of motor fuel, for the purpose of eliminating or substantially damaging a person, being a competitor in that market of the corporation or its agents or of a body corporate related to the corporation'.''

The substance of this amendment is to take out clause 3 of the Bill, as the Leader of the Australian Democrats (Senator Chipp) pointed out, and to substitute a proposition to add words to section 10 (3) of the principal Act. By agreement I rise to speak briefly and non-provocatively for the sole purpose of explaining what this amendment is about and what effect it would have if carried . It is my understanding that agreement has been reached for the debate to be adjourned when I have completed my remarks. The amendment essentially adds a further condition to section 10 of the Petroleum Retail Marketing Sites Act, a further requirement that has to be satisfied if the direct selling company sites are to stay in operation at all, even in a reduced number. The requirement is to add a further condition that has to be satisfied by each corporation, namely, that it is not to take advantage of its market power for the purpose of eliminating or substantially damaging a competitor.

The language in question is taken quite directly from section 46 of the Trade Practices Act. It is essentially designed to protect the independent service station operators against various forms of predatory practice, including in particular predatory pricing, which they may be subject to by the major oil companies. Some protections are presently enjoyed by service station proprietors under other provisions of the Trade Practices Act, for example section 49 which relates to price discrimination. The language of section 46, on which the present amendment is based, does not, however, protect the independent operators at the moment for the reason that section 46 of the Act has, as a threshold requirement, the consideration that the corporation be one which is 'in a position substantially to control the market for goods or services'. In other words, the prohibition on section 46 predatory activity applies only when, in effect, there is a monopoly of the market in question and the selling of the product in question. Of course, when we are talking about petroleum marketing, whatever one might think of the role of the oil companies, they do not constitute a monopoly. No one of them is in a position substantially to control a market. As such, section 46 has no application.

This then is an attempt to pick up and apply, for the protection of independent service station operators, that particular provision of the Trade Practices Act. Let me describe how it would work in practice. It has to be read in conjunction with section 12 of the parent Act. Provision is made for the court, on the application of the Minister or any person affected, to make an order restraining a prescribed corporation-which for this purpose includes the oil companies-from engaging in conduct that constitutes a contravention of section 10. If we make the conduct which would constitute a contravention of section 10 include predatory activities of this particular kind it would then be possible for a service station proprietor affected by the predatory or damaging activity to go to court and seek appropriate restraining orders. If the oil company were to ignore those restraining orders and to continue the activity in question the next step, of course, would be for the court to rule that the whole condition of the oil company being allowed to stay in the direct selling market would no longer be satisfied; at a stroke, a situation would be created where the oil companies would have to get out of retailing entirely because they would no longer be covered by section 10 protection.

It all no doubt sounds a little technical, but that is what it is about. The amendment is expressly designed to protect independent operators from such predatory activity as the oil companies might still be disposed to take. I can understand Senator Chipp's unhappiness with at least the procural aspects of this proposal to the extent, I suppose, that it does amount to something of a legislative asset stripping operation. It is proposed that the Senate first vote to take out Senator Chipp's clause 3, and then to substitute the section put forward by the Opposition. I am sure that in the interests of the independent service station proprietors, whom Senator Chipp and his Democrats are so anxious to protect, he will ultimately come to see the wisdom of a provision of this kind being incorporated in the legislation in the event that his own clause 3 is in fact defeated. I think that is perhaps a sufficient explanation to keep us all happy until we meet again on this particular subject.

speech.speaker: Chipp Sen The Hon D.L.

talk.start.para: —The Government has requested quite reasonably that this debate be adjourned so that it can understand the amendment moved by Senator Evans. I appreciate the fact that I will have two weeks in which to come to understand that amendment also. For the benefit of those who will be reading the Hansard of this debate I want to place on record the fact that the Australian Democrats will, of course, be opposing the amendment. If we did support it it would be tantamount to destroying our own Bill, and we would not do that.
—It could be put in two questions, perhaps.

—I acknowledge the interjection made by Senator Evans. Unless the Australian Labor Party is prevailed upon in the next two or three weeks, as I am sure it will be, by service station operators all around the country to change its mind and it comes into this chamber on the eleventh of--
—They may have a conversion on the road to Damascus.
—I suggest that the service station owners write to Senator Evans.

—Senator Missen, by interjecting, is also inviting service station operators to write, telephone or send telegrams to him. I am sure he will be pleased to hear from them. If the Labor Party does not change its mind I invite Senator Evans to try to break his amendment into two parts because without totally understanding it it does have a prima facie appeal to us. I thank the Senate for the opportunity of debating this private member's Bill.

speech.para: Progress reported.

debate.title: DIESEL FUEL TAXES LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1982

proctext.para: Debate resumed.

speech.speaker: Walsh Sen P.A.

talk.start.para: —When the debate was adjourned in mid- afternoon I had finished explaining the change that this Bill seeks to make in the provisions for exempting some categories of users from the excise on diesel fuel. I also mentioned that the Government had already amended the Bill in three or four different ways in the House of Representatives since it had been introduced. Indeed, I think this measure is another good example of Government incompetence with the introduction of eleventh-hour amendments following Government back bench pressure to change or withdraw the Bill. In this instance, forms had been printed, then the Government, under pressure from its own back bench and from outside, decided to change the Bill. The forms had to be scrapped and new forms had to be printed.

speech.para: The rationale for imposing an excise tax on diesel fuel, and of course on petrol, has traditionally been that these are road transport fuels and that it is therefore appropriate that some tax be levied on the fuel to offset the public money that goes into road construction and maintenance. I do not know whether that rationale is still taken seriously by the Government but, if it is, we are now in the incongruous position of having the excise tax on diesel fuel being extended to apply to railways, so that fuel used for locomotives will be subject to the tax and thereby railways will be placed at a disadvantage vis-a- vis roads. The Government's explanation for making these changes in the way that certain categories of users are exempt from excise, as distinct from imposing the tax on other categories of users, is that the previous system had been abused-the system under which users of diesel fuel for non-road purposes obtained certificates of exemption from the tax.

It is at least arguable that this new system is more open to abuse than the one it replaces. In any case, if the Government were really serious about ending abuses of the exemption, in whatever form it may be administered, it would do what a number of other countries have done in the same circumstances and add a dye to diesel fuel that is sold without excise for non-road use. Anyone caught with dyed diesel fuel in a vehicle or a piece of equipment which was not entitled to the exemption would be subject to quite heavy penalties. This effectively would deter people from doing so. I would have thought it was a matter of common sense that that was a system which was likely to work very efficiently. One would not need an army of inspectors, but periodic checks. It is self-evident that the incontrovertible evidence of dyed fuel in a vehicle or piece of equipment not entitled to use that fuel, and the provision of heavy penalties for such illegal use, would ensure that abuses were kept to a minimum. So I do not think it is credible that the Government has done this for that reason.

Let us look around to see why the Government did it. I believe that, as with so many recent decisions, the genesis of this Bill can be found in the manic determination of the Prime Minister (Mr Malcolm Fraser) to have a premature election this year before everybody realises that the economy has collapsed, as it is now in the process of doing, and that this is introduced as a cosmetic exercise to make the deficit look a little bit more respectable-I put that word 'respectable' notionally-in Malcolm Fraser's terms than it otherwise would have been.

Since none of the reasons that have been given for the introduction of this legislation will stand up to any sort of critical analysis, it seems that, if only by process of elimination, we come back to the conclusion that this is associated with the Prime Minister's desire to produce by cosmetic means a deficit more respectable, in his terms, than it would otherwise have been. I say by cosmetic means for this reason: The additional revenue collected-I have had a bit of difficulty getting these figures; there is no real information in the second reading speech but I trust and I believe that the figures are correct- because of the change in the way the exemption is administered, and because of some other peripheral changes for this financial year, will be $192m. The refund paid, according to the Estimates committee document, will be $112m. Of course, the difference is $80m. A small part of that can be attributed to the peripheral changes in categories of exemption and to the termination of whatever abuses may have accompanied the old system. But the greater part of that is a de facto interest free loan from farmers, the fishing industry and other previously, and still, exempt or ultimately exempt users of diesel fuel.

One quite serious anomaly affects the mining industry in Western Australia where companies operating in the same industry in the same area are to be treated quite differently because of the way that the exemptions or the new rules are to be administered. Any excise paid on fuel used in transporting ore from the mine site to a processing site will be refundable. Two mining companies operate in the Pilbara. One company processes the ore on the mine site and rails it a couple of hundred miles to the port. The other company rails the ore a couple of hundred miles to the port and processes it there. Because one company is transporting ore by rail for processing, the fuel used will be subject to refund. The other company, which is processing the ore on the mine site and is therefore transporting processed ore, will not. That is a very clear anomaly for two companies which operate in the same area.

Another anomaly, in my view, is that in Western Australia, in the Northern Territory and, I presume, in at least some other States, public State electricity commission power or the equivalent of State electricity commission power is produced by power stations operated by diesel fuel. These power stations also will now be subject to excise and the price of electricity therefore must rise.

Overall, there is no doubt that the changes made consequential to this Bill will have some inflationary impact because they will boost transport and other costs across a quite wide variety of industries. However, despite the reservations that the Opposition has about these Bills, they are Bills which are clearly associated with the Budget. They will not be opposed by the Opposition. Following the view which we stated very quickly after the Budget was introduced, this Budget belongs to the present Prime Minister and the present Prime Minister will have to live with it. Ultimately, I believe, in the political sense, he will die with it.

speech.speaker: Archer Sen B.R.

talk.start.para: —I will make only a brief contribution on these diesel fuel tax legislation amendment Bills. I support what the legislation presumes to do. As in the case of most legislation which seeks to change or to extend taxation measures, we have had a lot of submissions and representations from all sorts of industries and users, Australia-wide. But we need to remember that the main reasons for this legislation were, firstly, to eliminate areas of considerable abuse and, secondly, as a revenue measure, to equalise transport operations, mainly between rail and road and between the public and private sectors.

speech.para: The legislation has introduced a change of method. Having for many years operated with exemption certificates, users are now in a position where they no longer get an exemption but they can claim a rebate. It is certainly not as easy as the old scheme but the Government believes that it is more secure. Private contractors will now find that they will pay the same net amount for their fuel when competing with government contractors on public works. Road transport operators will find that they are now paying a rate for their fuel equivalent to that for diesel locomotives. I think this is a good proposal, and I support it.

I have, however, as I say, had representations from a fairly wide range of users. I have not had an opportunity thoroughly to investigate many of these representations. Among the people who have contacted me have been pleasure craft operators, tourist boat operators, cheese manufacturers, fishermen, sawmillers, farmers, dry cleaners, abattoir operators, holiday resort operators and others. Senator Thomas, who is unable to be here at the moment, mentioned also the iron ore miners and the salt miners. I have taken quite a few of these representations forward, but not all of them, by any means. But I am advised that they will be looked at at a later stage.

I am grateful that concessions have been provided to two of the groups I have represented. I refer to sections of the fishing industry and sections of the timber industry. I think the fishermen warrant a special mention. I and some of my colleagues in the Senate-I know Senator Withers and Senator Thomas were involved-made representations and secured, I am told, remissions for the participants in fishing co-operatives. The proposal that I certainly went along with was built on four grounds. I think this is important because, having gained a concession, there will be other groups which will believe that they have been unfairly treated. But in this particular case the reason why I supported the fishermen was that they were not looking for any extra exemption at all. We had a letter from the Acting Minister, Mr Fife, who made it quite clear that there had never been problems with fishermen with regard to malpractice in the use of fuel; that the fishermen themselves are the co-operatives and the co-operatives are the fishermen; and that from a practical sense, where we are looking at probably 3,000 to 4,000 individual fishermen, by doing it this way we might then be able to reduce that number to something like 50 or 60 co-operatives.

Senator Thomas had a special problem with the iron ore industry, similar to that outlined by Senator Walsh. As he said, four companies, each using the same basic commodity and operating in the same area, will secure their fuel at different rates depending on the rebate to which they are entitled. I think that is an anomaly to which more attention needs to be paid. I just hope that it will be possible to tidy up that anomaly. I understand the difference there will be a matter of probably $2m to $3m between the companies transporting ore over the same route.

As I say, I have been mixed up with the sawmillers. The problem there has been partly relieved. Again, we are still in the area of definition. I find it difficult to determine why fuel use in respect of logs which are brought into a mill and put across a saw bench attract a charge at one rate whereas if they go through the chipper the fuel used is charged for at a different rate. In fact, it is even worse than that because, if we really study this matter, we will find that part of the log will go through the saws and part will go through the chipper. I am not really sure how we can break up the difference in the charge for fuel in those two areas.

What is needed, I think, is two small amendments to the definitions which are set out in proposed new section 164, subsection (7). Under the definition ' forestry', in paragraph (d) after the words 'the milling', the words 'or processing' should be added so that that paragraph reads:
(d) the milling or processing of timber at a sawmill that is not situated in the forest or plantation in which the timber was felled-
Turning to paragraph (e), I propose that after the words 'where timber is milled at a sawmill', the words 'woodchip or pulp mill' should be added so that the paragraph reads:
(e) where timber is milled at a sawmill, woodchip or pulp mill that are not situated in the forest or plantation in which the timber is felled . . .

Those changes would avoid any difficulties as it would be absolutely impossible for anybody to determine correctly what proportions of any log go through one process or the other. I do not believe in making things more difficult than necessary and I do not see how we can prevent problems if we create situations that will lead to problems. I urge that the Government take every possible step to have payments made with the utmost speed. Delays to date have been very expensive. In fact, I have a letter from the President of the Australian Fishing Industry Council, Mr Connell, which says:
Below is a break-up of duty paid at 6.155 cents per litre and now outstanding to 7 companies in W.A., N.T. and QLD
W.A. 3 companies $128,561 N.T. 1 company 60,000 Qld 3 companies 178,761

Those figures are up to 12 October. On the information that I have to date, providing this Bill goes through today and providing it gets royal assent within about a week, payments for the early ones should be in the clients' bank accounts by about 12 or 13 November. I would like to see that that is done. These people have been out of their money for a long time. An amount of that magnitude certainly requires attention and I would be pleased if the Minister for Education (Senator Peter Baume) could confirm tonight that something like that would be possible and that the people who are at the beginning of this list will be treated as quickly as possible. I realise that there will be a large bank-up. I know that there will be difficulties for the officers in handling their first group of claims. But I do ask that every step be taken to get the first lot out as fast as possible because a considerable amount of money is involved and there has been considerable hardship in many cases as a result of this situation.

I do not see this legislation as being ideal by any means but I believe that had there been solid policing and appropriate penalties under the old system we could have largely secured satisfactory results. There have been changes, and I accept that, but I still believe that this matter has been handled in a way that is slightly less than ideal. I see that some doors have been left open and that there are areas that we will need to tidy up. I believe that people who have genuine problems will have the opportunity to have them tidied up. The minor matters should be able to be dealt with either by some small amendments or by regulations. However, I support the legislation and I again plead for the early payment of the claims made.

speech.speaker: Colston Sen M.A.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is debating three diesel fuel tax amendment Bills. Prior to the Budget, excise duty was payable for diesel fuel only if it was used on public roads but when the Budget was introduced on 17 August we were told of certain changes to the arrangements relating to the diesel fuel excise. Basically, the changes were that the excise on diesel fuel- which, including the extra levy, would be 6.155c per litre-would be payable by all users. Rebates were to be granted for certain off-road usage. We were told in the Budget that that usage would be in the agricultural, mining, fishing and forestry industries. Nursing homes would be able to obtain rebates and so would hospitals and aged persons' homes. Rebates would also be payable for certain domestic use.

speech.para: I use this opportunity to level criticism at the Government for the inordinate delay in having this legislation passed. Senator Archer, who has just concluded speaking, also referred to this in his speech. This legislation was ignored by the Government as it grappled with problems of its own making. We should remember that the legislation was introduced on 17 August, the same day as the Budget was brought down, and it has taken over two months for it to get to this place for debate. As the Government has hung on to power over the last few weeks , its inaction with this legislation has resulted in thousands of dollars being withheld from primary producers and certain other organisations. It should be remembered that the excise on diesel fuel has been paid by, if I can call them this, exempt users since 17 August but no rebates have yet been paid, and no rebates will be paid for some time. The Government knew full well that rebates would not be paid until this legislation got through both Houses and then received royal assent. It may even be some time after that before the rebates are actually paid or, as Senator Archer says, are in the bank accounts of those who are eligible for them.

I ask why those eligible for a rebate should have to wait so long, or even have to wait so long to be able to apply for a rebate. It is now over two months since some of the people eligible for the rebate started to pay the excise. Many primary producers who can ill-afford it are providing to the Government over this time what is virtually an interest-free loan. They have paid the excise and they are waiting for their rebate but it looks like they will now have to wait until the beginning or middle of next month. I have been approached by some primary producers, as I suppose many honourable senators have, and they have justly asked why they should have to wait so long. I would like to read a letter which a primary producer in north Queensland sent to the former Minister for Industry and Commerce. He said:

As you are aware your Government at Budget time changed the method for farmers to receive the distillate excise rebate. The Treasurer, at that time, stated that forms would be available to claim the rebate.
The announcement was made on the 17th August, 1982 and it is now October and the forms are still not available. Have you any idea when the forms will be available in Cairns?
I am surprised at your Government taking such action as changing the system of Rebate without having the forms ready for distribution.
In this time of high inflation, high costs and falling farm income, your Government is placing undue hardships on the farming community.

If a Labor government had delayed rebates like this I expect that throughout the nation its members would have been pilloried. Yet this Government seems to have got away with holding back this money which is rightfully due to many primary producers and other organisations. This Government should not escape criticism for its lack of action and deserves severe censure for letting the legislation languish for so long in the House of Representatives without bringing it here so that it can be passed, the forms can be distributed-as the primary producer to whom I referred mentioned-and the primary producers can obtain their rebates.

When I looked at this legislation I wondered whether the Government had thought through its new proposals properly. One cent of the 6.155c per litre excise is to be applied to the Bicentennial Road Development Program. Although that is the subject of a Bill that is yet to come before this chamber, it is worth mentioning that all non-road users of diesel fuel paying excise will be contributing to that program. This includes bakeries, dry cleaners and, as Senator Walsh said, even State railways. They will now be contributing to road development throughout Australia. That is a most peculiar situation. In fact, the managerial people in the various State railways do not think very much of the fact that they have to pay for road development in Australia. In Queensland I understand that the State railways will be paying about $2m towards road development. Next year, when the levy increases by another 1c per litre, they will be paying about $4m. I understand that the State railways have made submissions to the Government that they be exempt from this levy. I am not sure whether they have been exempted. The Minister for National Development and Energy (Senator Sir John Carrick) may be able to clear up that matter when he replies.

It is clear that the excise measures were not properly thought through before their introduction. I have received many representations and Senator Archer, who spoke before me, mentioned that he has received many representations. I wish to mention three of those. First, a major shipping company in north Queensland contacted me. It enclosed a copy of a letter that it had sent to the Treasurer ( Mr Howard). The letter mentioned to the Treasurer that the new policy 'will dramatically offset the future viability of this company and the livelihood of its 200 plus employees who in the fiscal year 1981-82 contributed $1.7m in personal income tax to the Treasury'. This is a shipping company which many communities in north Queensland rely upon to bring goods to them on a regular basis.

The second matter I wish to mention concerns a letter which I received from a member of Queensland Parliament. He outlined the difficulties facing local authorities in his area and mentioned the problems that a certain brickworks was going to face. I remember speaking to a shire chairman of a local authority in what one would call a near Brisbane area which, nevertheless, is in a rural area . The shire area is fairly small. The chairman mentioned to me a week and a half ago that about $9,000 extra would be payable by that shire because of the change in the diesel fuel excise policy. An amount of $9,000 might not sound much but to local authorities which have to eke out a living on a fairly limited income $ 9,000 is a considerable amount. Finally, I wish to read to the Senate a letter which outlines the difficulties which will be faced by one of the fuel distributors in Queensland. In a letter which the distributor wrote to the company from which he receives his oil he said:
Dear Sir,DIESEL FUEL REBATE SCHEME
You will know that the former method of collecting duty using Fuel certificates ceased on the 18th August 1982.
I believe that it ceased on 17 August but 18 August is mentioned. The letter continued:

You will also be aware that the new scheme imposes a dreadful financial burden on distributors and oil companies alike. I would like to offer you some figures taken from our business for the period 17th September, 1982.
litres (1) Total throughput period both duty paid and exempt 105,965 (2) Total litreage which would normally pay duty of that total 920
(3) Difference 105,045 (4) Total revenue collected for government on figure (1 ) $6,522.15 (5) Total revenue which would normally be collected $ 56.63
(6) Difference $6,465.52

In other words, the distributor was saying that normally $56.63 revenue would be collected but to collect the whole of the revenue, which has to be done before a rebate can be claimed, the amount of $6,522.15 had to be collected. Therefore, an unnecessary $6,465.52 was collected. The letter continued:

Undoubtedly figure (6) will revert to the entitled people on application but in the meantime South Sea Enterprises Pty. Ltd. and Caltex will have paid this money to Federal funds. The hardship is that we have to pay this amount to Caltex for on-forwarding and the entire system ignores the fact that South Sea Enterprise Pty. Ltd. in the main are carrying some of this non-earning money on 30 day accounts. When we have borrowed money at a not inconsiderable interest and some of our customers take 120 days to pay one does not have to be Federal Treasurer to see trouble ahead. Immediately South Sea Enterprise Pty. Ltd.'s 1982/83 budget is in shambles. Can you suggest any remedy for the problem?
Certainly it is a significant problem for that company. As it says, its 1982-83 budget is in a shambles because of the problems the company is facing. It asked:
Can you suggest any remedy for the problem?
Short of a more understanding government being in power I do not know that I can suggest any remedy for that company's problem.

speech.speaker: Siddons Sen J.R.

talk.start.para: —The diesel fuel tax legislation is among the least satisfactory to be introduced into this chamber for some time. I wish to briefly examine why this is so and then foreshadow some amendments that I will be moving on behalf of the Australian Democrats at the Committee stage. The Bills give legislative force to a Budget decision to abolish the exemption from excise duty of diesel fuel for all off-road use and the introduction in its place of a rebate for certain categories, as has been outlined by previous speakers. In effect, the Government has withdrawn the exemption from a huge range of users. In its place it has allowed the rebate to apply to only about 40 per cent of users. Therefore, many people will miss out.
—Do you think there was any justification for change?

—The Government claims that the new administrative procedures will simplify the process of claiming the rebates. A ministerial statement released on 8 September announced that the adjustments were being made to reduce significantly the amount of information which users need to provide when claiming the rebate. One can only doubt whether this is so. Under the old exemption system the user had to apply for an exemption, and he had it until it was revoked. Under the new rebate system the user has to apply for the rebate on a regular basis. That means he will be continually called on to supply information to the Government to claim his rebate. As Senator Colston has already pointed out, because of the delay in getting this legislation through the Parliament many users have been, for two months or more, essentially financing the Government. They have not been able to apply for the rebate. They are paying the full excise to the Government.

speech.para: The major problem with the Bills is this: The Government has not identified the people who will suffer as a result of this new legislation. No doubt this is politically very convenient for the Government. We have made extensive inquiries of the Government. I have asked a question in the Senate to which I have received no answer. We have not been able to get an answer from any official source as to what groups will be affected and to what degree they will be affected. This is an appalling state of affairs. The Government is about to raise a considerable amount of additional revenue that it cannot supply to this Parliament or to groups in the community that will be affected. The Government has claimed that it has had considerable trouble in the policing the old exemption system. One can well understand that it has had trouble. One would not be surprised when it has now become obvious that the Government has no idea where the money is coming from, or going to, so how on earth can officials monitor use or abuse?

This lack of information, I suggest, is a critical problem not only in this case but also generally in the administration of the Government. For instance, when I introduced a Bill to exempt computer softwear from sales tax the Australian Taxation Office could not even guess at the cost of the Bill to revenue. One can only wonder what on earth is going on. Nevertheless, we have been able to find out that some groups will be very seriously affected, not the least the tourist industry, local government and the bakery industry. They will lose out very considerably if this legislation is passed in its present form. Probably through an oversight in drafting, as Senator Archer has already indicated, the fishing industry will be very seriously disadvantaged unless there is some amendment to this Bill.

For these reasons one can say only that the estimates of revenue forgone by the Bill and the amount that the Treasury projects will be collected by the rebate are extremely suspect. I am informed by the Department of Industry and Commerce that it is not even known what the cost of this legislation will be to the railways. The Treasury estimates that the removal of the exemption will increase revenue by $304m in a full year and its replacement with the rebate will cost $ 128m in a full year. In other words only 42 per cent of fuel which would be exempt at present will attract the new rebate. However, given that no one knows who is benefiting from the exemption and how much of it went towards legitimate usage, Treasury estimates cannot really be relied upon. So we cannot help being unimpressed by a piece of legislation which the Government guesses might raise $ 160m this financial year but then again it might not. It depends on how accurately the Treasury has guessed.

The important point I wish to raise is this: This legislation is another example of a hidden tax on important users and it is typical of a deceptive approach to the raising of revenue as has been illustrated on two or three occasions already in this Budget. The Government has tried to sell its Budget as a give-away Budget, but what the Government is giving with one hand it is taking away with the other. We have to look only at the total tax revenue which the Government projects to raise in its Budget to see how obvious this is-this giving with one hand and taking away with the other. The projected increase in revenue to the Government from all sources in the Budget is 10.7 per cent. That is roughly in line with inflation. So the Government is raising another 10.7 per cent in revenue. In other words it is raising almost precisely the same amount of money in real terms this year as it raised last year. If honourable senators apply deflators they will find that that was true to the year before. In other words this Budget, the previous one and the one before that are exactly the same in their effect on the economy and in the total incidence of the burden of taxation on the people of this country.

This Bill is just another example of a government masquerading as Father Christmas. When it is stripped down to the bare essentials we find that the Government is hard bitten, hard nosed and as cynical as ever. In the light of the dissatisfaction of this package of legislation with a great range of users of diesel fuel we propose to move amendments in the Committee stage which will widen the scope of the rebate that applies to local government bodies, to tourism, to industry in certain areas and to baking. At the request of the fishing industry we will also seek to amend the legislation so that the definition of 'user' will apply to fishing co-operatives and major fishing companies and processors.

I would like to explain briefly the reasons for the projected amendments. Firstly, I will deal with local government. This is a multibillion dollar industry in this country and due to the paucity of information it is very difficult for us to assess accurately what effect this legislation will have on local government. But there is no doubt that it will be very considerable indeed . In effect this legislation will impose an additional tax directly on local government. It will do this at a time of considerable unemployment, at a time when it should be looking to local government to help solve the unemployment problem and create jobs. Instead of that it is applying an additional tax.

talk.start.para: —And giving extra money to local government through another program-the Bicentenary Road Development Program.
—This has got to be disputed.
—At least balance it up, Senator.

—Local government has been subjected to a systematic attack under this Government. In fact Mr Fraser eventually met his promise to provide local government with 2 per cent of income tax revenue but he also thrust an additional responsibility on to local government out of all proportion to the additional revenue that it has received over the last few years.

speech.para: Let us look at the tourist industry. There is no doubt that this legislation will have a dramatic impact on the tourist industry. Senator Archer raised that question insofar as it applies to Tasmania. We should bear in mind the fact that in 1980-81-these are the latest available reliable statistics that we can get hold of-foreign tourists spent $949m in Australia, almost 4 per cent of the total receipts on the current account of the balance of payments. That is a very considerable amount, and we do not see how those representations can be ignored. Is this Government to apply an additional tax on the tourist industry?
Debate interrupted.

interject.speaker: The PRESIDENT

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 7 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

interject.para: That the Senate do now adjourn.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Senate adjourned at 7 p.m.

proctext.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

question.para: Did the Australian Government, in concert with the authorities in Hong Kong, approach the Federal Bureau of Investigation in the United States of America to report on the activities of companies of persons associated with Nugan Hand Limited; if so: (a) when did the Australian Government receive this report; and (b) will the Government make the report public.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: The Australian Government did not act in concert with the authorities in Hong Kong to approach the FBI about the activities of the Nugan Hand group of companies.

I am advised that the Australian Federal Police has provided access to the Commonwealth/New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking to information received in confidence from the Federal Bureau of Investigation (see Hansard 18 August 1982, page 212).

I am further advised that the AFP had also passed to the FBI a general request from the Joint Task Force for information that it, or any other U.S. intelligence or enforcement agencies may have regarding Messrs Murray Stewart Riley, Harry Wainwright and their associates, and the Nugan Hand group of companies and persons associated with them.
I am advised that the AFP received advice from the FBI early in 1982, later confirmed in writing in August, that there was no further information that could be made available.

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

question.para: (1) What progress has been made by the Joint Commonwealth/New South Wales Task Force investigating the operations of Nugan Hand Limited in Australia.
(2) Does the Minister have any indication when this Task Force might report.
(3) When it does report, will the findings of the Task Force be made public.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) to (3) The Chairman of the Management Committee of the Commonwealth/New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking presented Volume 1 of the Task Force's report entitled 'The Activities of Murray Stewart Riley, Harry Wainwright and Some Related Drug Matters', to the Prime Minister and the Premier of New South Wales in February 1982.

On the advice of the Chairman of the Management Committee, and the Operations Committee of the Joint Task Force, Volume 1 of the report has not been made public (see House of Representatives Hansard, pages 1128 and 1131 of 18 March 1982 and page 1570 of 20 April 1982).

Volume 2 of the report, entitled 'Nugan Hand-Part 1', was forwarded to the Prime Minister and the Premier of New South Wales in July 1982. Consultation between the two Governments on the tabling of this Volume is continuing. I am advised that Volume 3 of the Report is currently under preparation and should be presented to the two Governments in the next few weeks.

Finally, the Commonwealth Government has announced its decision to extend the terms of reference of Mr Justice Stewart to enable him to investigate Nugan Hand . Terms of reference are currently being discussed with New South Wales and Victoria.

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

question.para: Has the Prime Minister refuted the allegation made in the National Times on February 21 that he had 'resolutely resisted' asking the United States agencies for information about the operations of the companies associated with Nugan Hand Limited; if so, what evidence supported this refutation.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: I am advised that following requests made by the liquidator of Nugan Hand Companies to the Prime Minister's Office in 1981, the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet asked the Department of Foreign Affairs to approach the United States authorities to support the liquidator's request to the United States Consulate-General in Sydney for information relating to Nugan Hand (see answer to Question No. 2034). I am also advised that the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet supported throughout the making of inquiries by the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking, through normal police channels, to the United States agencies (see answer to Senate Question No. 2033).

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 16 March 1982:

question.para: (1) What were the complete and specific terms of reference laid down by the task force set up by the Commonwealth and New South Wales Governments which has been investigating the activities of the companies associated with Nugan Hand Limited.

(2) Has any person involved in that task force inquiry approached the Federal Government for permission to gather information from overseas sources such as the United States Central Intelligence Agency.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Following reference of recommendation five of Mr Justice Woodward's further report to the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking:

the Management Committee of the Joint Task Force decided not to include immigration aspects regarding the grant of Australian citizenship to Wainwright and the financial aspects of the Corporate Affairs Commission investigation of Nugan Hand unless the finances related to illegal drug activity (see answer to Question No. 2168);
the Operations Committee of the Joint Task Force defined Recommendation five to include briefly:

'the identification of past criminal activities (if it existed) by Riley, Wainwright, the Nugan Hand Group of companies and others associated with them, and hopefully disclose hitherto unknown drug traffickers and their associates; the establishment of the nature of relationships between individuals and business organisations, legitimate or otherwise to determine whether or not individuals were/are acting as such or were/are merely part of some larger illicit organisation, that is organised crime syndicate/s, the ''mafia'', et cetera; the assessment of the degree of influence, if any, these people exerted on the drug trade of this country; the use made by these people and organisations of banking and other institutions in their illegal and improper activities; and finally, objectively assess some areas of drug enforcement with a view to improvement.'

(2) See answer to Question No. 2033. In addition, both Governments have recently been approached by the Joint Task Force in relation to the possibility of undertaking inquiries in the United States. The matter is currently under consideration.

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 25 May 1982:

question.para: (1) When was Mr Harry Wainwright granted Australian citizenship.

(2) Were all normally required inquiries conducted into Mr Wainwright's personal history before such grant of citizenship; if so, was the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs made aware of Mr Wainwright's history, inclusive of his pending indictment in a United States of America Court on charges of conspiracy and tax evasion, and his association with organised crime figures in the United States of America.
(3) Was the grant of citizenship by Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs officials in accordance with the citizenship legislation and Government guidelines.

answer.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (2) The normal inquiries to ascertain whether Mr Wainwright was of good character were made.

As part of these inquiries, details of the application were referred to the former Commonwealth Police who advised that Mr Wainwright was not reported in Australia as having been convicted of any criminal offence, nor having any outstanding charges against him. Overseas inquiries are not automatically instituted in respect of applicants for the grant of citizenship and there was no cause for such action to be taken at the time of Mr Wainwright's application.

At no time during the processing of his application for citizenship was the Department of Immigration and Ethnic Affairs aware of Mr Wainwright's alleged history, his pending indictment in United States of America Court on charges of conspiracy and tax evasion, nor his alleged association with organised crime figures in the USA.
(3) The grant of Australian citizenship to Mr Wainwright was in accordance with the guidelines under which the then Australian Citizenship Act was interpreted. See also answer to Question No. 2167.

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 25 March 1982:

question.para: Have any instructions gone to the joint New South Wales Federal Government Task Force on Drug Trafficking as to the conduct of its enquiries into Mr Harry Wainwright; if so, what were these instructions and by whom were they given.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: No instructions have gone from the Commonwealth Government and I am not aware of any instructions having been given by the New South Waes Government. No other person or body is authorised to give directions to the Joint Task Force.

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

question.para: (1) Did the Honourable Mr Justice Woodward in his further report to the Royal Commission into Drug Trafficking to the Government of New South Wales say: 'I have in the body of this report referred to the circumstances under which Wainwright obtained citizenship of Australia.'

(2) What were these circumstances and what action has been taken to ensure that persons involved in such circumstances have been located, and appropriate action taken; if no action has been taken, why not.

answer.speaker: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Immigration and Ethnic Affairs has supplied the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) Yes.
(2) Mr Justice Woodward reported that:

'Wainwright came to Australia in 1968. In 1973 he was charged with conspiracy involving tax avoidance in the United States but shortly before indictments were filed against him, he returned to Australia and obtained Australian citizenship. I received some evidence as to the means by which he did so. They were highly suspicious and obviously call for further investigation by the appropriate authorities.' (p. 236-7)

Australian Federal Police investigation of the grant of citizenship to Mr Wainwright has not found any evidence that anyone involved in the processing of his application was aware of any adverse information at the material times (see answer to Question No. 2114) nor has any evidence been found of any criminal action by anyone in connection with the grant of that citizenship. The Attorney- General's Department has advised that there are no grounds for a prosecution against Mr Wainwright under the relevant provisions of the Australian Citizenship Act and consequently there are no grounds on which he could be deprived of his Australian citizenship. Should further information relevant to this matter emerge the case would be promptly and critically reviewed again.

question.speaker: Bolkus Sen N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Administrative Services, upon notice, on 21 April 1982:

question.para: (1) Was it agreed that the immigration aspects of Mr Wainwright's citizenship together with the financial aspects of the Corporate Affairs Commission's investigation of Nugan Hand not related to illegal drug activity would not be included, when agreeing on the terms of reference of the Joint Drug Task Force on Drug Trafficking.
(2) What inquiries, if any, are being conducted into the above two subjects.

answer.speaker: Messner Sen The Hon A.J.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Administrative Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) When recommendation five of Mr Justice Woodward's Further Report was referred, in August 1980, to the Commonwealth-New South Wales Joint Task Force on Drug Trafficking investigations into immigration aspects of the granting of Australian citizenship to Harry Wainwright and investigations into the financial aspects of the Nugan Hand Bank, were already well advanced.
In view of this, it was decided by the Management Committee of the Joint Task Force not to include these aspects in the investigations.

(2) As to the immigration aspects of the granting of Australian citizenship to Wainwright, see answer to Question No. 2167. I am advised that the inquiries by the New South Wales Corporate Affairs Commission are continuing.
