question.speaker: Mulvihill Sen J.A.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

question.para: (1) Did Samir Makary of Granville, New South Wales, flee Australia in possession of a false passport while facing a charge of being in possession of heroin.
(2) Have any efforts been made via Interpol to apprehend Samir Makary.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) A fraudulently obtained passport was issued to a person believed to be Samir Makary and it has been confirmed that he used this passport to leave Australia.

(2) I am advised that the Joint Police Task Force, Sydney, has referred this matter to the Australian National Central Bureau of Interpol which has made enquiries through Interpol to locate Samir Makary. I understand that his whereabouts have not been established.

question.speaker: Jones Sen G.N.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, upon notice, on 18 August 1982:

question.para: (1) Did the Federal Government provide the Queensland Government's Department of Aboriginal and Islander Advancement with the trawler Kuzi 13 years ago to be used as a training vessel to teach Torres Strait Islanders commercial prawning and fishing techniques and to enable Islanders to gain skippers' tickets and become professional fishermen in part of a planned commercial fishing industry there.
(2) How many Torres Strait Islanders have been trained aboard the Kuzi since its arrival on Thursday Island and what are their names and the duration of their training periods.
(3) What qualifications have these people gained aboard the Kuzi and are those qualifications recognised in Australia.
(4) What form of examination are these trainees subjected to and what is the substance of such an examination.
(5) How many Islanders have become skippers as a direct result of their training aboard the Kuzi and what are their names.
(6) How many islanders are currently fulltime commercial fishermen and what is the extent of the fishing industry throughout the Torres Strait Islands that is controlled by Islanders themselves.
(7) What is the current weekly wage of a deckhand employed on the Kuzi.
(8) Have these Islanders been used as cheap labourers aboard this vessel since it was handed over by the Commonwealth 13 years ago.

answer.speaker: Baume Sen The Hon P.E.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Aboriginal Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1) In 1970-71 the Commonwealth Government provided the Queensland Government with funds to purchase a vessel to train Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders to participate in the prawning industry.
(2) to (8) The Queensland Government owns and is responsible for the MV Kuzi, and the Queensland Department of Aboriginal and Islanders Advancement provided the following answers to these questions:

(2) Substantial numbers of Torres Strait Islanders have served on this vessel in a training capacity. It is not possible to provide personal information relating to these persons, including their identities.
(3) The qualifications for duty on a prawning vessel are mainly thorough experience and familiarity with fishing techniques, deck duties and equipment maintenance, particularly nets.
(4) No examinations are provided or needed to promote recognition in these duties.

(5) and (6) The Department does not follow nor statistically record private employment details of Torres Strait Islanders or their independent commercial interests and activities, whether maritime or otherwise. Fisheries are largely controlled by the State and Commonwealth authorities.

(7) Wages on commercial fishing boats depend on the volume of catch and agreed catch sharing arrangements after costs. It is a joint venture scheme and personal incomes depend on and vary with these factors.

question.speaker: Evans Sen G.J.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, upon notice, on 19 August 1982:

question.para: What steps have been taken to implement the Convention on the World Cultural and National Heritage, ratified by Australia on 22 August 1974, in particular in relationship to matters involving the Aboriginal cultural heritage.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: Australia has nominated several sites to be included on the World Heritage List . Three of these nominations have been accepted by the World Heritage Committee for inclusion in the World Heritage List. Two of these are of paramount Aboriginal significance and were selected for that reason. These are the Kakadu National Park (for the antiquity and quality of its Aboriginal rock art and archaeological sites) and the Willandra Lakes Region, which contains the earliest cremation evidence in the world, together with unique evidence of the early life of Australian Aboriginals. In addition there are other Aboriginal sites currently being recorded for preservation and possible inclusion on the World Heritage List.

The Department of Home Affairs and Environment ceased involvement in the 'Life. Be in it' program before any recommendation could be adopted.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 15 September 1982:

question.para: (1) What has been the value of imports of military equipment in each financial year since 1969-70.
(2) What has been the Commonwealth's overseas deficit in each financial year since 1969-70.
(3) What has been the proportion of imports of military equipment in the Commonwealth's overseas deficit in each financial year since 1969-70.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

answer.para: (1), (2) and (3) The table below sets out the data requested.
Imports of Commonwealth's
military overseas Financial
equipment budget year
and stores (1) deficit (2) (1)/(2)

The series for imports of military equipment and stores was compiled by the Australian Bureau of Statistics by making, wherever possible, balance of payments valuation, timing and coverage adjustments to overseas trade statistics . The series on the Commonwealth's overseas budget deficit is taken from various budget statements.

It should be noted that movements in the series for imports of military equipment and stores and in the Commonwealth's overseas budget deficit do not necessarily closely correspond. For example, large jumps are evident in the import data in 1973-74 and 1980-81, when Australia took delivery of major items of military equipment; however, corresponding increases are not evident in the Commonwealth's overseas budget deficit. This is because of the practice of making substantial advance payments in years prior to the delivery of major items of military equipment.
Thus, the proportions shown in the final column of the table are quite erratic and little significance can be accorded to the result in any particular year.

answer.speaker: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

talk.start.para: —On 8 September 1982 (Hansard, page 687) Senator McLaren asked the Minister for Social Security the following question without notice:

answer.para: What amount of money will be available to the Lerwin Nursing Home in Murray Bridge out of the increased funds which he recently announced.
The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

On 8 September 1982 I announced Commonwealth grants totalling more than $15m to 94 organisations providing accommodation and other services for aged and handicapped people. The Lerwin Nursing Home in Murray Bridge is one of those 94 organisations. A Commonwealth grant estimated at $636,000 has been made available to assist in the construction of the proposed 40 bed nursing home.

answer.speaker: Guilfoyle Sen The Hon Dame M.G.C.

talk.start.para: —On 12 October 1982 (Hansard, page 1296) Senator Jones asked me, as Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs, without notice:

answer.para: I ask the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs whether she can inform the Senate of the date on which the Torres Strait Treaty will be ratified?
The Minister for Foreign Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

No date has yet been fixed for the ratification of the Torres Strait Treaty, which is dependent upon the enactment of complex implementing legislation, in both Papua New Guinea and Australia, particularly relating to the management of fisheries in the Torres Strait area. Discussions have been proceeding with Queensland, which will introduce complementary legislation. Draft Commonwealth legislation is now almost ready for presentation to Parliament.
